CODE OF ORDINANCES CITY OF SOCIAL CIRCLE, GEORGIA 
____________ 
Published in 2018 by Order of the City Council 
____________ 

PREFACE 
    This Code constitutes a codification of the general and permanent ordinances of the City of Social Circle, Georgia. 
    Source materials used in the preparation of the Code were the 2014 Code, as supplemented through 2016, and ordinances subsequently adopted by the city council. The source of each section is included in the history note appearing in parentheses at the end thereof. By use of the comparative tables appearing in the back of this Code, the reader can locate any section of the 2014 Code, as supplemented, and any subsequent ordinance included herein. 
    The various sections within each chapter have been catchlined to facilitate usage. Notes which tie related sections of the Code together and which refer to relevant state law have been included. 
Chapter and Section Numbering System 
    The chapter and section numbering system used in this Code is the same system used in many state and local government codes. Each section number consists of two parts separated by a dash. The figure before the dash refers to the chapter number, and the figure after the dash refers to the position of the section within the chapter. Thus, the second section of chapter 1 is numbered 1-2, and the first section of chapter 6 is 6-1. Under this system, each section is identified with its chapter, and at the same time new sections can be inserted in their proper place by using the decimal system for amendments. For example, if new material consisting of one section that would logically come between sections 6-1 and 6-2 is desired to be added, such new section would be numbered 6-1.5. New articles and new divisions may be included in the same way or, in the case of articles, may be placed at the end of the chapter embracing the subject, and, in the case of divisions, may be placed at the end of the article embracing the subject. The next successive number shall be assigned to the new article or division. New chapters may be included by using one of the reserved chapter numbers. 
Page Numbering System 
    The page numbering system used in this Code is a prefix system. The letters to the left of the colon are an abbreviation which represents a certain portion of the volume. The number to the right of the colon represents the number of the page in that portion. In the case of a chapter of the Code, the number to the left of the colon indicates the number of the chapter. In the case of an appendix to the Code, the letter immediately to the left of the colon indicates the letter of the appendix. The following are typical parts of codes of ordinances, which may or may not appear in this Code at this time, and their corresponding prefixes: 
CHARTER CHT:1 RELATED LAWS RL:1 SPECIAL ACTS SA:1 CHARTER COMPARATIVE TABLE CHTCT:1 RELATED LAWS COMPARATIVE TABLE RLCT:1 SPECIAL ACTS COMPARATIVE TABLE SACT:1 CODE CD1:1 CODE APPENDIX CDA:1 CODE COMPARATIVE TABLES CCT:1 STATE LAW REFERENCE TABLE SLT:1 CHARTER INDEX CHTi:1 CODE INDEX CDi:1  
Index 
    The index has been prepared with the greatest of care. Each particular item has been placed under several headings, some of which are couched in lay phraseology, others in legal terminology, and still others in language generally used by local government officials and employees. There are numerous cross references within the index itself which stand as guideposts to direct the user to the particular item in which the user is interested. 
Looseleaf Supplements 
    A special feature of this publication is the looseleaf system of binding and supplemental servicing of the publication. With this system, the publication will be kept up to date. Subsequent amendatory legislation will be properly edited, and the affected page or pages will be reprinted. These new pages will be distributed to holders of copies of the publication, with instructions for the manner of inserting the new pages and deleting the obsolete pages. 
    Keeping this publication up to date at all times will depend largely upon the holder of the publication. As revised pages are received, it will then become the responsibility of the holder to have the amendments inserted according to the attached instructions. It is strongly recommended by the publisher that all such amendments be inserted immediately upon receipt to avoid misplacing them and, in addition, that all deleted pages be saved and filed for historical reference purposes. 
Acknowledgments 
    The publisher is most grateful to Susan M. Roper, City Clerk, for her cooperation and assistance during the progress of the work on this publication. It is hoped that her efforts and those of the publisher have resulted in a Code of Ordinances which will make the active law of the city readily accessible to all citizens and which will be a valuable tool in the day-to-day administration of the city's affairs. 
Copyright 
    All editorial enhancements of this Code are copyrighted by Municipal Code Corporation and the City of Social Circle, Georgia. Editorial enhancements include, but are not limited to: organization; table of contents; section catchlines; prechapter section analyses; editor's notes; cross references; state law references; numbering system; code comparative table; state law reference table; and index. Such material may not be used or reproduced for commercial purposes without the express written consent of Municipal Code Corporation and the City of Social Circle, Georgia.

ORDINANCE NO. 2017-12 
AN ORDINANCE TO CODIFY THE ORDINANCES OF THE CITY OF SOCIAL CIRCLE, GEORGIA TO BE KNOWN AND DESIGNATED AS "CITY CODE OF SOCIAL CIRCLE, GEORGIA 2017". 
    TITLE This provision is designated to set forth the General Code of Ordinances of the City of Social Circle which includes the following items: 
General Provisions, Elections, Administration, Taxation, City Court and Enforcement of Ordinances, Public Health and Safety, Land Building Regulations, Traffic and Parking, General Offenses, Alcohol and Entertainment Regulations, Regulations of City Owned Utility Systems, Miscellaneous Regulations, Natural Gas, Cable Television Franchise, Effectivity and Validity of Code, a copy of which is attached hereto as Exhibit "A". 
    WHEREAS , the Mayor and Council are authorized to adopt a code of Ordinances for the City of Social Circle pursuant to Section 2.25 of the City Charter, and 
    WHEREAS , it is in the best interest of the health, safety and welfare of the citizens of Social Circle to maintain such a code of Ordinances and this new code shall be entitled the "City Code of Social Circle, Georgia," and also designated as "City Code of the City of Social Circle, Georgia 2017, 
    THE COUNCIL OF THE CITY OF SOCIAL CIRCLE HEREBY ORDAINS , that the "City Code of Social Circle, Georgia" be designated as "City Code of Social Circle, Georgia 2017," and is hereby adopted as the Official Code of the City of Social Circle, Georgia pursuant to the authority of Section 2.25 of the Charter of the City of Social Circle, Georgia as enacted by the General Assembly of Georgia. 
    The City Clerk is hereby authorized to retain the services of an electronic municipal code compilation company for the purpose of satisfying the electronic display requirements of the Georgia Code and the updating procedures required by Section 2.25 of the City's Charter. 
SO ORDAINED this 20 th day of June, 2017.

ORDINANCE NO. 2018-5 
AN ORDINANCE ADOPTING AND ENACTING A NEW CODE FOR THE OFFICIAL CODE OF THE CITY OF SOCIAL CIRCLE, GEORGIA; PROVIDING FOR THE REPEAL OF CERTAIN ORDINANCES NOT INCLUDED THEREIN; PROVIDING A PENALTY FOR THE VIOLATION THEREOF; PROVIDING FOR THE MANNER OF AMENDING SUCH CODE; AND PROVIDING WHEN SUCH CODE AND THIS ORDINANCE SHALL BECOME EFFECTIVE. 
    BE IT ORDAINED BY THE: 
    Section 1. The Code entitled the "Official Code of the City of Social Circle, Georgia," published by Municipal Code Corporation, consisting of chapters 1 through 17, each inclusive, is adopted. 
    Section 2. All ordinances of a general and permanent nature enacted on or before Feb. 20, 2018, and not included in the Code or recognized and continued in force by reference therein, are repealed. 
    Section 3. The repeal provided for in section 2 hereof shall not be construed to revive any ordinance or part thereof that has been repealed by a subsequent ordinance that is repealed by this ordinance. 
    Section 4. Unless another penalty is expressly provided, every person convicted of a violation of any provision of the Code or any ordinance, rule or regulation adopted or issued in pursuance thereof shall be punished by a fine not to exceed $1,000.00, or by confinement for a maximum term not to exceed six months, or both. Each act of violation and each day upon which any such violation shall continue or occur shall constitute a separate offense. The penalty provided by this section, unless another penalty is expressly provided, shall apply to the amendment of any Code section, whether or not such penalty is reenacted in the amendatory ordinance. In addition to the penalty prescribed above, the City may pursue other remedies such as abatement of nuisances, injunctive relief and revocation of licenses or permits. 
    Section 5. Additions or amendments to the Code when passed in such form as to indicate the intention of the City to make the same a part of the Code shall be deemed to be incorporated in the Code, so that reference to the Code includes the additions and amendments. 
    Section 6. Ordinances adopted after Feb. 20, 2018, that amend or refer to ordinances that have been codified in the Code shall be construed as if they amend or refer to like provisions of the Code. 
    Section 7. This ordinance shall become effective October 16, 2018. 
  
Passed and adopted by the City Council this 16 th day of October, 2018.

SUPPLEMENT HISTORY TABLE 
    The table below allows users of this Code to quickly and accurately determine what ordinances have been considered for codification in each supplement. Ordinances that are of a general and permanent nature are codified in the Code and are considered "Included." Ordinances that are not of a general and permanent nature are not codified in the Code and are considered "Omitted." 
    By adding to this table with each supplement, users of this Code of Ordinances will be able to gain a more complete picture of the Code's historical evolution.

Chapter 1 - GENERAL PROVISIONS 

Sec. 1-1. - Purpose; how Code designated and cited. 
(a)  General. The mayor and council of the City of Social Circle, Georgia ("city") desires to maintain a system by which all regulations of the city are easily accessed and understood by law enforcement officers and other city and county employees, local elected officials, and members of the general public. It is also the stated intention of the mayor and council that all regulations of the city be kept in a manner that will provide the same accessibility and understanding of such regulations in posterity. 
(b)  Amendment of the Official Code of the City of Social Circle, Georgia. This document, the Official Code of the City of Social Circle, has been created and is hereby amended in order to fulfill the stated purpose identified in subsection (a) above. 
(Former § 1-001(1.1, 1.2)) 
Sec. 1-2. - Definitions. 
    Advise and consent. Whenever the term "advise and consent of the council" is used in this Code, it shall be construed to mean an affirmative vote of the majority of a quorum of the council. 
    Building inspector means the building inspector of the city. 
    City means the City of Social Circle, Georgia. 
    City council or council means the mayor and city council of the city. 
    City manager means the person hired by the council as the chief administrative officer of the city, to whom all city employees are responsible with respect to performance of their job duties. 
    Clerk means the person hired by the council and appointed by the council as the clerk or the acting clerk of the city. 
    Code means the Official Code of the City of Social Circle, Georgia, adopted as such by the council. 
    County shall mean Walton County, Georgia. 
    Court or city court means the city court of the city. 
    Judge or recorder means the judge of the city court. 
    Mayor means the mayor of the city. 
    Mayor and council (or council ) means the mayor and council of the city. 
    Misdemeanor means a violation punishable by a fine not in excess of $1,000.00, confinement not exceeding six months, or both. 
    Official means the mayor or a member of the council. 
    Ordinance means a legislative act of the council of a general and permanent nature. 
    Owner, when applied to a building or to land, shall include any part owner, joint owner, tenant in common, joint tenant, or tenant by the entirety, of the whole or a part of such building or land. 
    Person includes a person, corporation, entity, firm, partnership, association, organization, and any other group acting as a unit. 
    Personal property includes every type of property except real property. 
    Property includes real, personal and mixed estates and interests. 
    Real property includes lands, tenements and hereditaments. 
    Reasonable time or notice shall be deemed to mean only such time as may be necessary for the prompt performance of the act required. 
    Resolution means a legislative act of the council of a special or temporary character. 
    Sidewalk means an improved portion of street between the curb and the adjacent property, intended for the use of pedestrians. 
    State means the State of Georgia. 
    Street means any public way, road, highway, street, avenue, boulevard, parkway, alley, viaduct or bridge, and the approaches thereto, within the city. 
    Tenant or occupant, when applied to a building or to land, shall include any person holding a written or oral lease of, or who occupies the whole or a part of, such building or land, either alone or with others. 
(Former § 1-001(2.1-2.26)) 
Sec. 1-3. - Amendments; hearings. 
(a)  Amendments to the Code. The council may from time to time amend the Code. The council may read and consider the proposed amendment at a regularly scheduled or properly called special meeting of the council. Following the reading, the council may vote to adopt, adopt with modifications, disapprove or table the proposed amendment. If the vote is for adoption, then the city manager shall make the amendment a physical part of the Code. Said amendment shall immediately upon adoption by the council become part of this Code. 
(b)  Public hearings; other requirements. In addition to the requirements in subsection (a) above, certain sections of this Code require that a public hearing be properly called, advertised and conducted concerning certain proposed amendments, prior to the council's consideration and adoption of said amendments. These public hearing requirements, along with any other provisions of this Code pertaining to such amendments, shall be adhered to by the council. 
(c)  Amendments to Code. The council may also from time to time adopt regulations that currently do not exist in the Code, or otherwise make revisions or changes to the structure or content of the Code itself. In so doing, the council shall follow the procedures set forth in subsection (a) above. In addition, the council shall conduct a public hearing if such a hearing is required by law or by the charter of the city. If the council votes to adopt new regulations, or votes to otherwise make revisions or changes to the structure or content of the Code, then the city manager shall make the regulations a physical part of the Code. Said new regulations shall immediately upon adoption by the council become part of this Code. 
(Former § 1-003(1.1-1.3)) 
Sec. 1-4. - Rules of construction. 
    In the construction of this Code the following rules shall be observed, unless such construction would be inconsistent with the manifest intent of the council: 
(1)  General rule. All words and phrases shall be construed and understood according to the common and approved usage of the language; but technical words and phrases and such others as may have acquired a peculiar and appropriate meaning in the law shall be construed and understood according to such peculiar and appropriate meaning. 
(2)  Delegation of authority. Whenever this Code requires the head of a department or other officer of the city to do some act or perform some duty, it shall be construed to authorize subordinates to do the required act or perform the required duty unless the terms of the Code require otherwise. 
(3)  Computation of time. The time within which an act is to be done as provided in this Code or in any order issued thereunder, when expressed in days, shall be computed by excluding the first day and including the last, except if the last day is Sunday or a holiday it shall be excluded; when any such time is expressed in hours, Sunday, from midnight to midnight, shall be excluded. 
(4)  Overlapping provisions. Where any provision of this Code imposes greater restrictions upon the subject matter than any general provisions imposed by this Code, the provision imposing the greater restriction or regulation shall be applicable. 
(Former § 1-003(2.)) 
Sec. 1-5. - Violations and penalties. 
(b)  Penalties. 
(1)  Penalties specified by Code section. The monetary and/or civil penalties to be imposed upon persons who violate the Code are specified within the individual sections of this Code, except as otherwise established by the council or by law. 
(2)  Penalty where no penalty provided. Any person who violates this Code for which no penalty has been set forth shall, upon conviction, be subject to punishment by a fine not to exceed $1,000.00, or by confinement for a maximum term not to exceed six months, or both. 
(3)  Each day violation occurs constitutes separate offense. Except as otherwise specified herein, any violation of this Code shall constitute a separate offense each day it occurs, and be subject to a separate penalty for each day of violation. 
(c)  Enforcement. 
(1)  City manager. Except as otherwise specified herein, the city manager is responsible for daily administration of the Code. This includes, but is not limited to, ensuring the Code is viable and up to date, applying the Code, and informing the council on any need to amend the Code. 
(2)  Citations. Except as otherwise specified herein, the city manager should see that any person violating this Code is issued a citation to appear in the city court. 
(Former § 1-004) 
Sec. 1-6. - Severability. 
(a)  Severability. 
(1)  General. If any chapter, section, paragraph, phrase or clause or any part of the Code shall be declared invalid or unconstitutional, or if the provisions of any part of said document as applied to any particular situation or set of circumstances shall be declared invalid or unconstitutional, such invalidity shall not be construed to affect the portions of this document not so held to be invalid, or the application of the Code to other circumstances not so held to be invalid. It is hereby declared as the intent of the council that the Code would have been adopted had such invalid portion not been included herein. 
(2)  Conflicts between specific and general provisions. Where there is an apparent conflict in this Code between specific and general provisions, the specific shall control. 
(b)  Repeal of conflicting provisions. All Codes and ordinances, or parts thereof, in conflict with the contents of this Code, and not preserved hereby, are hereby repealed, and this Code shall remain in effect until amended or repealed by the council. 
(Former § 1-002) 
Chapter 2 - ELECTIONS 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 2-1. - Adoption of state rules and regulations. 
    The rules and regulations promulgated by the state election board which pertain to municipal elections, together with the provisions of the Georgia Municipal Election Code contained in O.C.G.A., tit. 21, are hereby adopted as the rules, regulations, and provisions that shall govern the conduct of municipal general and special elections in this city. 
(Former § 2-001) 
Sec. 2-2. - Expenses. 
    Such funds as are necessary for the conduct of elections and for the performance of the duties that are specified by this chapter shall be budgeted and appropriated annually, and from time to time. 
(Former § 2-002) 
Secs. 2-3-2-25. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - REGISTRATION 

Sec. 2-26. - Election superintendent. 
(a)  Appointment. The election superintendent and his deputies shall be appointed by the council, as necessary, and shall serve at the pleasure of same. The election superintendent shall generally supervise and direct the administration of this article. All appointments shall be entered on the minutes of the council meeting at which they are made. 
(b)  Qualifications. The election superintendent and his deputies shall be electors of the city and shall be able to read, write, and speak the English language. Such appointees, while so serving, and within a period of six months after so serving, shall not be eligible for any nomination or office to be voted for at a primary or election. 
(c)  Oath. Prior to performing any duties, the election superintendent and all deputies shall swear to faithfully perform their duties, such oath to be administered by an officer authorized by law to administer the oath. 
(d)  Term of office. Persons appointed as election superintendent or deputy election superintendent shall serve for four years and until their successors are appointed and qualified, except in the event of resignation or removal as hereinafter provided. 
(e)  Powers. The election superintendent and all deputies shall exercise those powers and duties and shall be subject to such regulations as are set forth in the Georgia Municipal Election Code, O.C.G.A. § 21-3-1 et seq. 
(f)  Resignation or removal. The election superintendent and all deputies shall have the right to resign at any time by submitting a resignation to the council. The council shall have the right at any time to remove one or more of such deputies for cause after notice and hearing. If any election superintendent or deputy resigns or is removed for cause, all duties and authority as such shall terminate instantly. In the event of death, resignation, removal of the election superintendent or any deputies, the council shall appoint a successor who shall serve out the unexpired term. Each such appointment shall be entered on the minutes of the council meeting at which the appointment is made. 
(Former § 2-003) 
Sec. 2-27. - Elector qualifications. 
    Any person desiring to vote in any election must register as an elector at least 15 days prior to the primary or election at which he desires to vote; be a citizen of Georgia; be at least 18 years of age; and be a resident of the city. 
(Former § 2-004) 
Sec. 2-28. - Registration lists and records. 
    The county board of registrars shall be responsible for maintaining city voting registration cards. The form of the registration cards shall conform to the Georgia Election Code. The completed registration cards shall be kept in the main office of the county board of registrars. The other papers of the election superintendent shall be kept in the office of the election superintendent at city hall and shall be open to public inspection during usual business hours. 
(Former § 2-005) 
Sec. 2-29. - Challenge of registration list. 
    Any elector of the city shall have the right to challenge the registration of any person whose name appears on the registration list, in the manner set forth in the Georgia Election Code. 
(Former § 2-006) 
Sec. 2-30. - Permanency of registration. 
    Registration of an elector will be per the Georgia Election Code. 
(Former § 2-007) 
Sec. 2-31. - Absentee registration. 
    Absentee registration shall be per the Georgia Election Code. 
(Former § 2-008) 
Secs. 2-32-2-50. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - CANDIDATES 

Sec. 2-51. - Notice of candidacy. 
    Each candidate desiring to have his name placed on the ballot for an office to be filled shall file per the Georgia Election Code. 
(Former § 2-009) 
Sec. 2-52. - Qualification fees. 
    The qualification fee for candidates filing a notice of candidacy in any general or special election for mayor and/or city councilman, shall be the maximum amount allowed by the Georgia Election Code, which fee shall be paid at the time of filing. 
(Former § 2-010) 
Sec. 2-53. - Campaign financing disclosure. 
    All candidates shall keep all such records and file such reports required by the Georgia Campaign and Financial Disclosure Act. 
(Former § 2-011) 
Secs. 2-54-2-75. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - VOTING 

Sec. 2-76. - Election officials. 
(a)  Appointment. The following election officials shall be appointed by the council and receive compensation as provided by same: 
Municipal election superintendent; chief manager; two assistant managers; clerks, as necessary. 
(b)  Qualifications and powers. The municipal election superintendent and all poll officers shall meet such qualifications and exercise all such powers and duties as are provided in the Georgia Election Code. 
(Former § 2-012) 
Sec. 2-77. - Election districts. 
    The area comprising the corporate limits of the city shall be divided into election districts as determined by Home Rule. 
(Former § 2-013) 
Sec. 2-78. - Polling places. 
    The polling place within the city shall be located in the city and shall be designated by the council. 
(Former § 2-014) 
Sec. 2-79. - Date of election. 
    All municipal elections shall be held per the Georgia Election Code. 
(Former § 2-015) 
Sec. 2-80. - Write-in-votes. 
    Write-in votes shall be permitted in municipal elections, per the Georgia Election Code. 
(Former § 2-016) 
Sec. 2-81. - Absentee ballots. 
    Absentee ballots shall be used per the Georgia Election Code. 
(Former § 2-017) 
Sec. 2-82. - Contested elections. 
    Elections conducted pursuant to this may be contested as provided in the Georgia Election Code. 
(Former § 2-018) 
Secs. 2-83-2-100. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - RECALL 

Sec. 2-101. - General. 
    The mayor or any city councilman shall be subject to recall as provided by state law. 
(Former § 2-019) 
Sec. 2-102. - Procedure for recall. 
    Recall of any elected officer from office shall be brought about in the manner provided by state law. 
(Former § 2-020) 
Chapter 3 - ADMINISTRATION 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 3-1. - Exercise of governmental authority. 
    The corporate governmental powers of the city shall be exercised by the council as provided by Charter and by this chapter. 
(Former § 3-001) 
Sec. 3-2. - Library fund restrictions. 
    On September 11, 1990, effective date October 1, 1990, the mayor and council of the city established a trust for the benefit of the beneficiary, Social Circle, for its city library, known and described under the trust as the William H. Stanton Memorial Library ("library"). 
    In January, 2017 legal action is being filed to dissolve the trust, because the total revenue, interest, dividends and other cash accumulations to the trust had been consumed by the fees and expenses paid to SunTrust Bank. The superior court is being asked to terminate the trust, and award the entirety of the trust funds to the city. The funds are then to be maintained exclusively and perpetually in a separate earmarked account, solely for the purposes described hereinbelow. 
    Consistent with said trust, and also with the original testamentary trust, the income only, of the funds from the trust, shall be utilized, and only for the following purposes, with the corpus/principal of the funds being maintained intact in perpetuity: 
(1)  Maintenance of the new library building (current or future replacement Social Circle library) which shall include, but not be limited to, the cost of adequate fire and extended coverage insurance on the said building, books, furniture and fixtures; 
(2)  Purchase of books for the said library; 
(3)  Purchase of items and devices designed to aid persons who are blind, or who have impaired eyesight or hearing deficiencies, so as to enable them more advantageously to use the library; and 
(4)  To assist in library problems and needs designated to develop cultural opportunities for the Social Circle community. No more than one-third of the said income may be used in any one year for the purposes set out above. 
    The city shall maintain the library's name as "The William H. Stanton Memorial Library", in perpetuity, and the conference/meeting room shall be designated and marked in perpetuity as "The Walthour Hall." 
(Ord. No. 2017-2, 1-17-2017) 
Secs. 3-3-3-25. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - OFFICERS AND EMPLOYEES 

Sec. 3-26. - Administrative policy and procedures. 
(a)  Officers. Each officer shall perform all duties required of his office by state law, the Charter, and this Code, and such other duties not in conflict therewith as may be required. 
(b)  Department heads. All department heads shall: 
(1)  Be immediately responsible to the city manager for the effective administration of their respective department and all activities assigned thereto; 
(2)  Keep informed as to the latest practices in their particular field and institute, with the approval of the city manager, such new practices as would benefit the public; 
(3)  Submit quarterly and annual reports of the activities of their respective department to the city manager; 
(4)  Establish and maintain a system of filing and indexing records and reports in sufficient detail to furnish all information necessary for proper control of departmental activities and to form a basis for the periodic reports to the city manager; 
(5)  Be responsible for the proper maintenance of all city property and equipment used in their respective departments. 
(c)  Departments. Each department shall cooperate with every other department and shall furnish, upon the direction of the city manager, any other department such service, labor, and materials as may be requisitioned by the head of each department, as its own facilities permit. 
(d)  Operation of administrative services. All units in the administrative services shall accomplish the following: 
(1)  Office hours. Generally be open between the hours of 8:00 a.m. and 4:30 p.m. on weekdays and shall be closed Saturday, Sunday, and legal holidays. 
(2)  Make daily deposit. Make a daily deposit with the city treasurer of any monies received directly from the public. 
(3)  Payment of monies. Pay out monies belonging to the city in the manner prescribed herein. 
(Former § 3-003) 
Sec. 3-27. - Oaths. 
    All officers and employees required by Charter or some other provision of law to take an oath shall, before entering upon the discharge of their respective duties, take and subscribe the following oath before an officer authorized by law to administer oaths: 
"I, ___________, do solemnly swear or affirm that: 
I will faithfully execute the office of mayor/council person [strike one] of the City of Social Circle, and to the best of my ability support and defend the Constitution of the United States, the Constitution of Georgia, and the Charter, ordinances, and regulations of the City of Social Circle; 
I am not the holder of any unaccounted for public money due this state or any political subdivision or authority thereof; 
I am not the holder of any office of trust under the government of the United States, any other state, or any foreign state which I by the laws of the State of Georgia am prohibited from holding; 
I am otherwise qualified to hold said office according to the Constitution and laws of Georgia; 
I have been a resident of my district and the City of Social Circle for the time required by the Constitution and laws of this state; 
I will perform the duties of my office in the best interest of the City of Social Circle to the best of my ability without fear, favor, affection, reward or expectation thereof." 
Sworn to this ___ day of _______, 201___, 
      (Official taking oath)         Witness       In addition to those named in the Charter, any officer authorized by law to administer an oath (i.e. judges of the superior, probate, magistrate, and municipal court) may swear a municipal officer. A written copy of the oath shall be filed with the city clerk. A formal public ceremony, if desired, may be held at a different time. Finally, some officials may wish to follow optional traditions such as placing their hand on religious or secular material of their choosing (in some instances officials have been sworn while placing their hand on the laws and Constitution of the applicable government) while taking the oath, or by adding at the end, "so help me God." 
(Former § 3-004) 
Sec. 3-28. - Bonds. 
    Except as otherwise provide by law, the council may require any department head, city official, or employee, before entering upon the discharge of his duties, to give good and sufficient bond in any amount decided by the council. Said bond shall be payable to the city for the faithful performance of said duties and to protect the city from corruption, malfeasance, misappropriations, or unlawful expenditures in office. Said surety bonds shall be obtained from a surety company licensed to do business in Georgia which appears in the Federal Circular 570 and is approved by the council. The premiums thereon shall be paid by the city. 
(Former § 3-005) 
Sec. 3-29. - Compensation. 
    Each officer and employee of the city shall receive such compensation as may be provided from time to time by the council. 
(Former § 3-006) 
Sec. 3-30. - Election. 
    The mayor and the council shall be elected for four-year terms. Each shall serve until his successor is elected and qualified. 
(Former § 3-007) 
Sec. 3-31. - Qualification for office. 
    Any person whose principal place of residence is within the corporate limits of the city and who is both a qualified voter of the city and at least 18 at the time of election and meets all other legal requirements shall be eligible for the office of mayor or council. 
(Former § 3-008) 
Sec. 3-32. - Vacancies. 
    In case of a vacancy in the office of mayor or council from failure to elect, death, removal, or any cause whatsoever, such vacancy shall be filled as provided by law. 
(Former § 3-009) 
Sec. 3-33. - Council meetings. 
    The council shall hold regular meetings on the third Tuesday of each month at 6:30 p.m., unless otherwise ordered by the council; provided, that the mayor may convene the council whenever, in his opinion, the public business requires it, and he shall do so upon the application of three members of the council. It shall be the duty of each member of the council to attend each meeting of the council, unless prevented by some unavoidable circumstance. Per the Georgia Sunshine Laws, 2012 Rewrite, HB 397, Open and Public Meetings Act (O.C.G.A. §§ 50-14-1 et seq.) and the Open Records Act (O.C.G.A. §§ 50-18-70 et seq.), the following apply: The meeting agenda will be available to the general public a week in advance, and a notice containing such information will be posted and maintained in a conspicuous place available to the public at the regular meeting place and on any city website. The agenda shall list all items to be considered and briefly state what action is requested. All items timely submitted by city officials and staff to be on the agenda shall be placed on the agenda, and no one shall prohibit such a timely request from appearing on the agenda. Public requests to have an agenda item require clearly advising the clerk of the nature and details of the item including a summary of their position, and to provide all supporting documentation to be referenced in the meeting. To appear on a regular monthly meeting's agenda, the item must be submitted to the clerk by 1:00 p.m. on Tuesday of the week prior to the meeting. The agenda, together with data, reports, and memoranda, should be sent early enough to reach each member at least three days before the meeting. Any item received after the deadline will be held over for the next meeting unless a majority present at the meeting vote to add it to the agenda. Failure to include on the agenda an item which becomes necessary to address during the course of a meeting shall not preclude considering and acting upon such item. Public requests are to be added to the agenda as Item IV of the agenda titled, "Citizen Request." 
    For specially called meetings, the agenda shall consist only of the item or items specifically indicated as the purpose of the called meeting. When any called meeting is to be held, the city will give due notice thereof, the posting of a written notice for at least 24 hours at the place of regular meetings and giving of written or oral notice at least 24 hours in advance of the meeting to the legal organ in the county where regular meetings are held and, upon written request from any local broadcast or print media outlet whose place of business and physical facilities are located in the county, notice by telephone or facsimile to that requesting media outlet at least 24 hours in advance of the called meeting. When special circumstances occur and are so declared by the mayor and council at the meeting, they may hold an emergency meeting with less than 24 hours' notice upon giving such notice of the meeting and subjects expected to be considered at the meeting as is reasonable under the circumstances including notice to said legal organ, in which event the reason for holding the meeting within 24 hours and the nature of the notice shall be recorded in the minutes. Any oral notice required or permitted by this subsection may be given by telephone. A summary of the subjects acted on and those members present at a meeting shall be written and made available to the public for inspection within two business days of the adjournment of a meeting. The minutes of a meeting shall be promptly recorded and such records (other than executive session minutes) shall be open to public inspection. Said minutes shall, at a minimum, include the names of the members present at the meeting, a description of each motion or other proposal made, and a record of all votes, who voted for and against. Official minutes of the meetings shall be maintained in the city hall. Copies of contracts, maps, or similar material or documents related to actions taken may be included in the minutes, or incorporated by reference to an alternate location, in which case, such documents shall be stored in a central location identified by ordinance or resolution. Open Records shall be maintained per the state Records Retention Act, O.C.G.A. §§ 50-18-90 et seq. See O.C.G.A. § 50-18-71(a). Records must be produced within three business days of an open records request if possible. If not, the response must be made within three business days as to when the records will be produced, O.C.G.A. § 50-18-71(b)(1)(A). Requests can be made orally or in writing. O.C.G.A. § 50-18-71(b)(1)(B). All written requests shall go to a records custodian, O.C.G.A. § 50-18-71(b)(1)(B), the city clerk. The legal organ is notified of such, and the custodian is posted on any city website, O.C.G.A. § 50-18-71(b)(2). The three-day response period starts when the custodian gets the request. Charges for search, retrieval, redaction and production of copies is at the rate of the lowest paid full time employee able to respond, O.C.G.A. § 50-18-71(c)(1), the first 15 minutes are free. The city charges for redacting records, O.C.G.A. § 50-18-71(c)(1). Fees for copying records are $0.10/page for letter or legal size documents. For odd-size printed documents, the actual cost of producing the documents is charged. For electronic records, the city charges the actual cost of the media on which the records or data are produced, O.C.G.A. § 50-18-71(c)(2). The city charges for requested records, even if not picked up, O.C.G.A. § 50-18-71(c)(3). If estimated cost of producing records is over $25.00, the clerk shall notify the requestor within three business days of the request as to the estimated amount. The city can defer search until the requestor agrees to pay. If estimated cost of production is over $500.00, the city requires prepayment before the search, retrieval, review or production of records, O.C.G.A. § 50-18-71(d). If costs are not paid to the city, it requires prepayment for all new requests, until the previous charges are paid, O.C.G.A. § 50-18-71(d). If records are sought as part of litigation, the request must be in writing and copied to the city attorney. The city will prepare a duplicate set of the requested documents to the city attorney unless the city attorney elects not to receive them, O.C.G.A. § 50-18-71(e). Requests for emails shall contain information reasonably calculated to allow the clerk to locate the requested messages such as name, title, office or specific data base to be searched, O.C.G.A. § 50-18-71(g). The city shall not prepare new reports, summaries, or compilations not in existence at the time of the request, O.C.G.A. § 50-18-71(j). Personal email addresses, unlisted phone numbers, cell phone numbers found in public records are exempted and will be redacted, O.C.G.A. § 50-18-72(a)(20)(A). The exemption for home address, home telephone numbers, SSN, DOB, credit card, bank account, and similar personal data is extended to former and current employees, O.C.G.A. § 50-18-72(a)(21). When any meeting is closed to the public, the specific reasons for such closure shall be entered in the minutes, the meeting shall not be closed except by a majority vote of a quorum, the minutes shall reflect the names of the members present and the names of those voting for closure, and that part of the minutes shall be made available to the public as any other minutes. Any portion of the meeting not subject to any such exception, privilege, or confidentiality shall be open to the public, and the minutes of such portions not subject to any such exception shall be open to public inspection as provided in Georgia Law. Executive session minutes must be kept, but are confidential unless reviewed by a court in chambers. The executive session minutes will specify each issue discussed in executive session. If matters are discussed subject to the attorney-client privilege, the fact that an attorney-client discussion occurred and the subject shall be identified, but the substance of the discussion need not be recorded or identified, O.C.G.A. § 50-14-1(e)(2)(C). If a non-exempt topic is brought up in executive session, the mayor must immediately rule the discussion out of order. If the non-exempt discussion continues, the mayor must adjourn the meeting. The mayor and council shall execute and file with the official minutes of the meeting a notarized affidavit stating under oath that the subject matter of the closed portion was devoted to matters within the exceptions provided by law and identifying the specific relevant exception. Criminal penalty for violation of the Sunshine Laws is up to $1,000.00. The penalties will increase to $2,500.00 for subsequent violations in the same calendar year. 
(Former § 3-010; Ord. No. 2017-15, § 2, 8-15-2017) 
Sec. 3-34. - Personnel management system policies-Incorporation by reference. 
    The City of Social Circle Personnel Policy approved by the council on December 10, 2001, is hereby incorporated into this Code by reference in its entirety and made a part hereof as if it were set out in its entirety herein. Said policy replaces and supersedes any prior personnel policy or policies. All employees shall serve at the pleasure of a majority vote of the council. 
(Former § 3-014) 
Sec. 3-35. - City manager. 
(a)  Creation of city manager position. Pursuant to the powers granted in accordance with the constitution and the laws of Georgia, the position of city manager was created by an amendment to the Charter of the city to carry out the duties and responsibilities of an administrative nature. Except as otherwise stated in any employment contract, said city manager shall serve at the pleasure of a majority vote of the council. 
(b)  Minimum qualifications established. The city manager shall have the following minimum qualifications: 25 years of age; and Possess a bachelor's degree in government or business administration or related fields, provided that four years experience in the operation or management of a business or a portion thereof may be substituted for such bachelor's degree. 
(c)  Duties and responsibilities of city manager. The city manager shall have the following duties and responsibilities: To promote, facilitate and enforce this Code and all other city ordinances, resolutions, laws, regulations and rules; to coordinate matters and communications between the mayor and council and department heads of the city; to keep the mayor and council fully and regularly advised as to the financial condition and needs of the city and maintain accurate records reflecting the city's financial affairs; to assemble city department budget requests and present a compilation of same, along with an annual budget recommendation, to the mayor and council; to inspect, coordinate and represent the city in the performance of contracts and purchase of materials and supplies for the city within limitations and under such rules and regulations as may be imposed by the council, provided that the city manager is authorized to make purchases and contracts for the city in amounts not exceeding $2,600.00, except in emergencies up to $10,000.00, to be ratified by mayor and council at next council meeting thereafter; to prepare advertisements for bids and compile bids for contracts and purchases subject to any competitive bidding requirements; to maintain an inventory and maintenance schedule for city property; to coordinate, advise and recommend to the mayor and council in matters of personnel and compensation; to perform such other duties and responsibilities as may be delegated by the mayor and council; and to hold no other office or employment for remuneration while so engaged. 
(d)  City manager's salary. The minimum salary for the position of city manager shall be $30,000.00 with the actual salary being determined by the council based on the experience and qualifications of the person hired for such position. 
(e)  Council to have specific powers with regard to those of the city manager. The council reserves unto itself exclusive jurisdiction in the following: To levy taxes; to make appropriations; to fix the rates of all charges and fees; to authorize the incurring of indebtedness; to order work done where the cost is to be assessed against benefited property and to fix the basis for such assessment; to authorize contracts and purchases exceeding $2,600.00; to establish, alter, or abolish public roads, private ways, and bridges, according to law; to approve the insolvent lists for the city; to accept, for the city, the provisions of any optional statute where the statute permits its acceptance by the council of the city; to exercise all powers, duties and authorities imposed upon or vested in the council in respect to land subdivision, zoning and planning; to create and change the boundaries of special taxing districts authorized by law; to fix the bonds of city officers where the same are not fixed by statute; to enact any ordinances or other legislation; to determine the priority and authorization for capital improvement; to call elections for the voting of bonds or other indebtedness as provided by general law; to appoint members of all city boards and commissions; and to exercise all powers and authorities vested by law. 
(Former § 3-015) 
Sec. 3-36. - Liability insurance and contracts of indemnity for public officials. 
(a)  Council authorized to purchase insurance. The council is hereby authorized, in its discretion, to purchase policies of liability insurance or contracts of indemnity insuring or indemnifying the mayor and members of the council, and selected supervisors, administrators, employees or other elected or appointed city officers against personal liability for damages arising out of the performance of their duties or in any way connected therewith, whether based upon negligence, violation of contract rights or violation of civil, constitutional, common law or other statutory rights, whether state, federal or local. The amount of such insurance or indemnity and the persons chosen for coverage shall be at the discretion of the council. 
(b)  Council authorized to defend city officials in legal actions. 
(1)  Authorization stated. In lieu of obtaining the insurance or indemnity referred to in subsection (a) above or in addition thereto, the council may undertake to defend any actions brought or maintained against the mayor and/or members of the council and/or against supervisors, administrators, employees or other elected or appointed city officers, arising out of the performance of their duties or in any way connected. The council may expend state, federal and local funds for such purposes, including, but not limited to, attorney's fees, court costs, deposition costs, witness fees and compensation and all like costs, expenses and fees. The amount and type of such defense shall be at the sole discretion of the council. 
(2)  Exceptions. The council shall not furnish a defense to any person charged with a criminal offense involving theft, embezzlement or other like crime with respect to the property or money of or in which the city has an interest. Notwithstanding the foregoing sentence, the council may, in its discretion, reimburse any person charged with a criminal offense, involving theft, embezzlement or other like crime with respect to the property or money of or in which the city has an interest, if such person is found not guilty of such a crime or if the charges against such person are dismissed or nolle prossed. 
(Former § 3-017) 
Sec. 3-37. - Worker's compensation policy for volunteer firemen. 
    Insurance for firefighters. Volunteer firefighters working for and on behalf of the city shall be covered by and under the worker's compensation policy which covers the workers and employees of the city. 
(Former § 3-018) 
Sec. 3-38. - City employees' retirement system. 
    The ordinance approved August 9, 1983, establishing a retirement plan for the employees of the city, and setting forth the joint trust agreement and the contract for the administration of said plan by the city and the joint municipal employees benefit system, as amended, is hereby incorporated into this Code by this reference and is made a part hereof as if it were fully set out herein. 
(Former § 3-019) 
Sec. 3-39. - Employee benefits. 
    Pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 47-5-40, the city hereby subscribes to a plan of employee benefits consisting of group health, dental, live and accidental death insurance, offered through the Georgia Municipal Employees Benefit System. Said benefits shall be provided to eligible employees and dependents as defined by the insurance carrier under Policy Numbers 1016955, 1002814 and 1005551 (health) issued by Blue Cross Blue Shield of Georgia (or successor), and Policy Number 80338 (life & AD&D) issued by Greater Georgia Life Insurance Company (or successor) to the Georgia Municipal Employees Benefit System. The city agrees to include only qualified active employees of the City of Social Circle, on the original census of participants and on participant enrollment forms provided to GMEBS. The city subscribes to the PPO 90/80, PPO 80/60 and the HMO Plans. The city agrees to remit to GMEBS the monthly contributions necessary to keep in force the coverage provided. Such contributions shall be due and payable on the first day of each month and late fees or charges, as established by the GMEBS board of trustees, shall be collected on any contributions not received by the 15th day of each month. The city agrees to provide 30 days advance written notice to GMEBS of its intent not to continue participation in the employee benefit program. The plan year for the provision of employee benefits offered by the city to its employees shall begin on the first day of April, 2003, with the next renewal plan year beginning on the first day of April, 2004. The renewal date in succeeding years shall be established by GMEBS in accordance with its operating rules and regulations. 
(Former § 3-020) 
Secs. 3-40-3-75. - Reserved.
