ARTICLE IV. - BOARDS, COMMITTEES AND COMMISSIONS 

Sec. 3-111. - Standing committees. 
    The council is authorized to create standing committees as necessary. 
(Former § 3-011) 
Sec. 3-112. - Rules for the conduct of business. 
    Except as otherwise provided in this section, Roberts' Rules of Order Newly Revised shall govern the conduct of council meetings. Except as otherwise provided, Roberts' Rules of Order Newly Revised shall be a general guide for meetings. Prior to each meeting, each member should: Study the data, reports, and memoranda accompanying the agenda; review his/her own research and observations on the issues, as well as pertinent ordinances; review alternative solutions to each problem; look for the best solution, determine what positions others are likely to take, and consider where and how much he or she is willing to compromise; be ready to discuss his or her position. The performance of the presiding officer is the key to effective, businesslike meetings. He or she sees that meetings are orderly, conducted per the rules of procedure, and that they progress at an appropriate speed. At the same time, the presiding officer is responsible for ensuring members and citizens have ample opportunity to express their views. Members share with the presiding officer the responsibility for properly conducted meetings. This includes having respect for one another's views. It also requires willingness to compromise, where possible, for the good of the city. 
(1)  Call to order. The mayor, or in his absence the mayor pro tempore, shall take the chair at the hour appointed for meeting, and shall immediately call the council to order. 
(2)  Roll call. Before proceeding with the business of the council, the city clerk or a deputy may call the roll of the members. The names of those present shall be entered in the minutes. 
(3)  Quorum. A majority of all the members of the council shall constitute a quorum at any meeting of the council, and an affirmative vote of a majority shall permit the conduct of all business except that for which a greater vote has been mandated by this Code or general law. 
(4)  Order of business. The business of the council shall generally be taken up for consideration and disposition in the following order: call to order by presiding officer; roll call; approval of minutes of previous meetings; petitions and communications; reports of standing committees; reports of special committees; unfinished business; new business; adjournment. 
(5)  Reading of minutes. Unless a reading of the minutes of a council meeting is requested by a member of the council, such minutes may be approved without a reading if the clerk has previously furnished each member with a copy thereof. 
(6)  Reports by committees. Any business coming before the council may be referred to the proper committee for investigation and report. It shall be the duty of such committee to examine all matters referred to such committee, and make a report thereof at the next regular meeting of the council, or show good cause why no report is made. Such reports shall not be in writing unless so directed by the presiding officer. 
(7)  Manner of addressing council. No member, while the council is in session, shall speak on any subject unless recognized by the presiding officer. Every speaker shall address the chair, and no member shall interrupt anyone who is speaking, except to call him to order or for explanation. 
(8)  Limitations on addressing council. Any person not a member of the council, who desires to address the council shall first secure the permission of the presiding officer to do so, and then shall step up in front of the podium, give his name and address in an audible tone of voice for the record, and direct his remarks to the council as a body rather than to any particular member, limiting such remarks to three minutes, unless additional time is granted by the council. 
(9)  Code amendments, ordinances, resolutions, contracts and agreements. Unless otherwise provided in this Code, all Code amendments, ordinances, resolutions, contracts, and agreements of the city should generally be prepared, approved, introduced, and adopted in the following manner. 
a.  Preparation. All Code amendments and ordinances should be prepared by the city attorney, and should not be prepared for presentation to the council unless ordered by a majority vote of the council, or requested by the mayor, or prepared by the city attorney on his own initiative. 
b.  Administrative staff approval. All Code amendments, ordinances, resolutions, and contract documents should, before presentation to the council, have been approved as to form and legality by the city attorney or his authorized representative, and should have been examined and approved for administration by the mayor or his authorized representative where there are substantive matters of administration involved. 
c.  Introduction and adoption. 
1.  Ordinances, amendments, resolutions, and other matters or subjects requiring action by the council must be introduced and sponsored by a member of the council, except that the mayor or city attorney may present such to the council, and any council member may assume sponsorship thereof by moving that such be adopted. 
2.  An ordinance, amendment, resolution, or contract shall be deemed adopted or approved when it receives the affirmative vote of a majority of the council. For the purposes of tallying such vote, an abstention shall not be counted. The mayor shall cast the deciding vote in the event of a tie. 
(10)  Recording vote. The yeas and nays of the members present shall be recorded in the minutes on any questions taken. 
(11)  Questions of order. The presiding officer shall decide all questions of order, but any council member who is dissatisfied with the decision may appeal to the council in the manner provided by Roberts' Rules of Order New Revised for appealing from decisions of presiding officers. 
(12)  Executive session. The council may, at any time, upon call therefor by the presiding officer or upon motion duly carried by a council member, meet in executive session per Georgia law. Attendance at such session shall be limited to the mayor and members of the city council and such invitees as shall be invited by the majority vote of the council. 
(13)  Legal effect. Notwithstanding any other provisions of this section, a majority of a quorum at any meeting of the council may vary any provisions of this section. The legal effect of any action taken by the council at any meeting shall not be affected in any way by the failure of the council to follow any rules or provisions of this section unless the council minutes show such failure was brought to the attention of the council at said meeting prior to the taking of the subject action. 
(Former § 3-012; Ord. No. 2017-15, § 1, 8-15-2017) 
Sec. 3-113. - Legislative authority generally. 
    The council shall exercise the legislative functions of the city, and may pass any Code amendment, ordinance or resolution that it deems best for the city; provided that the same is not in conflict with the Charter of the city, the Constitution or laws of the State of Georgia, or the Constitution or laws of the United States of America. 
(Former § 3-013) 
Sec. 3-114. - Municipal planning commission. 
(a)  Purpose. 
(1)  General. The purpose of this section is to facilitate a coordinated and harmonious development of the city which will, in accordance with existing and future needs, best promote public health, safety, morals, order, convenience, prosperity and the general welfare, as well as efficiency and economy in the process of development. 
(2)  Planning commission maintained. There is hereby maintained the Social Circle Planning Commission, sometimes hereinafter referred to as the "planning commission." 
(b)  Organization and membership. 
(1)  Membership. The planning commission consists of seven members, all of whom shall be residents of the city be at least 18 years of age; be appointed by the council; and not be serving as mayor or on the council. 
(2)  Terms. The terms of the members are for four years, except that in the appointment of the first planning commission, one of the members was appointed for a term of two years, two of the members were appointed for a term of three years, and two of the members were appointed for a term of four years. In the event that the planning commission becomes inactive, disorganized, or suffers from a mass resignation of its members, the council shall appoint new members to terms as though it were establishing the first planning commission. 
(3)  Vacancies. Any vacancy in membership shall be appointed for the remainder of the term by council, which shall also have the authority to remove any member for any reason at any time, with or without cause. 
(4)  Compensation. All members of the planning commission shall serve without compensation, but may be reimbursed for actual expenses incurred in connection with their official duties. 
(5)  Organization. The planning commission shall elect a chair from among its members. The term shall be one year with eligibility for re-election. The planning commission shall also appoint a secretary, who may be an officer or employee of the city. 
(6)  Rules. The planning commission shall follow the requirements of the Georgia Zoning Procedures Law and be guided by Robert's Rules of Order, latest revision, and may, at its discretion, establish further reasonable rules of procedure, and shall determine its place and time of meeting. All meetings of the planning commission shall be open to the public. 
(7)  Employees and finances. The planning commission may appoint such employees and staff as it may deem necessary within the amounts appropriated for the purpose by the council. 
(c)  Powers and duties of the planning commission. The planning commission shall have all powers, duties and responsibilities provided for in this Code and by law. All actions of the planning commission shall be merely advisory and shall have no binding effect. 
(d)  Meetings of the planning commission. 
(1)  Regular meeting. All regular meetings of the planning commission shall be held at a time and place decided by a majority of the planning commission. 
(2)  Special meetings. The chair of the planning commission shall call special meetings thereof whenever in his opinion the public business may require it, or at the express oral or written request of any three members of the planning commission. Whenever a special meeting is called, the clerk of the planning commission shall notify each member of the planning commission and any other entity legally required to be notified, including without limitation the legal organ(s). 
(3)  Agenda. All reports, communications, requests, amendments, other documents, or other matter to be submitted to the planning commission shall at least 30 days prior to the planning commission meeting, be delivered to the city clerk, whereupon said clerk or the planning commission shall then prepare a list of such matters according to the order of business and furnish each member of the planning commission a meeting agenda as far in advance as time for preparation will permit. Any matter not on said agenda shall not be considered by the planning commission. 
(4)  The presiding officer-Election and duties. The presiding officer of the planning commission shall assume the chair upon his election by the members of the planning commission. The chair shall preserve strict order and decorum at all meetings. He shall state every question coming before the planning commission, announce the recommendation of the planning commission on all subjects, and decide all questions of order, subject, however, to an appeal to the planning commission, in which event a majority vote of the planning commission shall govern and conclusively determine such question of order. The chair shall not vote on any question except in the event of a tie vote or to create a constitutional majority. The members of the planning commission shall elect a vice-chair who shall serve as chair pro tem in the event of the absence of the chair. 
(5)  Call to order-Presiding officer. The chair or in his absence, the chair pro tem, shall take the chair at the hour appointed for the meeting, and shall then call the meeting to order. In the absence of the chair or chair pro tem, the city clerk shall call the planning commission to order, whereupon a temporary presiding officer shall be elected by the members of the planning commission present. Upon the arrival of the chair or chair pro tem, the temporary presiding officer shall immediately relinquish the chair. 
(6)  Roll call. Before proceeding with the business of the planning commission, the city clerk may call the roll of the members. The names of those present shall be entered in the minutes. 
(7)  Quorum. A majority of the members of the planning commission shall constitute a quorum at meeting. 
(8)  Order of business. Promptly at the beginning of each meeting, the members of the planning commission shall take their regular stations, and the business of the planning commission shall generally be taken up using the following as a guide as to order: roll call; approval of minutes of previous meeting; new business; unfinished business; miscellaneous; and adjournment. 
(9)  Reading of the minutes. Unless a reading of the minutes is requested by the chair or a member of the planning commission, such minutes may be approved without reading if they have been provided to the members before the meeting. 
(10)  Presiding officer may debate. The presiding officer may debate from the chair, subject only to such limitations of debate as are by these rules imposed on all members and shall not be deprived of any of the rights and privileges of a planning commission member by reason of his action as the presiding officer except as otherwise specified in this section. 
(11)  Obtaining the floor. Every member desiring to speak shall address the chair, and upon recognition by the presiding officer, shall confine himself to the question under debate, avoiding all personalities and indecorous language. 
(12)  Interruptions. A member, once recognized, shall not be interrupted when speaking unless it is to call him to order, or as herein otherwise provided. If a member, while speaking, is called to order, he shall cease speaking until the question of order is determined and, if in order, he shall be permitted to proceed. 
(13)  Privilege of closing debate. The individual initiating a request shall have the privilege of closing the debate. 
(e)  Addressing the planning commission. 
(1)  General. Any person planning to address the planning commission shall first secure the permission of the presiding officer. 
(2)  Addressing the commission after motion made. After a motion is made by the planning commission, no person shall address the planning commission. 
(3)  Manner of addressing planning commission; time limit. Each person addressing the planning commission shall stand, shall give his name and address in an audible tone of voice, and unless further time is granted by the planning commission, shall limit his address to five minutes. All remarks shall be addressed to the planning commission as a body and not to any member thereof. No person, other than the planning commission and the person having the floor, shall be permitted to enter into any discussion, either directly or through a member of the planning commission, without the permission of the presiding officer. No question shall be asked except through the presiding officer. 
(4)  Silence constitutes affirmative vote. Unless a member of the planning commission states that he is not voting, his silence shall be recorded as an affirmative vote. 
(e)  Decorum. 
(1)  By planning commission members. While the planning commission is in session, the members must preserve order and decorum, and a member shall neither delay or interrupt the proceedings, disturb any member while speaking, nor refuse to obey the orders of the planning commission or its presiding officer. 
(2)  By persons. Any person making personal, impertinent or slanderous remarks or who shall become boisterous while addressing the planning commission shall be barred from further audience before the planning commission, unless permission is granted by a majority vote of the planning commission. 
(3)  Enforcement of decorum. The Walton County Sheriff, or such member or members of the sheriff's department as he may designate, or a representative of the city department of public safety, shall be sergeant-at-arms of the planning commission meetings and shall carry out all orders and instructions given by the presiding officer for the purpose of maintaining order and decorum at the planning commission meeting. Upon instructions of the presiding officer, it shall be the duty of the sergeant-at-arms to place any person who violates the order and decorum of the meeting under arrest. 
(g)  Miscellaneous. 
(1)  Special committees. All special committees shall be appointed by a majority of the planning commission. 
(2)  Adjournment. A motion to adjourn shall always be in order and decided without debate. 
(3)  Legal effect. The legal effect of any action taken by the planning commission at any meeting shall not be affected in any way by the unintentional failure of the planning commission to follow any rules or provisions of this section, if the Georgia Zoning Procedures Law was not violated, unless the planning commission minutes show such failure was brought to the attention of the planning commission at said meeting prior to the taking of the subject action. 
(Former § 3-016) 
Sec. 3-115. - Recreation planning and advisory commission. 
(a)  Purpose. 
(1)  To advise the county commission on the broad range of recreation and leisure time needs of the residents of the city. 
(2)  The commission shall provide advice, counsel, and assistance to the Walton County Parks and Recreation Department with regard to recreation needs of city residents, conduct fund raisers for the Social Circle Booster Club, provide oversight on Booster Club finances and concession operations, administer and account for Booster Club funds, and identify potential recreational activities and programs for Booster Club financial support. 
(b)  Membership. The commission shall consist of nine members, each of whom shall be residents of the city or within the school district of the Social Circle City Schools. Members shall be appointed by the mayor and council and shall serve without pay for a term of four years. 
(c)  Annual reports. The commission shall submit to the mayor and council an annual report of fees and revenues from fund raisers, concessions, gifts and bequests, both real and personal property or donations. Such revenue and other receipts shall be subject to an annual audit by the city. 
(d)  Officers; powers. Upon appointment the commission shall meet and organize by electing one of their members chairman and such other officers as may be necessary. The commission shall have power to adopt bylaws, rules and regulations to carry out the purposes of the commission. 
(Former § 3-021) 
Sec. 3-116. - Main Street commission. 
(a)  Purpose. This article is created by the mayor and city council of the City of Social Circle, Georgia (hereinafter referred to as "mayor and council") to provide an organizational structure for the joint participation of private and public interests in the economic development of the business district of the city. The commission established by the ordinance from which this section derives shall be exclusively empowered with overseeing the Main Street Program, as that term is described in the rules, regulations and guidelines of the state department of community affairs. The Main Street commission is further charged with raising and overseeing the use of contributed private capital through deductible charitable contributions to the city given for the dedicated purpose of paying for Main Street Program initiatives within the Main Street district. 
(b)  Creation, appointment and compensation. A commission of the city is hereby created by official action of the mayor and council. The commission shall be the exclusive board of directors of the Main Street Program whose title shall be "Social Circle Main Street Commission" (hereinafter referred to as the "Main Street commission"). The registered office of the Main Street commission shall be city hall in the City of Social Circle with the address of P.O. Box 310, Social Circle, Georgia. The operational office of the Main Street commission shall be the Social Circle Visitors Center. This entity is a subsidiary commission of the city and all contributions to this organization shall be deemed gifts to the City of Social Circle, Georgia and deductible under the current statues and regulations of the Internal Revenue Code. All financial accounts of the Main Street commission shall be deemed public funds, subject to the annual review of the auditors of the city and shall be maintained under the standards of fund accounting for cities required under the Official Code of Georgia for cities. 
(1)  Membership, qualifications and terms of office. 
a.  The Main Street commission shall consist of 15 members, each of whom shall serve a maximum term of three years. Twelve members of the commission shall be appointed by the mayor and council. One commissioner shall serve as the representative of the historical preservation commission ("HPC") and be appointed by the HPC. One commissioner shall serve as a representative of the city's downtown development authority ("DDA") and shall be appointed by the DDA. One commissioner shall serve as a representative of the city planning commission and shall be appointed by the planning commission. The mayor of the city and the city manager shall serve as the city representatives to the commission with the authority to participate in discussions, but not vote or be counted toward a quorum. The commissioner serving as the planning commission representative is the only member that shall not have the power to vote. To ensure continuity of the Main Street commission, the initial terms are staggered as provided on Exhibit "B" attached to Ord. No. 2017-3 and incorporated herein by reference. In future appointments, the commission positions shall be referred to by the seat number affixed to the attached list. The commissioners shall have the following standards for appointment: 
b.  At least four members shall be residents of the city. 
c.  At least two members shall be business owners in the Main Street district. 
d.  At least one member shall own property in the Main Street district. 
(2)  Appointment, vacancies and removal. 
a.  When appointing Main Street commission members, the city clerk shall take action as may reasonably be required to inform city residents, business owners in the Main Street district and property owners in the Main Street district that an opening exists on the Main Street commission, including the publication of a notice in the principal newspaper of general circulation in the city. The city clerk shall accept applications from interested individuals. Acting as a committee of the whole, the mayor and council, chaired by the mayor, shall review the applications, interview applicants, and recommend a short list of potential candidates. Confirmation shall be by a majority vote of the mayor and city council. 
b.  If a member is unable to complete a term of office, then an appointment to fill the unexpired term shall be made in the same manner as making an initial appointment. A member so appointed shall serve the remainder of the unexpired term of his or her predecessor. 
c.  If a member is absent from three consecutive regular monthly meetings of the commission, without a Main Street commission approved excuse, the offending commissioner may be subject to being removed and replaced by official action of the mayor and council after a written request is made by the main street commission seeking removal of the absent commissioner. Members may participate via teleconference, with the approval of Main Street, if they are unable to attend a meeting. Industry appointees may send a substitute if they are unable to attend a Main Street meeting. 
(3)  Members shall serve without compensation, but may be reimbursed for reasonable expenses as approved by the mayor and council. 
(c)  Powers and duties. The Main Street commission shall: 
(1)  Make an annual report to the mayor and council on the economic condition of the Main Street district. 
(2)  Make recommendations to the mayor and council on economic and development issues concerning the city's business district. 
(3)  Search for local, state, federal, and private grants and other funds for the economic development of the Main Street district. 
(4)  Create and maintain a plan for the Main Street district incorporating the Georgia Main Street Association's four-point approach of organization, promotion, economic restructuring, and design as set forth in the Annual Standards for Accreditation, a copy of which is attached to Ord. No. 2017-3 as Exhibit "C". 
(5)  Faithfully fulfill all the conditions and terms of the Main Street memorandum of understanding as amended in the future and as set forth initially in the document attached to Ord. No. 2017-3 as Exhibit "D". 
(6)  To budget, invest, and when dedicated funds are held by others for the Main Street program, to oversee the budgeting and investment of such funds contributed to the Main Street Program including, but not limited to, the funds held by Social Circle Main. 
(7)  To generally carry on, conduct, promote, operate and undertake any transaction or operation necessary to carry out the powers and duties outlined herein. 
(8)  To make every effort to fulfill and to continue to fulfill in the future all the Annual Standards for Accreditation set forth in the documents attached hereto as the Georgia Main Street 2016 Annual Standards for Accreditation as amended in the future. 
(9)  To make all records available and assist the city auditor in the financial review of all contributions, public expenditures, investments, revenues and expenditures of the Main Street commission. 
(10)  To work with the state department of community affairs in administering the Main Street program consistent with and pursuant to its other standards for the Main Street program. 
(11)  To conduct all meetings subject to the notices and terms of the Georgia Open Meetings Law and to keep and make available all records, minutes and other written items, including communications, for review and copying pursuant to the Georgia Open Records Law. 
(d)  Assistance by the city. The city, through the action of the mayor and council, shall provide technical and clerical assistance as the Main Street commission by maintaining a permanent and complete record of the activities of the Main Street commission in the records of the clerk of the city. 
(e)  Bylaws, officers and quorum. The Main Street commission shall have the authority to supplement this section by adopting rules and procedures, such as bylaws, for the transaction of its business. The Main Street commission shall have the prerogative to adopt reasonable rules and bylaws without amendment to this section or the vote of the mayor and council. The Main Street commission shall provide for the time and place of regular meetings and a method for the calling of special meetings. The Main Street commission shall meet at least monthly. Meetings and notices of meetings shall be conducted in accordance with the Georgia Open Meeting and Records Act, O.C.G.A. § 50-18-70. 
(1)  A quorum shall consist of a majority of the current appointed and serving members. For purposes of establishing a quorum, commissioners appointed by the HPC, DDA and planning commission shall be counted. A vote of a majority of the members attending the meeting is needed to take action. 
(2)  The Main Street commission shall elect a chair and such other officers as it deems appropriate from among its members. Officers shall serve one-year terms and shall be eligible for reelection. The Main Street commission shall elect its initial officers at the first meeting following their appointment and thereafter in February of each year. 
(Ord. No. 2017-3, §§ 1-5, 2-21-2017) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 20174-3, §§ 1-5, adopted February 21, 2017, did not specify manner of inclusion; hence, inclusion as section 3-116 is at the discretion of the editor. 
Secs. 3-117-3-130. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - PROCUREMENT AND CONTRACTING[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2017-21, §§ 1-8, adopted September 19, 2017, did not specify manner of inclusion; hence, inclusion as article V, sections 3-131-3-138 is at the discretion of the editor. 

Sec. 3-131. - Purpose. 
    The purpose of this article is to provide for the fair and equitable treatment of all persons involved in public purchasing and contracting with the city, to give city staff objective rules to follow in expending the resources of the city, to maximize the purchasing value of public funds in procurement, and to provide safeguards for maintaining procurement and contracting systems of quality and integrity. 
(Ord. No. 2017-21, § 1, 9-19-2017) 
Sec. 3-132. - Eligibility. 
    Every new contractor contracting with the city, and any subcontractor that contractor hires, must register with the federal work authorization program, or E-Verify, in order to be eligible to perform work for the city. Contracts between the city and contractors, and between the contractors and their subcontractors, must be accompanied by sworn affidavits attesting to affiant's registration with E-Verify and compliance with E-Verify's citizenship requirements. 
(Ord. No. 2017-21, § 2, 9-19-2017) 
Sec. 3-133. - Utilization of facilities agreements. 
(a)  The city manager or any designee of the city manager is authorized to approve and execute facility use agreements that involve the request of a single party to use a city facility (park, town green, etc.) for a one-time event. 
(b)  The city manager is authorized to approve and execute programming agreements that involve the request of an organization to use a city facility (park, town green, etc.) for a series of connected events that span an entire season (e.g. a soccer organization's use of the park for the fall season). 
(Ord. No. 2017-21, § 3, 9-19-2017) 
Sec. 3-134. - Sole source procurement. 
    A contract may be awarded without competition when the city manager determines, in writing, after conducting a good faith review of available sources, that there is only one source for the required supply, service or constructed item. The city manager shall conduct negotiations, as appropriate, as to price, delivery and other terms. A record of sole source procurements shall be maintained as a public record and shall list each contractor's name, the amount and type of each contract, and a listing of the item(s) procured under each contract. 
(Ord. No. 2017-21, § 4, 9-19-2017) 
Sec. 3-135. - Emergency procurements. 
    Notwithstanding any other provisions of this article, the city manager may make or authorize others to make emergency procurements of supplies, services, or construction items when there exists a threat to public health, welfare, or safety; provided that such emergency procurements shall be made with such competition as is practicable under the circumstances. A written determination of the basis for the emergency and for the selection of the particular contractor shall be included in the contract file. This provision shall not abrogate the city's requirements as specified in the Official Code of Georgia. 
(Ord. No. 2017-21, § 5, 9-19-2017) 
Sec. 3-136. - Financial policy city manager authority. 
    The city manager is hereby authorized to make all expenditures and purchases for regular budgeted items approve by the city council with the express limitation that a capital expenditure that has not been specifically identified in the budget must be identified by specific action of the mayor and city council by resolution prior to purchase. 
    The city manager is also authorized to spend and purchase items that are non-pre-budgeted goods and services up to $25,000.00 without mayor and council approval provided there is contingency funds available from the budget or other approved non-budget revenue sources including reserves. 
    Notwithstanding the terms of this paragraph, the city manager is required to follow all other bidding requirements of this article. With the approval of the city manager, department heads are authorized to purchase goods and services up to $500.00. 
(Ord. No. 2017-21, § 6, 9-19-2017) 
Sec. 3-137. - Bids and proposals. 
    The two primary procurement methods for the city shall be competitive sealed bidding and competitive sealed proposals. All procurements shall be made via one of these two methods unless the procurement falls under the sole source procurement, or emergency procurement sections above, which serve as exceptions to these two primary methods. The terms and conditions of the purchasing section of the financial policies of the current budget are incorporated into this article as Schedule 1 attached to Ord. No. 2017-21 and incorporated herein by reference. 
(1)  Competitive sealed bidding. An invitation for bids shall be issued and shall include specifications, and all contractual terms and conditions applicable to the procurement. Adequate public notice of the invitation for bids shall be given a reasonable time, not less than 15 calendar days prior to the date set forth therein for the opening of bids. The public notice shall state the place, date, and time of bid opening. Bids shall be opened publicly in the presence of one or more witnesses at the time and place designated in the invitation for bids. The amount of each bid and such other relevant information as the city manager deems appropriate shall be recorded. The record and each bid shall be open to public inspection. 
Bids shall be unconditionally accepted without alteration or correction, except as authorized in this article. Bids shall be evaluated based on the requirements set forth in the invitation for bids-no other criteria may be used in bid evaluation. Such requirements may include criteria to determine acceptability such as inspection, testing, quality, workmanship, delivery, and suitability for a particular purpose. 
Correction or withdrawal of inadvertently erroneous bids before or after bid opening, or cancellation of awards or contracts based on such bid mistakes, may be permitted where appropriate. Mistakes discovered before bid opening may be modified or withdrawn by written notice received in the office designated in the invitation for bids prior to the time set for bid opening. After bid opening, no changes in bids shall be permitted unless the bidder can show by clear and convincing evidence that a mistake of a nonjudgmental character was made, the nature of the mistake, and the bid price actually intended. In lieu of bid correction, a low bidder alleging a material mistake of fact may be permitted to withdraw its bid if: (1) the mistake is clearly evident on the face of the bid document but the intended correct bid is not similarly evident, or (2) the bidder submits evidence which clearly and convincingly demonstrates that a mistake was made. All decisions to permit correction or withdrawal of bids shall be supported by written determination by a city official. 
The contract shall be awarded with reasonable promptness by appropriate written notice to the lowest responsible and responsive bidder whose bid meets the requirements and criteria set forth in the invitation for bids. In the event the low responsive and responsible bid for a given project exceeds available funds as certified by the appropriate fiscal officer, the city manager is authorized, when time or economic considerations preclude re-solicitation of work of a reduced scope, to negotiate an adjustment of the bid price with the low responsive and responsible bidder, in order to bring the bid within the amount of available funds. 
(2)  Competitive sealed proposals. When the city manager, or other relevant department head, determines that the use of competitive sealed bidding is either not practicable or not advantageous to the city, a contract may be entered into by use of the competitive sealed proposals method. 
As provided in a request for proposals, discussions may be conducted with responsible offerors who submit proposals determined to be reasonably susceptible of being selected for award for the purpose of clarification to assure full understanding of, and conformance to, the solicitation requirements. 
Award shall be made to the responsible offeror whose proposal is determined in writing to be the most advantageous to the city, taking into consideration price and the evaluation factors set forth in the request for proposals. No factors other than those set forth in the request for proposals may be used in the evaluation. 
(Ord. No. 2017-21, § 7, 9-19-2017) 
Sec. 3-138. - State requirements. 
    The city hereby incorporates herein by reference the notice, bonding, and other procurement requirements of the state as specified in O.C.G.A. tit. 13, ch. 10 and tit. 36, ch. 91. Any project or contract governed by these statutes shall follow and satisfy the requirements therein, notwithstanding any conflicting provision of this article. 
(Ord. No. 2017-21, § 8, 9-19-2017) 
Chapter 4 - TAXATION 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 4-1-4-25. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - SPECIFIC TAXES LEVIED 

Sec. 4-26. - Ad valorem tax. 
(a)  Rate of levy. The council may set and levy to meet the ordinary current expenses of the city an annual ad valorem tax upon all real and personal property within the city. 
(b)  Assessment and fair market value. All property subject to municipal ad valorem taxation shall be assessed at 40 percent of its fair market value. The basis for fair market value shall be 100 percent of the fair market value determined for the property for city ad valorem tax purposes. 
(c)  Appeal of assessment. Any taxpayer may appeal from an assessment by the board of tax assessors to the board of equalization as to matters of taxability, uniformity of assessment, and value, and if still dissatisfied may appeal to the Superior Court of Walton County from a decision of the county board of equalization. All such appeals shall be made in the manner provided by law. 
(d)  When taxes are due and payable. Ad valorem taxes shall become due on the 20th day of October each year and shall be deemed delinquent if not paid within 60 days after said due date. Tax bills showing the assessed valuations, amount of taxes due, tax due dates, and information as to delinquency dates and penalties shall be sent to all taxpayers at least 30 days prior to the due date, but failure to send a tax bill shall not invalidate any tax. Delinquent taxes shall bear interest at 12 percent per annum from due date. 
(e)  Failure to pay tax. The city shall issue an execution against any person who has defaulted in the payment of any ad valorem tax. The execution thus issued shall be a lien on all the property of such person, both real and personal, and shall be placed in the hands of the city officer responsible for collection by levy and sale. 
(f)  Against whom charged. Taxes are to be charged against the owner of the property if known, or against the specific property itself if the owner is not known. Life tenants and those who enjoy the use of the property are chargeable with the tax. 
(g)  Exempted property. The property exempt from ad valorem taxation under law shall be exempt from city ad valorem taxation. 
(Former § 4-001) 
Sec. 4-27. - Malt beverage excise tax levied under Georgia law. 
(a)  Rate of levy. There is hereby set and levied on the sale of malt beverages within the city an excise tax in the sum of $0.05 per 12 ounces and in similar proportion of bottles, cans, and containers of various sizes. 
(b)  Against whom levied. The malt beverage excise tax is levied against and shall be paid by each licensed wholesale dealer in malt beverages in the municipality. 
(c)  Due date and required report. The malt beverage excise tax shall be paid on or before the tenth day of the month following the calendar month in which the beverages are sold or disposed of, and payment shall be accompanied by a report itemizing the exact quantities of malt beverages sold for the preceding calendar month by size and type of container. Any tax remaining unpaid at the expiration of 15 days from the due date shall be delinquent. 
(d)  Enforcement. The tax levied by this section may be enforced by execution in the same manner as other taxes of the city and failure of payment of such tax shall be grounds for revocation or refusal of the business license of the delinquent taxpayer. 
(Former § 4-002) 
Sec. 4-28. - Alcoholic beverage excise tax levied under Georgia law. 
(a)  Rate of levy. There is hereby set and levied on the sale of alcoholic beverages, excluding fortified wine, an excise tax in the sum of $0.80 per wine gallon and in similar proportion for bottled containers of various sizes. 
(b)  Against whom levied. The alcoholic beverage excise tax shall be paid by each licensed wholesale dealer in alcoholic beverages in the municipality. 
(c)  Due date and required report. The alcoholic beverage excise tax shall be paid on or before the tenth day of the month following the calendar month in which the beverages are sold or disposed of, and payment shall be accompanied by a report itemizing the exact quantities of alcoholic beverages sold for the preceding calendar month by size of container. 
(d)  Enforcement. The tax levied by this section may be enforced by execution in the same manner as other taxes of the city and, in addition, any failure of payment of such tax shall be grounds for revocation or refusal of the business license of the delinquent taxpayer. 
(Former § 4-003) 
Sec. 4-29. - Insurers license fees assessed under Georgia law. 
(a)  General. The purpose of this section is to impose license fees on insurers conducting business within the city; to impose a gross premiums tax on insurers operating within the state; and other purposes. 
(b)  Insurers license fees. 
(1)  Definition. For the purposes of this section, the term insurer means a company which is authorized to transact business in any of the classes of insurance designated in O.C.G.A. § 33-3-5. 
(2)  Fee levied. There is hereby levied an annual license fee upon each insurer doing business within the city in the amount of $40.00. For each separate business location in excess of one not covered in subsection (b)(3), which is operating on behalf of such insurers within the city, there is hereby levied a license fee in the amount of $100.00 per year. 
(3)  License fees for insurers insuring certain risks at additional business locations. For each separate business location, not otherwise subject to a license fee hereunder, operated and maintained by a business organization which is engaged in the business of lending money or transacting sales involving term financing and in connection with such loans or sales offers, solicits or takes application through a licensed agent of an insurer for insurance, said insurer shall pay an additional license fee of $14.00 per location. 
(4)  Insurance agency license fees; independent insurance agencies, brokers, etc. not otherwise licensed. There is hereby levied an annual license fee upon independent agencies and brokers for each separate business location from which an insurance business is conducted and which is not subject to the company license fee imposed by subsection (b)(2) hereof in the amount of $100.00 for each such location within the city. 
(c)  Gross premiums tax. 
(1)  Gross premiums tax imposed on life insurers. There is hereby levied an annual tax based solely upon gross direct premiums upon each insurer doing business within the state writing life, accident and sickness insurance in an amount equal to one percent of the gross direct premiums received during the preceding calendar year, in accordance with O.C.G.A. § 33-8-8.1. "Gross direct premiums" as used in this paragraph shall mean gross direct premiums as used in O.C.G.A. § 33-8-4. The premium tax levied by this paragraph is in addition to the license fees imposed by this section. 
(2)  Gross premiums tax, all other insurers. There is hereby levied an annual tax based solely upon gross direct premiums upon each insurer doing business within the state, other than an insurer transacting business in the class of insurance designated in Subsection 1 of O.C.G.A. § 33-3-5, in an amount equal to two and one-half percent of the gross direct premiums received during the preceding calendar year, in accordance with O.C.G.A. § 33-8-8.2. "Gross direct premiums" as used in this subsection (c)(2) shall mean gross direct premiums as used in O.C.G.A. § 33-8-4. The premium tax levied by this subsection is in addition to the license fees imposed by this section. 
(d)  Administrative provisions. 
(1)  Due date for license fees. License fees imposed in subsection (b) shall be due March 1 each year. 
(2)  Clerk to notify insurance commissioner. The clerk forwarded a duly certified copy of this section 4-29 to the insurance commissioner of the state within 45 days of its original enactment. 
(3)  Effective date. This section became effective on January 1, 1995, having formerly been known as a separate ordinance pertaining to insurer's fees and originally adopted by the council at its regularly called meeting of January 9, 1995. 
(Former § 4-004) 
Sec. 4-30. - Public utility franchise taxes. 
(a)  Electric utility franchises. The authority, right, permission and consent are hereby granted to each electric supplier within the meaning of O.C.G.A. §§ 46-3-1 et seq., ("company") their successors, lessees and assigns, subject to the terms and conditions set forth hereinafter, for a period of 35 years, to occupy and use the streets, alleys and public places of the city as from time to time each such company may deem proper or necessary for the overhead or underground construction, maintenance, operation and extension of poles, towers, lines, wires, cables, conduits, insulators, transformers, appliances, equipment, connections and other apparatus for the business and purpose of transmitting, conveying, conducting, using, supplying and distributing electricity for public or private use, and to re-enter upon such streets, alleys and public places from time to time as each such company may deem proper or necessary to perform these functions, and to cut and trim trees and shrubbery when and where necessary, in the judgment of each such company, to ensure safe and efficient service. The foregoing notwithstanding, the definition of company shall not include any entity with whom the city has a written franchise agreement. 
    The use by any company of the streets, alleys, public places and other property of the city for the operation of any of its electric distribution systems, and the grant of requisite street franchise rights, is expressly conditioned upon payment by such company of franchise fees pursuant to this section, and continued use and occupancy of such city property for said purpose without payment of such franchise fees shall be unlawful, and the city shall be entitled to enforce compliance with this section by appropriate proceeding at law or in equity. 
    Provided further, that the rights, permission and consents herein contained are made for the following considerations and upon the following terms and conditions, to wit: 
(1)  Each company shall pay to the city on or before the 20th day of each month, a sum of money equal to five percent of the gross sales of electric energy to all of such company's customers served within the corporate limits of the City during the preceding month. The five percent rate herein specified shall be reviewed at the first council meeting in January of each year and may be changed by majority vote of the council to such other levels as are allowed or mandated by law. Such a rate change shall take effect on February 1st of the year in which such rate change is approved. The city should provide the company with written notice of any such rate change. 
(2)  The percentage of gross revenues prescribed to be collected shall be in lieu of all other license and business or occupation taxes, but shall not at any time be considered to interfere with, or in any way prevent the collection of, ad valorem taxes upon the property of the company in the same manner as all other property, real and personal, in the city is taxed. 
(3)  In the event the city shall grant to any other electric utility the right to use and occupy its streets for like purposes, such use and occupancy shall be upon the same terms and conditions as those herein contained, including the payment provisions. 
(4)  Each company shall fully protect, indemnify and hold harmless (including payment of the city's reasonable attorney's fees and court costs) the city from all damages to person or property caused by the construction, maintenance, operation or extension of poles, wires or other apparatus, by such company, or conditions of streets, alleys or public places resulting therefrom, for which the city would otherwise be liable. Provided however, the city shall not be indemnified for damages arising from the willful misconduct of the city itself. 
(5)  Each company shall, in constructing, maintaining, operating and extending its poles, wires and other apparatus, submit and be subject to all reasonable exercises of the police power of the city. 
(6)  The grant of rights, permission and consents by the city in this section to any company is specifically conditioned upon the payment of all sums due the city from such company in accordance with the rate, conditions and payment dates set forth in subsection (1) above, and failure by any company to timely pay said franchise fees shall constitute a forfeiture of all rights granted to such company by this section. From and after the original implementation of this public utility franchise tax, each company's continued use and occupancy of the streets, alleys and public places of the city for the aforesaid purposes shall evidence that company's acceptance of the franchise granted hereby and shall render that company liable for payment of all fees required by subsection (1). In the event of forfeiture for failure to comply with such requirements, the forfeiting company shall nevertheless remain liable for all sums accrued until such time as the company removes all of its property from the city following such forfeiture. 
(7)  The city manager shall be responsible for the administration and enforcement of this section, and shall have the power to prepare and provide for the collection of the fees herein required. 
(8)  All work done by any company upon the streets, alleys and public places of the city shall be done under the supervision of the city, and any sidewalk, street pavement or other city improvement which may be displaced, obstructed or destroyed by reason of such work shall be properly replaced, reopened or repaired by such company to the satisfaction of the mayor and council of the city. 
(b)  Franchise tax on telephone and telegraph companies. The authority, right, permission and consent are hereby granted to each telephone and/or telecommunication company ( "company") providing telephone and/or telecommunication service within the city their successors, lessees and assigns, subject to the terms and conditions set forth hereinafter for a period of 35 years, to occupy and use the streets, alleys and public places of the city as the company may deem proper or necessary for the overhead or underground construction, maintenance, operation and extension of poles, towers, lines, wires, cables, conduits, appliances, equipment, connections and other apparatus for the business and purpose of transmitting, conveying, conducting, using, supplying and distributing telephone communications service for public or private use, and to re-enter upon such streets, alleys and public places as such company may deem proper or necessary to perform these functions, and to cut and trim trees and shrubbery when and where necessary, in the judgment of such company, to ensure safe and efficient service. 
    The use by the company of the streets, alleys, public places and other property of the city for the operation of any of its telephone communication systems, and the grant of requisite street franchise rights, is expressly conditioned upon payment by company of franchise fees pursuant to this section, and continued use and occupancy of such city property for said purpose without payment of such franchise fees shall be unlawful, and the city shall be entitled to enforce compliance with this section by appropriate proceeding at law or in equity. 
    The rights, permission and consents herein contained are made for the following considerations and upon the following terms and conditions, to wit: 
(1)  The company shall pay to the city on or before the 20th day of each month, a sum of money equal to three percent of the gross recurring local service revenues received from all of such company's customers served within the city during the preceding month. For the purposes of this section, the phrase "gross recurring local service revenues" shall include, but not be limited to, revenues from the following services, all as defined in company's tariff in effect on the date of passage hereof as applicable to the city: 
Basic Local Exchange Service, Directory Assistance Service, Operator Assisted Local Calls, ESSX Service, Touch Tone Calling Service, Interphone Services, Special Billing Services, Arrangement for Night, Sunday and Holiday Services, Custom Calling Services, Touch Tone Service, RingMaster Service, TicketTaker Service, Simplified Message Desk Interface, Message Waiting Indication-Audible, Surrogate Client Number, Telecommunications Service Priority (TSP) System, Electronic White Pages (EWP), Multiline Hunt Queuing, Hot Line Service, Warn Line Service, Automatic Number Identification, Custom Service Area (CSA), Answer Supervision, Caller Detail Information, Data Transport Service, Integration Plus Management Services (IPMS), Frame Relay Service, Switched Multi Megabit Data Service (SMDS), Native Mode LAN Interconnection (NMLI) Service. 
The three percent rate herein specified shall be reviewed at the first council meeting in January of each year and may be changed by majority vote of the council to such other levels as are allowed or mandated by law. Such a rate change shall take effect on February 1st of the year in which such rate change is approved. The city should provide the company with written notice of any such rate change. 
(2)  The percentage of gross recurring local service revenues prescribed to be collected shall be in lieu of all other license and business or occupation taxes, but shall not at any time be considered to interfere with, or in any way prevent the collection of ad valorem taxes upon the property of the company in the same manner as all other property, real and personal, in the city is taxed. 
(3)  In the event the city shall grant to any other telephone and/or telecommunication company the right to use and occupy its streets for like purposes, such use and occupancy shall be upon the same terms and conditions as those herein contained, including the payment provisions hereof. 
(4)  The company shall fully protect, indemnify and hold harmless (including payment of the city's reasonable attorney's fees and court costs) the city from all damages to person or property caused by the construction, maintenance, operation or extension of poles, wires or other apparatus, by such company, or conditions of streets, alleys or public places resulting therefrom, for which the city would otherwise be liable. The city shall not be indemnified for damages arising from the willful misconduct of the city itself. 
(5)  The company shall, in constructing, maintaining, operating and extending its poles, wires and other apparatus, submit and be subject to all reasonable exercises of the police power of the city. 
(6)  The grant of rights, permission and consents contained in this section are specifically conditioned upon the payment of all sums due the city from the company in accordance with the rate, conditions and payment dates set forth in subsection (1) above, and failure by the company to timely pay said franchise fees shall constitute a forfeiture of all rights granted to such company by this section. The company's continued use and occupancy of the streets, alleys and public places of the city for the aforesaid purposes shall evidence the company's acceptance of the franchise granted hereby and shall render the company liable for payment of all fees required by subsection (1) hereof. In the event of forfeiture for failure to comply with such requirements, the forfeiting company shall nevertheless remain liable for all sums accrued until such time as the company has removed all of its property from the city after such forfeiture. 
(7)  The city manager shall be responsible for the administration and enforcement of this section, and shall have the power to prepare and provide for the collection of the fees herein required. 
(8)  All work done by the company upon the streets, alleys and public places of the city shall be done under the supervision of the city, and any sidewalk, street pavement or other city improvement which may be displaced, obstructed or destroyed by reason of such work shall be properly replaced, reopened or repaired by such company to the satisfaction of the council. 
(9)  Due compensation for telephone companies with end user retail customers within the city. 
a.  The city hereby requires due compensation of three percent of actual recurring local service revenues, as defined in O.C.G.A. § 46-5-1(b)(8) and (9); provided, however, that any company which pays in excess of three percent of actual recurring local service revenues pursuant to an existing franchise agreement shall continue to pay in accordance with the agreement until the expiration of the franchise agreement or December 31, 2012, whichever occurs first, and any company which pays in excess of three percent of actual recurring local service revenues in accordance with an occupational license tax arrangement shall continue to pay in accordance with such payment schedule until December 31, 2012. 
b.  Regarding any telephone company that does not have retail, end user customers located within the city's municipal boundaries, the payment by such company to a municipal authority in accordance with the rates set by regulations promulgated by the department of transportation for the use of its rights-of-way shall be considered the payment of due compensation. 
(10)  Authorized designee. The manager, shall, on behalf of the city, exercise day-to-day administrative duties necessary to fulfill the regulatory authority of the city under O.C.G.A. §§ 46-5-1, et seq. and shall perform the following duties: 
a.  Review application information submitted by a telephone company to the city and, if an application is incomplete, notify the telegraph or telephone company within 15 business days of the receipt of such application, identifying in such notice all application deficiencies. 
b.  Report the receipt of a completed application to the council within 60 days of the receipt of such completed application. 
c.  Review payments of due compensation submitted by the company to ensure compliance with the provisions of the amended law and this section. 
d.  Provide a coordination function between a telephone company and all city departments on any matter relating to the amended law and this section. 
e.  Arrange and evaluate, no more than once a year, a comprehensive review of the records of a company which is reasonably related to the calculation and payment of due compensation. 
f.  Provide to all telegraph and telephone companies located in its rights-of-way written notice of annexations and changes in municipal corporate boundaries. 
(c)  Franchise fee for state issued cable or video franchise. 
(1)  Franchise fee for state issued cable or video franchise. The city requires a franchise fee of five percent of gross revenues generated within the city for any cable or video state franchise issued in its corporate boundaries by the state. 
(2)  Authorized designee. The city hereby authorizes the city clerk, upon receipt of notice to the city of its right to designate a franchise fee for an applicant for or holder of an existing state franchise, to provide written notice to the secretary of state of each applicant for or holder of a state franchise within a service area that is wholly or partially located within the city limits of the five percent franchise fee rate applicable to such applicant or holder of a state franchise.

Sec. 4-31. - Local option sales tax. 
    The council is authorized to levy a local option sales tax as necessary. 
(Former § 4-006) 
Sec. 4-32. - Local option income tax. 
    The council is authorized to levy a local option income tax as necessary. 
(Former § 4-007) 
Sec. 4-33. - Municipal tax sales. 
(a)  Time, place, and manner of sale. The time, place, and manner of the sale of property, both real and personal, for taxes due the city shall be the same as that provided by law for sheriffs' sales for state and county taxes. 
(b)  Purchase by city. The clerk shall attend all sales of property for taxes due the city and in the event no person bids for the property for the tax amount due thereon, the clerk shall place a bid for such property for the city and, if the bid is accepted, take custody of the deed for the city. 
(c)  Redemption of property sold for taxes. Any person whose property is sold in obedience to an execution issued for the collection of city taxes shall have such rights of redemption of said property as are set forth in O.C.G.A. §§ 48-4-1 et seq. 
(Former § 4-008) 
Sec. 4-34. - Financial institutions business license tax. 
(a)  Per O.C.G.A. § 48-6-93, there is hereby levied for the year 1996, and each year thereafter, an annual business license tax upon depository financial institution a business license tax at the rate of 0.25 percent of the gross receipts of said institutions. "Gross receipts" shall mean gross receipts as defined in O.C.G.A. § 48-6-93. Notwithstanding any other provisions of this section, the minimum amount of business license tax due from any depository financial institution pursuant to this section shall be $1,000.00 per year. 
(b)  Each depository financial institution within the city shall file a return of its gross receipts with the city on March 1st of the year following the year in which such gross receipts were measured. Said returns shall be in the manner and in the form prescribed by the commissioner of the department of banking and shall be based upon the allocation method set forth in O.C.G.A. § 48-6-93(d). The tax levied pursuant to this section shall be assessed and collected based upon the information provided in said return. The due date for taxes levied by this section shall be April 1st of each year. 
(Former § 4-009) 
Sec. 4-35. - Occupation tax and business regulations. 
(a)  Occupation tax required for business dealings in Social Circle. For the year 2004 and thereafter, each person engaged in any business, trade, profession, or occupation in the incorporated area of Social Circle, Georgia, including an out-of-state business with no location in Georgia exerting substantial efforts within the state pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 48-13-7, shall pay an occupation tax for said business, trade, profession, or occupation. Registration of payment of such tax shall be displayed conspicuously in the taxpayer's place of business. If the taxpayer has no permanent business location in Social Circle, such business tax registration shall be shown to the city clerk or to any officer of the Walton County Sheriff's Department or a representative of the city department of public safety, upon request. Payment of occupation tax shall not be a precondition to the operation of any business or practice of any profession in the city, said tax being for raising revenue. 
(b)  Construction of terms; definitions. 
    Administrative fee means the approximate reasonable cost of handling and processing the occupation tax. 
    Employee means an individual whose work is performed under the direction and supervision of the employer and whose employer withholds FICA, federal income tax, or state income tax from such individual's compensation or whose employer issues to such individual for purposes of documenting compensation a form I.R.S. W-2 but not a form I.R.S. 1099. 
    Location or office shall include any structure or vehicle where a business, profession, or occupation is conducted, but shall not include a temporary or construction work site which serves a single customer or project or a vehicle used for sales or delivery by a business or practitioner of a profession. 
    Occupation tax means a tax levied on persons, partnerships, corporations, or other entities engaging in an occupation, profession, or business, for revenue raising purposes. 
    Regulatory fees means payments, whether designated as license fees, permit fees, or by another name, which are required by Social Circle as an exercise of its police power and as a part of or an aid to regulation of an occupation, profession, or business. The amount of a regulatory fee shall approximate the reasonable cost of the actual regulatory activity performed by Social Circle. A regulatory fee may not include an administrative fee. 
    Person includes sole proprietors, corporations, partnerships, or any other form of business organization, but excludes nonprofit organizations and state, federal or local governments or instrumentalities thereof. 
    Practitioner of profession or occupation is one who by law requires state licensure regulating such profession or occupation. 
    Practitioners of professions and occupations shall not include a practitioner who is an employee of a business, if the business pays an occupation tax. 
(c)  Administrative and regulatory fees. 
(1)  A non-prorated, non-refundable administrative fee of $100.00 shall be required on all business and occupation tax accounts for the initial start-up, renewal, or reopening of those accounts. 
(2)  Regulatory fees may only be imposed in compliance with O.C.G.A. § 48-13-9. 
(d)  Occupation tax levied; restrictions. 
(1)  An occupation tax shall be levied upon those businesses and practitioners of professions and occupations with one or more locations or offices in the incorporated area of Social Circle, based upon the following criteria: 
a.  The number of employees of the business or practitioner who are employed in the business or practitioner's dominant line of business in Social Circle. An employee who works for the same business or practitioner in more than one county or municipal corporation shall be counted as being employed in Social Circle if Social Circle is the local government entity in which the employee works for the longest period of time within the calendar year. 
b.  The number of employees of a business or practitioner includes all full-time positions and all full-time position equivalents as follows: An employee who works 40 hours or more weekly shall be considered a full-time position. The average weekly hours of employees who work less than 40 hours weekly shall be added and such sum shall be divided by 40 to determine the number of full-time position equivalents. 
(2)  Occupation tax schedule. The tax rate determined by number of employees for each business, trade, profession, or occupation is as follows and will be developed and updated from time to time by the mayor and council of the city: All businesses-$4.50 per employee. 
(3)  Exemptions. 
a.  No business or practitioner shall be required to pay more than one occupation tax for each of its locations. 
b.  No occupation tax shall be required from those real estate brokers, real estate agents, or real estate companies whose offices are located outside the jurisdiction and who sell property inside the jurisdiction. 
c.  No occupation tax shall be required from the following: 
1.  Any disabled veteran of any war or armed conflict in which any branch of the armed forces of the United States engaged, whether under United States command or otherwise; 
2.  Any blind person; or 
3.  Any veteran of peace-time service in the United States armed forces who has a physical disability incurred during the period of such service. 
d.  No occupation tax shall be levied on any state or local authority, nonprofit organization, or vendor operating under a contract with a tax-exempt agricultural fair, as that term is defined in O.C.G.A. § 2-2-8. 
(e)  Occupation tax on businesses with no location in Georgia. 
(1)  An occupation tax shall be levied on those businesses and practitioners of professions with no location or office in the state of Georgia if the business's largest dollar volume of business in Georgia is in the city and the business or practitioner: has one or more employees or agents who exert substantial efforts within Social Circle for the purpose of soliciting business or serving customers or clients; or owns personal or real property which generates income and which is located in Social Circle. 
(2)  The rate of taxation for businesses taxed under this section is the same as in subsection (d) above. For the purposes of computing the occupation tax on a business described in subsection (1) of this section, the number of employees of the business employed in Social Circle shall be computed based on the number of employees or agents who exert substantial efforts within the incorporated area of Social Circle for the purpose of soliciting business or serving customers or clients. 
(f)  Reduction for businesses commenced after July 1. When any person commences business on or after July 1 in any year, the occupation tax for the remaining portion of the year shall be 50 percent of the tax that would have been imposed for the entire year. A practitioner of a profession or occupation who elects as his or her occupation tax the amount described in subsection (h)(2) below shall receive no reduction in such amount. 
(g)  More than one place or line of business. Where a business is operated at more than one fixed location in Social Circle, each location shall be considered a separate business for the purpose of occupation tax. Such business is required to obtain the necessary registration and pay an occupation tax for each location. 
(h)  Professionals classified in O.C.G.A. § 48-13-9(c). Practitioners of professions as described in O.C.G.A. § 48-13-9(c)(1-18) shall elect as their occupation tax one of the following: 
(1)  The occupation tax based on number of employees as set forth in subsection (d) above. 
(2)  A fee of $100.00 per practitioner who is licensed to provide the service, such tax to be paid at the practitioner's office or location; provided, however, that a practitioner paying according to this paragraph shall not be required to provide information to the local government relating to the gross receipts of the business or practitioner. The per-practitioner fee applies to each person in the business who qualifies as a practitioner under the state's regulatory guidelines and framework. 
(3)  This election is to be made on an annual basis and must be done by January 1 each year. If no election is timely made, the occupation tax shall be imposed as set forth in subsection (d) above. 
(i)  Practitioners exclusively practicing for a government. Any practitioner whose office is maintained by and who is employed in practice exclusively by the US, Georgia, a city or county of Georgia or instrumentalities of the US, shall not be required to obtain a license or pay an occupation tax for that practice. 
(j)  Purpose and scope of tax. The occupation tax levied herein is for revenue, not for regulatory purposes, nor is the payment of the tax a condition precedent to the practice of any such profession, trade, or calling. The occupation tax only applies to those businesses and occupations covered by O.C.G.A. §§ 48-13-5-48-13-28. All other businesses and occupations are taxed by the local government pursuant to the pertinent general and/or local law and ordinance. This section does not apply to state or local authorities or non-profit organizations. 
(k)  Return required. The owner, proprietor, manager, or secretary of any business subject to the occupation tax for the upcoming calendar year shall, on or before December 31 of the preceding year, file with the city clerk, on a form furnished by the city clerk, a signed return setting forth each location at which business is conducted in Social Circle, the line or lines of business that the business conducts at each such location, the business tax identification number, the employees' social security numbers, and the number of employees of the business or practitioner, computed according to the above guidelines, for each line of business at each location. Any omission of federal tax identification number or social security number shall be reported to the state revenue commissioner. Where a business or practitioner has commenced operation after January 1, the return shall be filed no later than 30 days after commencement of such business. 
(l)  Failure to file return. Any person required to file an occupation tax return who fails to file by the date required shall be subject to a civil fine by a court of competent jurisdiction. The fine shall not exceed $200.00 and may be enforced by the contempt power of the court. 
(m)  Inspections of books and records; penalty for under-reporting. Social Circle, through its officers, agents, employees, or representatives, may inspect the books of the business for which the returns are made for the sole purpose of determining the number of employees of the business, and upon demand relevant books and records shall be made immediately available for such inspection. Failure to comply shall be punishable by a fine by a court of competent jurisdiction for the enforcement of city ordinances. The fine shall not exceed $200.00 and may be enforced by the contempt power of the court. Adequate records relevant to the number of employees of the business shall be kept in Social Circle for examination. If, after examination of the books or records, it is determined that a deficiency occurs as a result of under-reporting, the amount of the deficiency shall be treated as delinquent and shall be subject to the penalties and procedures for delinquent occupation tax amounts provided in subsections (o) through (r) below. This section shall not be construed as requiring any professional or business to divulge information protected under any privilege recognized by the laws of Georgia, including, but not limited to attorney-client privilege. 
(n)  Returns confidential. Except in judicial proceedings or other proceedings necessary to collect the occupation tax hereby levied, or as otherwise required by law, it shall be unlawful for any person to divulge or make known in any manner gross receipts set forth or disclosed in any occupation tax return required hereunder. Information revealing gross receipts shall be confidential and open only to the officials, employees, agents, or clerks of Social Circle using said returns for the purpose of this occupation tax levy and the collection of the tax. Independent auditors or bookkeepers retained by the city shall be classed as "employees". Nothing herein shall be construed to prohibit the publication by officials of statistics, so classified as to prevent the identification of gross receipts, or the inspection of information revealing gross receipts by duly qualified employees of the tax departments of the State of Georgia, the United States, and other local governments. 
(o)  When tax due; tax registration. 
(1)  Each occupation tax for 2004 and succeeding calendar years thereafter shall be payable January 31 of each year and shall, if not paid by May 1 of each year, be subject to penalties for delinquency as prescribed in subsection (p) below. If any person commences business for the first time in Social Circle after January 1, the tax shall be due and payable 30 days after the date of the commencement of the business, and delinquency shall occur upon nonpayment after 90 days from the due date. 
(2)  The tax registration herein provided for shall be issued by the city clerk upon receipt of all amounts due for the occupation tax. Each such registration shall be for the calendar year the registration was obtained unless otherwise specifically provided. 
(p)  Penalty for delinquency; interest on delinquent tax; other remedies. 
(1)  Should any occupation tax imposed by this chapter be delinquent, the person liable for the tax shall pay a penalty of ten percent of the tax due. 
(2)  Any occupation tax which becomes delinquent shall bear interest from the date of delinquency on the unpaid amount at 18 percent per annum. 
(3)  The city clerk may collect delinquent occupation taxes in the same manner as provided by law for tax executions. 
(4)  A court of competent jurisdiction for the enforcement of ordinances of Social Circle may impose a civil fine for failure to pay the occupation tax (or regulatory fee), not to exceed $500.00, which may be enforced by the contempt power of the court. Per City of Atlanta v. Barnes, this subsection (p)(4) shall not apply to attorneys. 
(q)  Registration to be revoked for failure to pay tax, file returns, permit inspection of books. Upon the failure of any business to timely pay occupation tax or to timely or truthfully make returns, or upon failure to amend a return to set forth the truth, or upon failure to permit inspection of its books as above provided, any business tax registration granted under this chapter shall be automatically revoked. No new business tax registration shall be granted for a business for which any part of the occupation tax is unpaid, or to a person who has failed to submit adequate records as requested by Social Circle in accordance with subsection (m). However, nothing in this section shall be construed as prohibiting the operation of any business or practice of any profession in Social Circle, regardless of status of the occupation tax registration for such business or professional. 
(r)  Lien for delinquent occupation tax. 
(1)  The city clerk and/or designated tax collector, upon any tax or installment becoming delinquent and remaining unpaid, shall issue execution for the amount of said tax and the penalty against the person liable for said tax, which said execution shall bear interest at the rate of 18 percent per annum from the date when such tax or installment becomes delinquent.
