The lien shall cover the property in Social Circle of the person liable for said tax, all as provided by the laws of the city and Georgia. The lien of said occupation tax shall become fixed on and date from the time when such tax or any installment thereof becomes delinquent. 
(2)  The execution shall be levied by the city clerk upon the property of the defendant in Social Circle, and sufficient property shall be advertised and sold to pay the amount of said execution, with interest and costs. All proceedings in relation thereto shall be as provided by the laws of Social Circle and Georgia, including without limitation O.C.G.A. tit. 48, chs. 3, 4 and 5. 
(s)  Reserved. 
(t)  Social circle officials; subpoena and arrest powers. Social Circle's duly designated officers and inspectors have full subpoena powers regarding enforcement hereof. 
(u)  Businesses licensed by state. Each person subject to the occupation tax which is also licensed by the state shall post the state license conspicuously in its place of business. This requirement is not a precondition to the operation of any business or practice of any profession in the city. 
(v)  Businesses not covered by this chapter. The following businesses are not subject to occupation tax, registration fees or regulatory fees provided for herein, but may be assessed other types of taxes pursuant to other general laws of Georgia or by local law: 
(1)  Those businesses regulated by the Georgia Public Service Commission. 
(2)  Those electrical service businesses organized under O.C.G.A. tit. 46, ch. 3. 
(3)  Any farm operation for the production from or on the land of agricultural products, but not including agribusiness. 
(4)  Cooperative marketing associations governed by O.C.G.A. § 2-10-105. 
(5)  Insurance companies governed by O.C.G.A. §§ 33-8-8, et seq. 
(6)  Motor common carriers governed by O.C.G.A. § 46-7-15. 
(7)  Those businesses governed by O.C.G.A. § 48-5-355. (Businesses that purchase carload lots of guano, meats, meal, flour, bran, cottonseed, or cottonseed meal and hulls.) 
(8)  Agricultural products and livestock raised in Georgia governed by O.C.G.A. § 48-5-356. 
(9)  Depository financial institutions governed by O.C.G.A. § 48-6-93. 
(10)  Facilities operated by a charitable trust governed by O.C.G.A. § 48-13-55. 
(w)  Occupation tax inapplicable where prohibited by law or provided for pursuant to other existing law. An occupation tax shall not apply where such levy is prohibited or exempted by the laws of Georgia or of the United States. 
(x)  Amendment, repeal of provision. This amendment shall be subject to amendment or repeal, in whole or part, and no such amendment or repeal shall be construed to deny the right of the city to assess and collect any of the taxes or other charges prescribed. Said amendment may increase or lower the amounts and tax rates of any occupation and may change the classification thereof. 
(y)  Applications of provisions to prior section 4-010. This amendment does not repeal or affect the force of any part of any ordinance heretofore passed where taxes levied under such Prior Code section 4-010 have not been paid in full. Any parts of ordinances or code sections heretofore and hereinafter passed which provided for the issuing and enforcing of execution for any tax or assessment required by such, or that imposed fines or penalties for the nonpayment of such tax, or for failure to pay regulatory fees provided for therein, or failure to comply with any other provisions hereof, shall continue and remain in force until such tax, regulatory fee, or assessment shall be fully paid. 
(z)  Enforcement of provisions. It is hereby made the duty of the city clerk to see that the provisions hereof relating to occupation taxes are observed. 
(aa)  Full force and effect until changed by governing body. This amendment shall remain in full force and effect until changed by amendment adopted by the mayor and council. All provisions hereto relating to any form of tax herein levied shall remain in full force and effect until such taxes have been paid in full. 
(bb)  Requirement of public hearing before tax increase. The council shall conduct at least one public hearing before increasing the rate of occupation tax set forth herein. 
(cc)  Public hearing in years of increasing revenue. In any year when revenue from occupation taxes is greater than revenue from occupation taxes for the preceding year, the mayor and council shall hold one or more public hearings as part of the process of determining how to use the additional revenue. 
(dd)  Exemption or reduction in occupation tax. The mayor and council may by subsequent amendment or resolution provide for an exemption or reduction in occupation tax to one or more types of businesses or practitioners of occupations or professions as part of a plan for economic development or attracting or encouraging selected types of businesses or practitioners of selected occupations or professions. Such exemptions or reductions in occupation tax shall not be arbitrary or capricious, and the reasons shall be set forth in the minutes of the mayor and council. 
(ee)  Conflicts between specific and general provisions. Where there is an apparent conflict in this amendment between specific and general provisions, the specific shall control. 
(ff)  Effective date. This amendment took effect on December 31, 2003. 
(Former § 4-010) 
Sec. 4-36. - Pawnbrokers and dealers in second-hand merchandise. 
(a)  Definitions. 
    Dealer in second-hand merchandise means any private entity which holds itself or its place of business out as a buyer, seller or trader of used or distressed merchandise. 
    Licensee is deemed to include all persons, agents or employees operating under said license. 
    Pawnbroker means any private entity with which property is deposited as security for the payment of a debt. 
    Specific entities included in this section. Specifically included in the above defined categories shall be: 
(1)  Any dealer, salesperson, or buyer of gold, silver, jewelry, coins and/or other precious metals, whether said sales, trades or purchases are retail, wholesale or by any form of pawn; 
(2)  Any dealer, salesperson, or buyer of semi-precious metals to include, but not being limited to, iron, steel, copper, aluminum, brass, and wet-cell batteries, commonly referred to as "junk"; 
(3)  Any dealer, salesperson, or buyer of used parts designed for use with automobiles, trucks or other vehicles; and 
(4)  Any private entity providing selling space, singularly or in multiple units, indoors or outdoors, for the purpose of what is commonly referred to or known as a flea market operation shall, for the purpose of this section, be considered a primary license applicant, and as such, shall be held responsible for the provisions of this section concerning transactions made by lessees of said selling space in the same manner as if said lessees were agents or employees. 
    Specific entities excluded in this section. Specifically excluded from the above defined categories shall be: 
(1)  Wholesalers, buyers and sellers, who sell, trade or deal only with retail mercantile establishments; 
(2)  Private sales, commonly referred to as garage sales, when held on the seller's residential property for a period not exceeding 24 hours; 
(3)  Organizational sales by non-profit groups holding fund raisers with all funds going directly to the sponsoring organization; and 
(4)  State licensed used car or truck dealers or repair garages as to the dealing in used vehicle parts. 
(b)  Licensing requirements. 
(1)  Application to be submitted. Any private entity desiring to do business as a pawnbroker or dealer in second-hand merchandise shall make application and notice to the city, at least 72 hours prior to the opening or advertising of the business operation. 
(2)  Application requirements. All notices/applications shall include the following: 1) full name and address of the person, company or corporation; and 2) submission of standard fingerprint cards of principals, agents and employees to the clerk within 24 hours of the application of agents or employees operating in the city. The cost of processing the fingerprinting shall be deposited. 
(3)  Fee required. At the time of submission of an application to operate as a pawnbroker or dealer in second-hand merchandise the applicant shall pay the annual license fee as specified in section 4-35 of this Code). 
(c)  Traveling or itinerant dealers. 
(1)  Provisions applicable to traveling dealers. All of the provisions of this section shall also apply to any traveling or itinerant dealer, his agent, or employees intending to establish a temporary business of a type addressed by this section. 
(2)  Exceptions and specifications. The license fee for an itinerant dealer shall be $25.00, and the license issued shall be valid for a period not to exceed seven calendar days. No itinerant dealer, his agent, or employee may apply for or receive a temporary license more than once during any calendar quarter. Any dealer, agent or employee not previously furnishing fingerprint cards as required by this section must do so within 24 hours of any subsequent application. 
(d)  General regulations. 
(1)  Business hours. No licensee shall open his place of business or conduct any business between 10:00 p.m. and 8:00 a.m.; provided, however, that such a place of business may remain open until 10:30 p.m. on Fridays and until 11:00 p.m. on Saturdays. 
(2)  Premises to be open to police. It shall be the duty of every licensee to admit to his premises the sheriff or any deputy or police officer or a representative of the city department of public safety, or agent of the city who may desire at any time to search for articles missing or stolen, or to make any inspection authorized by this section, without a search warrant. 
(e)  Records requirements. 
(1)  Forms to be used, distributed. Each licensee shall have an adequate supply of pre-numbered three-part forms which, in addition to any records deemed necessary by the licensee, must be made, maintained and distributed by the licensee daily. Specific retention and distribution of forms shall occur as follows: 
a.  The original shall be maintained by the licensee as a permanent record to be kept for a minimum of ten years; 
b.  The second copy of the form shall be kept in the Walton County Sheriff's files or the city department of public safety's files, for comparison with items reported stolen; and 
c.  The third copy will be forwarded by the Walton County Sheriff's Department or the city department of public safety, to the communications record center for G.C.I.C. comparison as computer time availability permits. 
(2)  Licensees to provide accurate descriptions of merchandise. The licensees shall enter an accurate description of all property pledged or sold to them. The description shall include as a minimum: The name of the maker of the article; any identifying mark or number; and a statement of the kind and color of material of which it is made. 
(3)  Licensees to provide accurate descriptions of seller or depositor. The licensees shall also enter positive identifying information of the person who sold or deposited the article, including name, address, date of birth, race, estimated weight and height, and signature. Licensees may take such information from a valid driver's license or other such official form bearing a photograph of the person when completing the form. 
(4)  Entries to be timely made. The entries required in subsection (e)(1) above shall be made at the time of the transaction. Other records maintained by the licensee shall be kept current to reflect every transaction and they shall be made as soon as possible following each transaction. 
(5)  False entries. It is unlawful for any licensee to make any false entry in any records required by this section. 
(6)  Transactions with minors prohibited. It shall be unlawful for any licensee to receive any article in pawn, or purchase any article for resale, from any person under 18 years of age. 
(f)  Holding of goods. 
(1)  Goods to be held for ten days. Any licensee operating under this section who takes any kind of personal property, on pawn or buys such, taking full title thereto, shall hold the property so taken in pawn or sale for at least ten days before disposing of the goods by sale, transfer, shipment, or otherwise. 
(2)  Exception. This aforesaid provision cannot be waived by contract, but it does not apply nor is it intended to cover purchasers from reputable wholesale supply houses and manufacturers, or goods of a perishable nature. 
(3)  Surrender of stolen property. If is reasonably suspected that any item bought, sold or traded to, or received in any manner by licensees, is the subject of any crime, the licensees shall, upon demand of the sheriff or his designee, or a representative of the department of public safety, surrender the same to the Walton County Sheriff's Department or the city department of public safety. 
(g)  General operating requirements for junk dealers and junk yards. 
(1)  Application of this subsection. The general operating requirements as specified herein shall apply to all junk dealers. 
(2)  Appearance of junk yards. The following appearance requirements shall apply to all junk dealers in Social Circle: 
a.  No weeds in a junk yard shall be permitted to attain a height of more than eight inches; 
b.  Junk shall be stored in piles not exceeding ten feet in height, and shall be arranged to permit easy access to all such junk for firefighting purposes; 
c.  The area on the premises where junk is kept shall be enclosed, except for entrances and exits, with a solid, vertical wall or fence of a minimum height of eight feet measured from ground level; 
d.  The fence or wall shall not contain any poster or advertising of any kind except one sign of the licensee not exceeding nine square feet in size; and 
e.  Entrances and exits shall not be wider or more numerous than reasonably necessary for conduct of the business. 
(3)  Sanitary conditions to be maintained. The following sanitary conditions shall be maintained at all junk dealers: 
a.  No junk yard shall be allowed to become a nuisance; nor shall any junk yard be operated in such manner as to become injurious to the health, safety, or welfare of the community or of any residents close by; 
b.  No water shall be allowed to stand in any place in such manner as to afford a breeding place for mosquitoes; 
c.  No garbage or other waste liable to give off a foul odor or attract vermin shall be kept on the premises; nor shall any refuse of any kind be kept on the premises, unless such refuse is saleable junk; 
d.  No junk shall be allowed become scattered or blown off the business premises; 
e.  No combustible material of any kind not necessary or beneficial to the business shall be kept on the premises; nor shall the premises be allowed to become a fire hazard; 
f.  Fuel and oil shall be removed from any scrapped engines or vehicles on the premise; 
g.  No junk or other material shall be burned on the premises in any incinerator not meeting the requirements of the city building codes; and no junk or other material shall be burned on the premises in the open; and 
h.  No noisy processing of junk or other noisy activity shall be carried on in connection with the licensed business on any Sunday holiday, or on any day between the hours of 6:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m. 
(4)  Administrative requirements. The licensee shall permit inspection of the premises by law enforcement at any reasonable time. 
(h)  Penalties. Any licensee or agent or employee thereof violating this section shall be subject to punishment as a misdemeanor by a fine not to exceed $1,000.00 or by confinement in the Walton County Jail or other detention facility for a maximum term not to exceed six calendar months, or both, at the discretion of the presiding judge. 
(Former § 4-011) 
Sec. 4-37. - Freeport exemption. 
    Pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 48-5-48.2 there shall be exempt from taxation 80 percent of the value of the tangible personal properties set forth in this section for the year beginning January 1, 2005, and all subsequent years unless changed by referendum. Terms used below are defined by O.C.G.A. § 48-5-48.2(a). 
(1)  Inventory of goods in the process of manufacture or production which shall include all partly finished goods and raw materials held for direct use or consumption in the ordinary course of the taxpayer's manufacturing or production business in the state. The exemption provided for in this section shall apply only to tangible personal property which is substantially modified, altered or changed in the ordinary course of the taxpayer's manufacturing, processing or production operations in this state. 
(2)  Inventory of finished goods manufactured or produced within the state in the ordinary course of the taxpayer's manufacturing or production business when held by the original manufacturer or producer of such finished goods. The exemption provided for in the subsection shall be for a period not exceeding 12 months from the date such property is produced or manufactured. 
(3)  Inventory of finished goods which, on January 1, are stored in a warehouse or dock, whether public or private, and which are destined for shipment to a final destination outside this state and inventory of finished goods which are shipped into this state from outside this state and stored for transshipment to a final destination outside this state. The exemption provided for in this subsection shall be for a period not exceeding 12 months from the date such property is stored in this state. Such period shall be determined based on application of a first-in, first-out method of accounting for the inventory. The official books and records of the warehouse or dock where such property is being stored shall contain a full, true and accurate inventory of all such property, including the date of the receipt of the property, the date of the withdrawal of the property, the point of origin of the property, and the point of final destination of the same, if known. The official books and records of any such warehouse or dock, whether public or private, pertaining to any such property for which a Freeport exemption has been claimed, shall be at all times open to the inspection of all taxing authorities of this state and of any political subdivision of this state. 
(Former § 4-012) 
Sec. 4-38. - Hotel-motel excise tax. 
(a)  Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Due date means from the 20th day after the close of the monthly period for which tax is to be computed. 
    Guestroom means a room occupied or intended, arranged or designed for occupancy, by one or more occupants for the purpose of living quarters or residential use. 
    Hotel means any structure or any portion of a structure, including but not limited to any bed and breakfast house, lodging-house, rooming-house, dormitory, Turkish bath, bachelor hotel, studio hotel, motel, motor hotel, auto court, inn, public club or private club, containing guestrooms and which is occupied or is intended or designed for occupancy, by guests, whether rent is paid in money, goods, labor or otherwise. Such term does not include any jail, hospital, asylum, sanitarium, orphanage, prison, detention center or other building in which human beings are housed and detained under legal restraint. 
    Monthly period means the calendar month of any year. 
    Occupancy means use or possession or the right to the use or possession of any room or apartment in a hotel, or the right to the use or possession of the furnishings or to the services and accommodations accompanying the use and possession of the room. 
    Occupant means any person who, for a consideration, uses, possesses or has the right to use or possess any room in a hotel under any lease, concession, permit, right of access, license or use or other agreement or otherwise. 
    Operator means any person operating a hotel in this city, including but not limited to the owner or proprietor of such premises, lessee, sub-lessee, lender in possession, licensee or any other person otherwise operating such hotel. 
    Permanent resident means any occupant as of a given date who has or shall have occupied or has or shall have right of occupancy of any guestroom in a hotel for at least 30 consecutive days. 
    Person means an individual, firm, partnership, joint venture, association, social club, fraternal organization, joint stock company, corporation, nonprofit corporation or cooperative nonprofit membership, estate, trust, business trust, receiver, trustee, syndicate, or any other group or combination acting as a unit, the plural as well as the singular number, excepting the United States of America, the state, and any political subdivision of either upon which the city is without power to impose the tax provided in this article. 
    Rent means the consideration received for occupancy valued in money, whether received in money or otherwise, including all receipts, cash, credits, and property or services of any kind or nature, and also the amount for which credit is allowed by the operator to the occupant, without any deduction whatsoever. 
    Return means any return filed or required to be filed as provided in this article. 
(b)  Rate of levy. There is set and levied on each occupant of a guestroom of any hotel located within the corporate limits of this city a tax in the amount of five percent of rent for such occupancy. This tax is imposed per O.C.G.A. § 48-13-51(a)(1)(A)(3). 
(c)  Collection of tax by operator. It shall be the duty of every operator of a hotel located within the city to collect the tax on occupants imposed herein. 
(d)  Exemption. Notwithstanding any other provision of this article, no tax shall be imposed upon a permanent resident, or upon rooms, lodgings or accommodations for a period of one or more days for use by state or local government officials or employees traveling on official business. 
(e)  Registration of operator. Every person engaging in or about to engage in business as an operator of a hotel in this city shall immediately register the business with the city clerk, on a form provided by the city clerk for such purpose. The required registration shall set forth the name which the operator transacts business or intends to transact business, the location of his place of business, and such other information as would facilitate the collection of the tax by the city clerk. The registration shall be signed by the owner if a natural person, by a member or partner in case of ownership by association or partnership, or by an officer in the case of ownership by a corporation. A separate registration shall be required for each place of business of an operator. 
(f)  Certificate of taxing authority. Upon registration of an operator, the city clerk shall issue to such operator without charge a certificate of authority to collect the tax on occupants. Each certificate shall state the name and location of the business to which it relates. 
(g)  Due date and required report. All taxes levied by this article shall be due and payable to the city clerk monthly on or before the 20th day succeeding each respective month in which such taxes are collected, and payment shall be accompanied by a return for the preceding monthly period showing the gross rent, rent from permanent residents, taxable rent, and amount of tax collected or otherwise due for the period, and such other information as may be required by the city clerk. 
(h)  Collection fee allowed operators. Operators collecting the tax levied under this article shall be allowed a percentage of the tax due and accounted for and shall be reimbursed in the form of a deduction in submitting, reporting and payment of the amount due if the amount is not delinquent at the time of payment. The rate of the deduction shall be the same rate authorized for deductions from state tax under the "Georgia Retailers" and "Consumer's Sales and Use Tax Act". 
(i)  Determination if no return made; unsatisfactory return. 
(1)  Estimate authorized. If any hotel operator fails to file a return as required under the provisions of this article, the city clerk shall make an estimate of the amount of gross rentals of such operator for the period for which the operator failed to file the return and such estimate shall be based upon any information which is or may come into the possession of the city clerk. One or more deficiency determinations may be made of the amount due for one or more monthly periods. 
(2)  Notice of determination. The city clerk or his designated representative shall give to the hotel operator written notice of his determination as provided in this section. The notice may be served personally or by mail; if by mail, such service shall be addressed to the operator at his address as it appears in the records of the city clerk. Service by mail is complete when mailed by certified mail. 
(3)  Interest on amount found due. The amount of the determination made under this section shall bear interest at the rate of three-fourths of one percent per month, or fraction of a month, from the 20th day of the month following the monthly period for which the amount or any portion of the amount should have been returned until the date of payment. 
(4)  Time within which notice of deficiency determination to be mailed. Except in the case of failure to make a return, every notice of a deficiency determination shall be mailed within three years after the 20th day of the month following the monthly period in which the amount is proposed to be determined, or within three years after the return is filed, whichever period should expire last. 
(5)  Unsatisfactory return. The same rules shall apply if a return is made but is determined to be unsatisfactory by the city clerk. 
(j)  Required records. Each hotel operator collecting a tax under the provisions of this article shall keep all records, receipts, invoices and other pertinent papers for a period of at least three years, setting forth dates of occupancy and such other information as the city clerk may require. 
(k)  Administration and enforcement. 
(1)  Authority of the clerk. The city clerk shall administer and enforce the provisions of this article for the collection of the tax imposed by this article. 
(2)  Records required from operators; form. Every operator renting guestrooms in this city to a person shall keep such records, receipts, invoices and other pertinent papers in such form as the mayor and council may require. 
(3)  Examination of authorized records; audits. The city clerk or any person authorized in writing by the city clerk may examine the books, papers, records, financial reports equipment and other facilities of any operator renting guestrooms to a person and any operator liable for the tax, in order to verify the accuracy of any return made, or if no return is made by the operator, to ascertain and determine the amount required to be paid. 
(4)  Authority to require reports; contents. In administration of the provisions of this article, the city clerk may require the filing of reports by any persons or class of persons having in such persons' possession or custody information relating to rentals of guestrooms which are subject to the tax. The reports shall be filed with the city clerk when required by the city clerk and shall set forth the rental charged for each occupancy; the date of occupancy and such other information as the city clerk may require. 
(l)  Action for collection of tax. 
(1)  Action for tax; time for. At any time within three years after any tax or any portion of such tax required to be collected becomes due and payable, the mayor and council may bring an action in a court of competent jurisdiction in the name of the city to collect such amount due, together with interest, court fees, filing fees, attorney's fees and other incidental legal fees. 
(2)  Duty of successors or assignees of operator to withhold tax from purchase money. If any operator liable for any amount under this article sells his business or quits the business, his successors or assigns shall withhold sufficient of the purchase price to cover such amount until the former owner produces a receipt from the city clerk showing that he has been paid or a certificate showing no amount is due. 
(3)  Liability for failure to withhold, certificate of notice of amount due, time to enforce successor's liability. If the purchaser of a business fails to withhold the purchase price as required, he shall be personally liable for the payment of the amount required to be withheld by him to the extent of the purchase price. 
(4)  Tax credit, or interest paid more than once or erroneously or illegally collected. Whenever the amount of any tax or interest has been paid more than once, or has been erroneously or illegally collected or received by the city under this section, it may be offset by the city clerk. 
(m)  Penalties. Any operator or other person who fails to register as required in this articles or who fails to furnish any return required to be made, or who fails or refuses to furnish a supplemental return or other data required by the city clerk, or who renders a false or fraudulent return shall be deemed guilty of an offense and upon conviction shall be punished as provided herein. 
(Former § 4-013) 
Sec. 4-39. - Prepaid wireless transactions. 
(a)  9-1-1 Charge on prepaid wireless transactions. In accordance with O.C.G.A. § 46-5-134.2, there is hereby imposed a prepaid wireless 9-1-1 charge as defined by O.C.G.A. § 46-5-134.2(a)(4) upon every prepaid wireless retail transaction occurring within the jurisdiction of the city within the county public service answering point in the amount of $0.75. 
(b)  Collection of 9-1-1 charge on prepaid wireless transactions. Prepaid wireless 9-1-1 charges collected by sellers shall be remitted to the commissioner of the department of revenue at the times and in the manner provided by O.C.G.A. tit. 48, ch. 8 with respect to the sales and use tax imposed on prepaid wireless calling service. 
(c)  Administrative provisions. The city clerk is hereby directed to file with the state revenue commissioner a certified copy of the ordinance from which this section derives and amendments thereto, in accordance with O.C.G.A. § 46-5-134.2(j)(1), within ten days of enactment of the ordinance from which this section derives. 
(d)  Depositing of funds; use of funds. In accordance with O.C.G.A. § 46-5-134.2(j)(5), funds received by this city from charges imposed by this section shall be deposited in the Emergency Telephone System Fund maintained on behalf of the city by the county pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 46-5-134 and kept separate from general revenue of the jurisdiction. All such funds shall be used exclusively for the purposes authorized by O.C.G.A. § 46-5-134(f). 
(Former § 4-014) 
Chapter 5 - CITY COURT AND ENFORCEMENT OF ORDINANCES 

Sec. 5-1. - Creation of city court. 
    The city court of the city shall have jurisdiction and authority to try offenses against the laws and ordinances of said city and to punish for a violation of the same. Such court shall have the power to enforce its judgments by the imposition of such penalties as may be provided by this Code or laws of Georgia, to subpoena witnesses, to punish witnesses for non-attendance, and try all offenses occurring within the territorial limits of the city including traffic cases which, under the laws of Georgia, are now and hereinafter placed within the jurisdiction of municipal courts to the extent of and in accordance with the provisions of such laws and all laws subsequently enacted amendatory thereof. The presiding officer of such court shall be appointed by and serve at the pleasure of the council and shall be known as the judge of the city court. The court shall be convened at the city hall or such other place within the city as designated by the judge of the city court, with the approval of the city manager. 
(Former § 5-001) 
Sec. 5-2. - Judge. 
    The judge of the city court shall be a member of the state bar of Georgia, shall be at least 25 years of age, and have practiced law for at least three years. The council shall provide for the compensation of the judge. The council shall have authority to appoint standby associate judges to serve in the absence of the city judge. Any standby associate judge shall possess the qualifications set forth above for the judge of the city court and have the same powers granted to the judge of the city court. 
(Former § 5-002) 
Sec. 5-3. - Sessions of court. 
    A regular session of the city court shall be held once each month at a fixed hour of a fixed day determined by the judge; provided, that any session may be dispensed with when there is no business pending in the court or no cases are ready for trial. The city court may hold special sessions when, in the judge's opinion, it is necessary or there is urgent cause for trial before the next regularly scheduled session of court. 
(Former § 5-003) 
Sec. 5-4. - Clerk of court. 
    There shall be a clerk of court who shall be appointed or removed by the council. The clerk of court shall: prepare all subpoenas and warrants and maintain a docket thereof that will show the name of the person on whom the subpoena or warrant was issued, its date, at whose instance it was issued and to whom it was delivered; be the custodian of the seal of the court and have authority to certify copies of all official records of the court and to maintain the proper books of accounts, including receipts and disbursements, which the court may maintain; and perform such other duties as may be imposed upon him/her by the judge. 
(Former § 5-004) 
Sec. 5-5. - Practice. 
    The city shall have the opening and conclusion of each case, unless the defendant introduces no evidence. The city shall announce first whether ready for trial and, if not ready, shall be held to as strict a showing for a continuance as the defendant. 
(Former § 5-005) 
Sec. 5-6. - Persons charged with offense; summons and trial. 
    Any person charged with an offense shall be informed by summons in writing served on him of the nature and cause of his accusation; shall have compulsory process for obtaining witnesses in his behalf; shall have a speedy trial; shall be confronted with the witnesses against him and have the privilege of cross examination as in the superior courts of the state. The same rules as to examination of witnesses and the evidence adduced as obtained in such courts, as far as they are applicable to examining courts, shall be applicable to cases before the city court. The party accused shall have the privilege of defending himself, by counsel or by himself, or both, whichever shall seem proper to him. 
(Former § 5-006) 
Sec. 5-7. - Form and execution of summons. 
    It shall be the duty of the clerk of court in all cases where complaint is made or information given of any violation over which the city court has jurisdiction, whether the party be confined in jail or not, to issue a summons directed to the accused requiring such person to appear in city court to answer such charge, which summons shall set forth the offense, and the time and place of trial, bear the name of the judge of the city court, be signed by the clerk of court, and directed to the sheriff of Walton County, Georgia or the city department of public safety, to be executed, which sheriff or his designee or a representative of the city department of public safety shall execute the same by serving a copy on the accused or leaving it at his place of residence. 
(Former § 5-007) 
Sec. 5-8. - Witness-Subpoena. 
    When the attendance of any witness may be required before the court, the clerk of court shall issue a subpoena, directed to the witness, stating the time and place of trial and the parties to the case, and bear the name of the judge, which subpoena shall be served as other summons by the Walton County Sheriff or his designee or a representative of the city department of public safety. 
(Former § 5-008) 
Sec. 5-9. - Same-Defaulting. 
    If any person so summoned as a witness shall fail, neglect, or refuse to attend a trial, or render at the time a sufficient excuse in the judgment of the court, the defaulting witness shall be liable to a fine not to exceed $50.00 and, if the cause shall be continued on account of the witness's absence, the court may issue an attachment against such witness requiring him to show cause on the day appointed for trial why he should not be further dealt with for contempt. Any law enforcement officer, by virtue of such attachment, shall arrest and confine the person, so as to have him before the court at such time as may be appointed for further hearing of the original complaint. 
(Former § 5-009) 
Sec. 5-10. - Continuances. 
    Where the ends of justice require it, cases may be continued. All continuances shall be addressed to the sound legal discretion of the court. 
(Former § 5-010) 
Sec. 5-11. - Plea of guilty in absence of defendant. 
    Any party against whom any complaint is lodged may plead guilty under such regulations and upon such terms as the court may prescribe and, if such party cannot attend trial, the court may pass such order or sentence in the case as if the party were present. 
(Former § 5-011) 
Sec. 5-12. - Persons implicated to be tried. 
    If, on the trial of any cause before the city court, it appears that any other person besides the one on trial has committed a violation within the jurisdiction of the city court, he may then and there be tried if present, unless the case is continued for legal cause. 
(Former § 5-012) 
Sec. 5-13. - Docket. 
    A docket shall be kept in the office of clerk of court on which shall appear the name of every defendant charged with a violation of this Code or any city ordinances, or of any other offense over which the city court has jurisdiction and, at the trial of all cases in the city court, the city court judge shall record opposite the statement of the case any sentence pronounced and the date; and the clerk of court shall enter, under the city court judge's sentence, the final disposition of the case, that is, whether the fine, if any, was collected and the date of such collection, and when and to whom such amounts were turned over by the clerk of court. 
(Former § 5-013) 
Sec. 5-14. - Enforcement of penalties against corporations. 
    Whenever a corporation shall commit any violation over which the city court has jurisdiction, a warrant shall issue against such corporation for violating such provisions, and the clerk of court shall issue a copy of such warrant, which shall be served by the Walton County Sheriff or his designee or a representative of the city department of public safety, upon any officer of the corporation in the city; and the deputy serving such copy shall at the time notify such person upon whom such service is made of the time and place of trial, and shall make an entry of such service upon the warrant, showing the time of service and upon whom the service was made, and return the same to the city court, and docket the case, which case shall stand for trial in the order which other cases against individuals are tried. If, on the trial, the defendant corporation fails to appear, or appearing fails to plead, the judge of the city court shall cause to be entered a plea of not guilty, and trial shall proceed as though the defendant has appeared and pleaded. Upon conviction of any corporation, there shall be rendered judgment against it for the fine imposed by the presiding officer, together with all costs of prosecution, upon which judgment the clerk of court shall issue an execution against the defendant, which shall be levied and collected by the Walton County Sheriff or his designee or a representative of the city department of public safety, of said city as tax executions in favor of the city are now allowed by law to be levied and collected. 
(Former § 5-014) 
Sec. 5-15. - Appearance bond-Security requirement, maximum amount. 
    The city court judge, the Sheriff of Walton County, or his deputy or a representative of the department of public safety may take bond, with security or without security, at their discretion, in a sum not exceeding $1,000.00 for the appearance of any party accused of a violation of any provision of this Code or any ordinance of the city, or any other offense over which the city court has jurisdiction, to stand to and abide by his trial before the city court, and also of witnesses to testify in any case pending or about to be commenced in such court. 
(Former § 5-015) 
Sec. 5-16. - Same-Failure to give, subsequent confinement or guard. 
    If either party or witness shall fail or refuse to give the bond and security as required of them, or either of them, such person so failing or refusing may be confined to the jail of the county, or other place in Walton County, Georgia as may be directed by the city court judge, so as to be present to abide the trial or to testify as the case may be. 
(Former § 5-016) 
Sec. 5-17. - Same-Forfeiture for failure to appear, service of rule. 
    All bail taken under this chapter shall be special bail, and the power of the security over the principal shall be the same as in the special bail. Upon the failure of any principal to appear in any bond or recognizance given by a person charged with a violation of any provision of this Code or any ordinance of the city, or of any other offense over which city court has jurisdiction, or by a witness to appear and testify, the presiding officer shall pass a rule requiring the principal and sureties on such bond to show cause on a day therein named not to be less than ten days from the passage of such rule, why they should not be required to pay the amount of such bond. A copy of such rule shall be served upon the principal and security or securities by Walton County Sheriff or his designee or a representative of the city department of public safety at least five days before the time therein set for hearing the same. 
(Former § 5-017) 
Chapter 6 - PUBLIC HEALTH AND SAFETY 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 6-1. - Storage of explosive or inflammable liquid or material. 
(a)  Purpose. This section is designed as a protective measure against fire and explosion and to protect the health, welfare and safety of the residents of the city. Nothing contained in this section shall allow the storage or sale of gasoline, naphtha or other explosive or inflammable liquid or material which in any way violates federal or state law. 
(b)  Storage and installation requirements. It shall be unlawful for any entity to install a storage tank of a greater capacity than 8,000 gallons above or below the surface of the ground, and to keep stored therein gasoline, naphtha or other explosives or inflammable liquid, or to install more than three storage tanks of 8,000 gallons each or a combined capacity of 24,000 gallons, above or below the surface of the ground, and to store therein gasoline, naphtha or other explosive or inflammable liquid or material, for sale at retail or distribution otherwise within the corporate limits of the city. 
(c)  Penalties. Any entity found guilty of violating any of the provisions of this section shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and upon conviction thereof shall be fined an amount not exceeding $1,000.00, or be imprisoned in jail for a period not exceeding 30 days, or by both such fine and imprisonment. Each day such violation is committed or permitted to continue shall constitute a separate offense. Notwithstanding the foregoing, the violation of this section shall be deemed, and is declared to be, a public nuisance, and may be subject to abatement summarily by a restraining order or a temporary or permanent injunction issued by a court of competent jurisdiction. Nothing in this section shall be construed as an election of remedies and it is hereby provided that the city may seek both the criminal penalties and the injunctive relief contemplated by this section for any violation of the provisions of this section. 
(Former § 6-003) 
Sec. 6-2. - Burial of dead bodies. 
(a)  General. This section is a health measure and will be strictly enforced by the city. It shall be unlawful for any individual, partnership or corporation to bury any dead body within the city, except as specified in this section. 
(b)  Burial requirements. Any excavation or grave in which a dead body is buried within the city must be covered with soil of not less than 18 inches on top of vault or burial casing in which body is placed; the ground around said excavation or grave shall be level. 
(c)  Penalties. Any individual, partnership, corporation and/or representative violating this section will guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction, may be fined or punished by a fine not to exceed $1,000.00, by imprisonment for a term not to exceed one year, or a combination of such fine and imprisonment. 
(Former § 6-005) 
Sec. 6-3. - Open wells. 
(a)  Filling and covering requirement. All property owners with open wells must fill the wells or cover them with concrete slabs that meet with the city's specifications. 
(b)  Penalties. Any individual, partnership, corporation and/or representative violating this section will guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction, may be fined or punished by a fine not to exceed $1,000.00, by imprisonment for a term not to exceed one year, or a combination of such fine and imprisonment. 
(Former § 6-006) 
Sec. 6-4. - Municipal cemetery. 
    The mayor and council have the power and authority to: Provide, own and furnish, in and near the city, cemeteries for the burial of the dead; regulate and control the interments in such cemeteries; exercise police control and to care for such cemeteries; and, provide city care to lots in such cemeteries. The mayor and council find that the historical and cultural heritage of the city is among its most valued and important assets and that the preservation of this heritage is essential to the promotion of the health, prosperity, and general welfare of the people of the city and of the public generally. The cemeteries, graveyards, and burial grounds are uniquely precious and vulnerable thus deserving of devoted stewardship; the city is richly blessed with the heritage and history of its people who are now deceased; that many native pioneers and early residents were integral to the community's development; and that the resting places and memorials of those who have passed are valuable to current and future generations. Therefore, with the intent of caring for and managing the cemeteries, graveyards, and burying grounds, and regulating the use of such areas for the utility, education, pleasure, and welfare of the citizens; the mayor and council hereby ordain and enact into law this amended cemetery chapter. 
(1)  Definitions. The following phrases, words and their derivations shall have the meaning given herein. 
Municipal cemetery or cemetery is the municipal cemetery of the city, which includes Social Circle Cemetery East and Social Circle Cemetery West. 
Person is any person, firm, partnership, association, corporation, company or organization of any kind. 
Resident shall mean anyone who has or formerly had his/her main dwelling in the city and has or previously maintained such residence for at least 60 consecutive days prior to purchasing a burial plot in the municipal cemetery. 
Superintendent is the utilities superintendent of the city. 
(2)  Authority. The superintendent shall manage, operate and maintain the municipal cemetery subject to any limitations and restrictions set forth herein or contained in any applicable laws. 
(3)  Rules and regulations. The council may establish rules and regulations for the use of the cemetery relating to: Subdividing the cemetery into burial plots; capacity of each plot; location of graves; and type of plantings, monuments and markers that will be permitted for the proper and most attractive development of the cemetery. These rules include without limitation the following: 
a.  The use of wire, iron stands, rocks, concrete containers, or breakable containers causes hazards to visitors, lawn maintenance personnel and machinery, and are strictly prohibited. 
b.  During the grass cutting season, between the first of March and the last of October, any flowers or floral arrangements, or any other items must be placed in the permanent vase on the flat marker. Any other types of flower or floral arrangement which cannot be put in these vases are not permitted. 
c.  No trinkets (small ceramic statuary, beads, crosses, lights, etc.) are allowed on any grave space or marker since these cause mowing and trimming hazards which may harm visitors and lawn maintenance personnel and machinery. The plot owner agrees to not attempt to establish a shrine to their loved one or around a grave, inurnment, or crypt. 
d.  The city reserves the right to: 
1.  Enter upon any area and remove any monument, effigy, structure, inscription, or other items placed on, upon or near any plot that is in violation of these rules and regulations. Any items removed will not be held for reclamation and will be deemed abandoned property and will be disposed of at the city's discretion. The city will have no liability for any loss or damage to any items placed on or near a plot in violation of these rules and regulations or removed by the city; 
2.  Remove floral arrangements that have become unsightly in the opinion of the city; and 
3.  Grade and improve all sections of the city cemetery. 
e.  The plucking of, or removal of, any plant or flower, either wild or cultivated, is strictly prohibited. Planting, mowing or maintenance of any kind by anyone other than the city or those whom are contracted by the city is strictly prohibited. 
f.  The city or any contract company for the city will not be held responsible for damages to any grave marker. 
g.  Any changes such as: address, phone number or ownership of family plot are the sole responsibility of the owner to notify the city of these changes. 
h.  The city must be notified when a marker is placed so that it may be placed within the boundaries of the grave. 
i.  In the perpetual care cemetery, coping shall be grass, marble or granite, not gravel. 
(4)  Duties of the superintendent. Direct cemetery. The superintendent shall: Look after and take proper care of the cemetery and see that no plot is used or occupied in violation of this section or of any rule or regulation; Collect and turn over fees-All fees and charges collected by the superintendent for duties and services performed in connection with the cemetery shall be for the use of the city and shall immediately be turned over to the city; Supervise interment-The superintendent shall supervise internment when it is necessary for him to do so. The superintendent is authorized to require the removal of any trees or shrubbery on privately owned plots which are causing damage to adjacent plots or to city-owned property. The superintendent is authorized to effect the removal and to assess the property owner for the cost of the removal. Payments of assessments shall be made to the city clerk. All private removal of trees and shrubbery from plots shall be subject to the approval of the superintendent and shall be at the expense of the respective plot owner. The city shall be held harmless from any damages occurring as a result of the removals. 
(5)  Rules for interment. No deceased person shall be interred in the cemetery until the superintendent has found: That a burial permit has been obtained from the public health officer as required by law; that the plot in which burial is to be made has been fully paid for; that the person arranging for such burial has the right to the use of such plot; that such plot is not used beyond its capacity; and that proper record is made of the name and age of the deceased person and of the exact location of the grave. One cremated remains may be included in addition to a casket in each burial plot, or four cremated remains in a burial plot if no casket. In either case, limited to one headstone per plot. 
(6)  Lot valuation. The city may place a value on all unsold plots in the cemetery, and may record such valuations on an official map or plan of such cemetery. There shall be no discrimination in the sale of lots on any basis, except that per resolution currently residents shall be charged a purchase fee of $800.00 per plot purchased and non-residents shall be charged $2,000.00 per plot purchased, unless changed by resolution. Any person desiring to purchase a plot(s) may do so upon payment of the price fixed for such plot or upon making arrangements, according to rules and regulations that may be established by the council, for the purchase of such plot on an installment plan. In the columbarium wall the fee is per resolution $700.00 per niche for a city resident and $1,750.00 per niche for a non-resident, unless changed by resolution. 
(7)  Records of ownership. The city manager may keep full and complete records of the ownership of all plots in the cemetery, of the burial capacity of each plot, sold and unsold, of the location of each grave, of the names of the persons buried in each grave that has been or shall hereafter be used, and of the date of each burial. 
(8)  Accounts. The city manager shall keep detailed accounts of receipts and expenditures of the cemetery. 
(9)  Reports. The city manager may make an annual report on the condition of the cemetery providing the council with all information necessary to determine the amount that should be appropriated for the cemetery in the budget. 
(Former § 6-007) 
Sec. 6-5. - Nuisances. 
(a)  Definitions. For the purpose of this chapter, the following words shall have the meanings respectively ascribed below: 
    Nuisance means anything which causes hurt, inconvenience, or damage to another, provided that the hurt, inconvenience or damage complained of shall not be fanciful or such as would affect only one of fastidious taste, but rather such as would affect an ordinary reasonable person; and the fact that the act done may otherwise be lawful shall not keep it from being a nuisance. 
(1)  Nuisance per se. An act, occupation, or structure which is a nuisance at all times and under any circumstances, regardless of location or surroundings. 
(2)  Private nuisance. A nuisance limited in its injurious effects to one of a few individuals. 
(3)  Public nuisance. A nuisance which damages all persons who come within the sphere of its operation, though it may vary in its effects on individuals. 
(b)  Proceedings to abate generally. Any nuisance existing within the corporate limits of this city, except for a nuisance hereinafter expected, shall be abated in the manner set forth in this chapter. 
(1)  Initiation. Proceedings to abate a nuisance, whether public or private shall be initiated by the filing of a complaint with the city clerk, which such complaint shall state the nature and location of the nuisance and the name and address of the complainant or complainants. In the case of a private nuisance, the complaint shall be filed by the person or persons injured by the nuisance; in the case of a public nuisance, the complaint shall be filed on behalf of the public by a city official or by a citizen specially injured by the nuisance. 
(2)  Notice of hearing. Upon the filing of a complaint as hereinabove provided, the city clerk shall issue a notice directed to the owner of the premises upon which the nuisance complained of is located and, if the person maintaining the same be a different person from the owner, then also to the person maintaining the nuisance, calling on such person to show cause, either personally or by attorney, at the time and place directed by the city clerk, why such activity alleged to be a nuisance should not be ordered abated and removed by the mayor and city council. Such notice shall be served at least two days prior to the date set for the hearing by any police officer of the city, and shall be made either personally or by leaving a copy at the party's most notorious place of abode. 
A copy of such notice shall also be mailed to the complainant or complainants. 
(3)  Order of abatement. If after hearing all the evidence, the mayor and council should decide that the activity complained of is a nuisance, the mayor shall issue an order directed to the police chief or any member of the police force, commanding that the nuisance be abated. A copy of such order of abatement shall be served on the party or parties maintaining the nuisance. 
(4)  Effect of noncompliance. In the event of a refusal to comply with the order of abatement issued by the mayor, the person or persons maintaining the nuisance shall be subject to arrest for violation of state law. 
(c)  Summary abatement. Nothing contained in the foregoing section shall prevent the mayor and city council from summarily and without notice ordering the abatement of or abating any nuisance per se in the law or where the case is an urgent one and the health and safety of the public or a portion thereof is in imminent danger. 
(d)  Findings regarding unsafe, unsanitary or abandoned buildings, dwellings or structures. Under the authority of O.C.G.A. § 41-2-9, the mayor and council specifically adopt by incorporation herein by reference the provisions of O.C.G.A. §§ 41-2-7, 41-2-8, 41-2-9, 41-2-10, 41-2-11, 41-2-12, 41-2-13, 41-2-14, 41-2-15, 41-2-16, and 41-2-17. These provisions are adopted as an official ordinance of the city as if specifically set forth herein in their entirety. 
(e)  Duties of city manager or her designee. Pursuant to the authority of O.C.G.A. § 41-2-10, the mayor and council of the city hereby designate the city manager or her designee as the public officer with the authority to enforce the provisions of § 4.4 of the City of Social Circle Code of Ordinances. The city manager or her designee may determine, under existing ordinances, that dwellings, buildings or structures are unfit for human habitation or are unfit for its current commercial, industrial, or business use if he finds that conditions exist in such buildings, dwellings, or structures which are dangerous or injurious to the health, safety or morals of the occupants of such dwellings, buildings or structures; of the occupants of neighborhood dwellings, buildings, or structures; or of other residences of this municipality. Such conditions may include the following (without limiting the generality of the foregoing): 
(1)  Defects therein increasing the hazards of fire, accidents, or other calamities; 
(2)  Lack of adequate ventilation, light or sanitary facilities; 
(3)  Dilapidation; 
(4)  Disrepair; 
(5)  Structural defects; and 
(6)  Uncleanliness. 
    The public officer designated by this section may determine, under existing ordinances, that a dwelling, building, or structure is vacant, dilapidated, and being used in connection with the commission of drug crimes upon personal observation or report of a law enforcement agency and evidence of drug crimes being committed. 
    Within the context of this section, the public official shall utilize the existing codes of the city to the standard for satisfaction of the provisions of this section including but not limited to the electrical codes, building codes and fire codes previously adopted by the city. 
(e)  Further duties of city manager or her designee. The city manager or her designee is hereby authorized to exercise such powers as may be necessary or convenient to carry out and effectuate the purpose and provisions of this section and O.C.G.A. § 41-2-7 through § 41-2-10 and O.C.G.A. § 41-2-12 through § 41-2-17, including the following powers in addition to others granted in O.C.G.A. § 41-2-7 through § 41-2-10 and O.C.G.A. § 41-2-12 through § 41-2-17: 
(1)  To investigate the dwelling conditions in the city in order to determine which dwellings, buildings, or structures therein are unfit for human habitation or are unfit for current commercial, industrial, or business use or are vacant, dilapidated, and being used in connection with the commission of drug crimes; 
(2)  To administer oaths and affirmations, to examine witnesses, and to receive evidence; 
(3)  To enter upon premises for the purpose of making examinations; provided, however, that such entries shall be made in such manner as to cause the least possible inconvenience to the persons in possession; 
(4)  To appoint and affix the duties of such officers, agents, and employees as he deems necessary to carry out the purposes of the ordinances and provisions adopted herein; and 
(5)  To delegate any of his functions and powers under the ordinance to such officers and agents as he may designate. 
(Ord. No. 2017-7, § 2, 4-18-2017) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2017-7, § 2, adopted April 18, 2017, did not specify manner of inclusion; hence, inclusion as section 6-5 is at the discretion of the editor. 
Secs. 6-6-6-25. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - EMERGENCY MANAGEMENT 

Sec. 6-26. - Generally. 
(a)  Definition. 
    Emergency management shall mean the preparation for and the carrying out of all emergency and disaster functions other than those functions for which military forces or state and federal agencies are primarily responsible, to prevent, minimize, and repair injury and damage resulting from emergencies or disasters, or the imminent threat thereof, of manmade or natural origin. These functions include, without limitation, fire fighting services, police services, medical and health services, rescue, engineering, warning services, communications, protection against the effects of radiological, chemical and other special weapons, evacuation of persons from stricken areas, emergency welfare services, emergency transportation, plant protection, shelter, temporary restoration of public utility services, and other functions related to civilian population, together with all other activities necessary or incidental to total emergency and disaster preparedness for carrying out the foregoing functions. 
(b)  Office of the county emergency management director. It is the desire and intent of the city to be a part of the Walton County emergency management agency. The chairman, county commissioners of Walton County, with concurrence of the mayors of all cities within the county, shall nominate for appointment, by the governor, a director of emergency management for the entire county. When appointed, the emergency management director is charged with the following duties: 
(1)  To represent the council of the city on matters pertaining to emergency management and to assist city officials in organizing city departments for emergency operations; 
(2)  To develop, in conjunction with city and county departments the Walton County Plan for Emergency Functions set forth in subsection (a). Such plan will be in consonance with the Georgia Natural Disaster Operations Plan and Nuclear Operations Plan, and shall be submitted to the governing officials of Walton County and the cities therein for approval, and then to the Georgia Emergency Management Agency for approval. 
(3)  To maintain the emergency management agency and carry out the day-to-day administration of the Walton County emergency management program, including the submission of required reports, to the Georgia Emergency Management Agency. 
(4)  To submit reports required by the council in keeping with good management practices, e.g., financial, daily activity; and 
(5)  To obtain, with the authority of all governing officials, a facility to be used as the Walton County emergency operating center and to coordinate the activities of the Walton County emergency operating center staff during periods of an emergency, and under the supervision of Walton County governing officials. 
(c)  Walton County emergency management agency. The Walton County Emergency Management Agency shall be established around existing city and county departments and the emergency functions describe in subsection (a) above are assigned as follows: 
DEPARTMENT/AGENCY FUNCTIONS County Board of Commissioners and City Mayors Direction and Control Walton County Clerk Administrative Services and Resources County Sheriff's Department; City Police Departments Police Services and Search and Recover Communications County and City Fire Departments Rescue, Fire and Hazardous Material Control Walton County Superintendent of Schools; Social Circle Superintendent of Schools Transportation Services Walton County Road and Bridges Department; City Street Departments Engineering Monroe Water, Light and Gas Commission and Walton County Sewerage and Water Authority Utilities, Petroleum and Solid Fuel Walton County Department of Family and Children Services Social Services Walton County Health Department Health and Medical Services Walton County Chamber of Commerce Emergency Public Information Walton County Emergency Management Agency Evacuation; Radiological Protection; Training; Damage Assessment; Public Property Assistance; Specific Hazards; and State Military Support Walton County Chapter American Red Cross Sheltering and Temporary Housing and Food Services  
    Heads of city departments listed above are responsible for developing appropriate annexes to the local emergency operations plan (EOP) for their assigned emergency functions. Such annexes will be submitted to the emergency management director for inclusion in the local EOP for submission to appropriate local officials for approval. 
(Former § 6-001(1.)) 
Sec. 6-27. - Emergency powers. 
(a)  Powers during an emergency or disaster. In the event of a man-made or natural disaster, actual enemy attack upon the United States, or any other emergency which may affect the lives and property of the citizens of the city, the mayor separately, or jointly with the chairman, county commissioners, or in their absences their legally appointed successors, may determine that an emergency or disaster exists and thereafter shall have and may exercise for such period as such emergency or disaster exists or continues, the following powers: 
(1)  To enforce all rules, laws and regulations pertaining to emergency management, and to assume direct operational control over all emergency management resources; 
(2)  To seize or take for temporary use, any private property for the protection of the public; 
(3)  To sell, lend, give or distribute all or any of such property or supplies among the inhabitants of the county and to maintain a strict accounting of property or supplies distributed and for funds received for such property or supplies; and 
(4)  To perform and exercise such other functions and duties, and take such emergency actions as may be necessary to promote and secure the safety, protection and well-being of the inhabitants of the county. 
(b)  Volunteers. All persons, other than officers and employees of the city, performing emergency functions pursuant to this Code shall serve with or without compensation. While engaged in such emergency functions, duly assigned volunteers shall have the same immunities as city officers and employees. 
(Former § 6-001(2.)) 
Sec. 6-28. - Penalties. 
    Any person violating any provision of this chapter shall, upon conviction thereof, be punishable for committing a misdemeanor. 
(Former § 6-001(3.)) 
Sec. 6-29. - Mutual aid during local emergencies. 
(a)  Findings and purpose. 
(1)  Findings. The city provides fire protection services to the citizens of Social Circle through its fire department. On occasion local emergencies occur, during which there exist conditions of extreme peril to the safety of persons and property, as caused by natural disasters, riots, civil disturbances or other emergency situations. These local emergencies present potentially major public safety problems, which conditions are or are likely to be beyond the control of the personnel, equipment, and facilities of the city. Neighboring political subdivisions are likely to also be confronted with similar local emergencies, which conditions are or are likely to be beyond the control of personnel, equipment and facilities of these jurisdictions. The state has provided for mutual aid during local emergencies through O.C.G.A. §§ 36-69-1, et seq. the Georgia Mutual Aid Act. 
(2)  Purpose. The purpose of this section is to provide a mechanism where the resources of the city can be combined with resources of a neighboring political subdivision during local emergencies, so that the life and property of all may be better protected and to demonstrate the desire of the citizens of the city to be good neighbors during times of local emergencies in neighboring political subdivisions. 
(b)  Mutual aid authorized. 
(1)  Requesting assistance from neighboring jurisdictions. The fire chief of the city may request assistance and cooperation from neighboring political subdivisions during local emergencies in the city pursuant to the Georgia Mutual Aid Act. 
(2)  Providing assistance to neighboring jurisdictions. The fire chief of the city shall cooperate with and provide assistance during local emergencies to neighboring political subdivisions of the state. 
(Former § 6-002) 
Secs. 6-29-6-50. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - LITTER CONTROL, GARBAGE DISPOSAL AND YARD TRIMMINGS REGULATIONS 

Sec. 6-51. - Litter control. 
(a)  Definitions. 
    Litter includes without limitation all sand, gravel, slag, brickbats, rubbish, waste material, tin cans, refuse, garbage, trash, debris, dead animals or discarded materials of every kind and description. 
    Public or private property includes without limitation the rights-of-way of any road or highway; any body of water or watercourse or the shores or beaches thereof; any park, playground, building, refuge, conservation or recreation area; and residential or farm properties, timberlands or forests. 
(b)  Scope. 
(1)  Dumping litter on public or private property. It shall be unlawful to dump, deposit, throw or leave or to cause or permit the dumping, depositing, placing, throwing or leaving of litter on any public or private property in the city unless: the property is designated by the city for the disposal of litter and the person is authorized to use such property for such purpose; the litter is properly placed into a litter receptacle or container lawfully installed on such property; or the person is the owner or lawful tenant and has properly placed non-oversized litter at curbside for regular scheduled pickups, in a manner consistent with the public welfare. Oversized litter is that which does not fit in a standard garbage collection company supplied bin. 
(2)  Prima-facie evidence. Whenever litter is thrown, deposited, dropped or dumped from any vehicle, it shall be prima-facie evidence that the operator of the conveyance has violated this section. 
(3)  Rebuttable presumption. Except as provided in subsection (b)(2) above, whenever any litter is discovered to contain any items which display the name of a person thereon so as to indicate that the item belongs or belonged to such person, it shall be prima-facie evidence that such person has violated this section. 
(4)  Enforcement. All law enforcement agencies and officers of the city and any person, officer or constable appointed by the council are authorized, empowered and directed to enforce compliance with the above regulations. 
(5)  Designation of containers for household garbage. As used in subsections (b)(5) and (6) of this section, household garbage means animal, vegetable and fruit refuse matter and other matter ordinarily generated as by-products of a household or restaurant, including but not limited to, tin cans, bottles, paper, cardboard, plastics and wrapping or packaging materials. The council may provide containers for the dumping of trash or garbage therein and shall be authorized to designate any or all such containers as being suitable for the dumping therein of household garbage only. 
(6)  Misuse or vandalization of container. If a container is clearly marked household garbage only, it shall be unlawful for any person to dump any refuse or other material into the container other than household garbage. It shall be unlawful for any person to set fire to the contents of, scatter or disperse the contents of, or otherwise vandalize, any containers provided by the city for the dumping of trash or garbage. Any person who violates subsections (b)(5) or (6) shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(7)  Penalties. Any person who violates this section shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction thereof, shall be punished as follows: by a fine of not less than $300.00 nor more than $1,000.00; in the sound discretion of the court, the person may be directed to pick up and remove from any public street or highway or public right-of-way for a distance not to exceed one mile, all litter deposited by anyone prior to the date of execution of sentence; or in the sound discretion of the court, the person may be directed to pick up all litter from any public park, private right-of-way or, with the prior permission of the owner, private property upon which it can be established by competent evidence that the person has deposited litter. The court may publish the names of persons convicted of violating this section. 
(Former § 6-004(1.)) 
Sec. 6-52. - Garbage disposal regulations. 
(a)  Collection containers provided by city. The city shall furnish to each single-family residence a roll-out cart and a recycling basket. The owner and lessee shall be responsible for replacing any damaged roll-out cart and/or recycling basket. If an owner or lessee shall move from the residence such owner or lessee shall notify the city and the cart will be reclaimed. The city may either provide roll-out carts and recycling baskets to individual residents of multifamily housing or a sufficient number of stationary dumpsters in each apartment complex for use by residents. All non-residential customers must use and pay for a dumpster or rollout cart for depositing household garbage. Such containers may be furnished by the city or a private vendor. No cardboard boxes may be placed in a container unless they are first demolished and folded so the boxes are flat. 
(b)  Size, bundling and placement of garbage. All household garbage shall be placed in the container. No construction/demolition debris, tires, magazines, ashes, wood, metal, yard trimmings, waste products or other related materials which are not household garbage may be placed in or around the containers. The city will not empty or pick up such containers, and the person depositing or allowing the deposit of such prohibited material shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and remain responsible for lawful disposal thereof. Residential owners and lessees who have been given a roll-out cart and recycling basket shall place the cart and basket near the curb or street by 5:30 a.m. on the day of collection in their area prior to the arrival of the sanitation vehicles and shall remove the cart by 7:00 p.m. of the same day. This requirement of curbside placement may be waived for any person who is physically unable to place the cart on the street. The city manager must approve all such waivers. 
(c)  Monthly charge imposed; persons liable. To defray the costs of collection of garbage and recyclables, monthly sanitary and health fees are herewith fixed and assessed against the owner and occupant of each residence in the city, unless the city, in its sole discretion acting through the city manager, determines it is not practical for the owner or occupant to use such services and such services are not used. The amount of the monthly charges shall be set by the council and a schedule of such charges is on file in the clerk's office, which schedule as amended is incorporated herein by reference. 
(d)  Evasion of monthly charge. It shall be a misdemeanor for any person to place or cause to be placed on the premises of another, any garbage, to avoid the monthly sanitation and health charge. 
(e)  Termination of services for non-payment of charges. Any person failing to pay the monthly sanitary and health charge shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and, in addition to other penalties, all garbage collection provided by the city to the premises for which the monthly charges are past due may be immediately terminated by the city. 
(Former § 6-004(2.)) 
Sec. 6-53. - Yard trimmings disposal regulations. 
(a)  Definitions. 
    Commercial solid waste means all types of solid waste generated by stores, office, restaurants, warehouses and other non-manufacturing activities, excluding residential and industrial wastes. 
    Composting means the controlled biological decomposition of organic matter into stable, odor-free humus. 
    Leachate collection system means a system at a landfill for collection of the leachate which may percolate through the waste and into the soils surrounding the landfill or transfer station. 
    Municipal solid waste means any solid waste derived from households, including garbage, trash and sanitary waste in septic tanks and includes solid waste from single-family and multifamily residences, hotels and motels, bunkhouses, campgrounds, picnic grounds, and day use recreation areas; includes yard trimmings and commercial solid waste, but not construction/demolition debris, tires, wood, metal, solid waste from mining, agricultural or silvicultural operations or industrial processes or operations. 
    Municipal solid waste disposal facility means any location where the final deposition of any municipal solid waste occurs, whether or not mixed with or including commercial or industrial solid waste, including but not limited to municipal solid waste landfills. 
    Municipal solid waste landfill means a disposal or transfer facility where any amount of municipal solid waste, whether or not mixed with or including commercial waste, industrial waste, nonhazardous sludge or small quantity generator hazardous waste, is disposed of by means of placing an approved cover thereon. 
    Yard trimmings mean leaves, brush, grass clippings, shrub and tree prunings, discarded Christmas trees, nursery and greenhouse vegetative residuals, and vegetative matter resulting from landscaping development and maintenance, other than mining, agricultural and silvicultural operations. 
(b)  Placement and disposal of yard trimmings-Prohibitions. It shall be unlawful to place or mix yard trimmings with other municipal solid waste within the incorporated area of the city. Yard trimmings shall not be disposed of at any municipal solid waste disposal facility having a liner and leachate collection system or requiring vertical expansion located within the city. 
(c)  Sorting, storing, composting and collecting yard trimmings. Yard trimmings shall be sorted and stockpiled, or chipped, or composted, or used as mulch or otherwise beneficially reused or recycled to the maximum extent feasible.
