    The council hereby adopt the following required options for handling yard trimmings: 
(1)  Naturalized, low-maintenance landscaping requiring little or no cutting; 
(2)  Grass cycling by mowing it high and letting it lie; 
(3)  Stacking branches into brush piles for use as wildlife habitats and for gradual decomposition into the soil; 
(4)  Composting on site where material was grown, followed by incorporation of the finished compost into the soil at that site; 
(5)  Chipping woody material on the site where such material was generated; 
(6)  Collecting yard trimmings and transporting them to another site to be chipped or composted for later use; and 
(7)  Chipping woody material for later use as fiber fuel. 
(d)  Penalties. Any person violating this section shall be punished by a fine not to exceed $1,000.00, by imprisonment for a term not to exceed six months, or a combination of such. 
(Former § 6-004(3.)) 
Secs. 6-54-6-75. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2017-7, § 1, adopted April 18, 2017, repealed the former section 6-54 in its entirety, which pertained to nuisances and derived from the prior code § 6-004(4.). 
 For current provisions pertaining to nuisances, the user's attention is directed to section 6-5. 
ARTICLE IV. - BODY CRAFTING 

Sec. 6-76. - Authority. 
    The legal authority for this is O.C.G.A. §§ 16-5-71, 16-5-71.1, 16-12-5, 31-3-4, 31-5-1, et seq. and 31-40-1, et seq. 
(Former § 6-008(1.)) 
Sec. 6-77. - Purpose and findings. 
    The unregulated operation of body craft studios and body craft procedures constitutes a health risk to the general public, and poses a significant risk of transfer of communicable diseases, infections, pathogens and other harmful agents to and among the citizens of Social Circle. Substandard and poor sanitary conditions exist in the body craft and tattoo industry that pose a health risk to the safety and welfare of the general public. These regulations include reasonable standards that will ameliorate the substandard sanitary conditions in this industry and safeguard the public health, safety, and general welfare of the citizens of Social Circle and the individuals who utilize body craft and tattoo procedure rooms. There is a substantial need directly related to the public health, safety, and general welfare to comprehensively address these concerns through the adoption of the following regulations. 
(Former § 6-008(2.)) 
Sec. 6-78. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms, and phrases, when used in this section shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Antibacterial solution means any solution used to retard the growth of bacteria approved for application to human skin and includes all products labeled accordingly as approved by the FDA. 
    Antiseptic means any solution used to retard the growth of bacteria approved for application to human skin and includes all products labeled accordingly as approved by the United States FDA. 
    Biohazard means any infectious agent(s) or parts thereof presenting a risk to health or well-being, directly or indirectly, through infection or through disruption of the environment. 
    Board of health means the Newton County Board of Health. 
    Body crafting means physical body alteration by permitted establishments and by licensed operators using: body piercing, tattooing, and cosmetic tattooing. Branding, scarification, implants and suspension shall not be performed in a body craft studio. "Body crafting" does not include practices that are considered medical procedures by the Georgia State Medical Board, which shall not be performed in a body craft studio. Body crafting does not include the painting of the skin with tempura or temporary, non-indelible inks, paints or dyes. 
    Body craft studio means any building or structure where body craft is performed. 
    Body crafter means any person who performs body crafting. 
    Body crafter permit means the authorization granted to the body crafter to perform body crafting. Such permit is the property of the board of health. 
    Body piercing means puncturing or penetration of the skin or mucosa of a person with any sharp instrument and/or the insertion of jewelry or other adornment thereto in the opening, except that piercing of the outer perimeter or lobe of the ear with pre-sterilized single-use stud and clasp ear piercing systems shall not be included in this definition. 
    CDC means Centers for Disease Control. 
    Cosmetic tattooing means to mark or color the skin by pricking in, piercing, or implanting indelible pigments or dyes under the skin or mucosa. "Cosmetic tattooing" shall include permanent cosmetics, micro-pigmentation, permanent color technology, and micro-pigment implantation. 
    City or town means Social Circle, Georgia, and includes the board of health and its duly authorized representatives or employees. 
    Currently licensed health care professional means professionals licensed by Georgia to perform health care services and includes licensed physicians, registered nurses (RN), licensed practical nurses (LPN), and licensed emergency medical technicians. 
    Department means the department of human resources of the State of Georgia. 
    Director means the director of the board of health or the director's designee. 
    Disinfection means a process that eliminates many or all pathogenic microorganisms, with the exception of bacterial spores from inanimate objects. Guideline for Environmental Infection Control in Healthcare Facilities: Recommendation of CDC and the Healthcare Infection Control Practices Advisory Committee (HICPAC); U.S. Department of Health and Human Services Center for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) (2003). In the event that HICPAC or the CDC publishes materials or amends regulations applicable to this definition, this definition shall be deemed amended to include the latest versions of these documents, regulations, and recommendations. 
    Easily cleanable means readily accessible, non-absorbent material and of such finish and fabrication that residue may be completely removed by non-mechanical low friction methods. 
    EPA means the United States Environmental Protection Agency. 
    FDA means the United States Food and Drug Administration. 
    Hand hygiene means hand washing, antiseptic hand wash, antiseptic hand rub, or surgical hand antisepsis. Guideline for Hand Hygiene in Health-care Settings: Recommendations of the Healthcare Infection Control Practices Advisory Committee and the HICPAC/SHEA/APIC/IDSA Hand Hygiene Task Force. Morbidity and Mortality Weekly Report (MMWR); October 25, 2002; 51 RRl6); 1-44. 
    Implant means to fix an object in or under human tissue. Body craft implants include, but are not limited to, three-dimensional body craft applications. This definition of implant does not include medical procedures by board-certified medical and dental personnel. 
    Instrument means any hand piece, needle, needle bar, sharp, device, or other object that is used or may come into contact with a client or may be exposed to bodily fluids during body crafting. 
    OSHA means the United States Occupational Safety and Health Administration. 
    Owner means the person or entity that owns, maintains or controls a body craft studio and who is responsible for the operation of the studio. 
    Permit means written authorization to operate a body craft studio. 
    Plan of correction means the plan to correct deficiencies in meeting this section. 
    Procedure room means the room in a body craft studio where the body crafter does body crafting. 
    Sanitary means no visible debris, residue or contamination, and reduced microbial contaminants. 
    Sanitized means an effective antimicrobial treatment by a process that provides sufficient chemicals or other suitable method on surfaces for enough time to reduce the microbial count to a sanitary level. 
    Sharps means any discarded article that may cause punctures or cuts to the skin or tissues. 
    Single-use means an instrument or article reasonably anticipated to come into contact with blood and compromised tissue surfaces during use. Such are not to be used on more than one customer or client for any reason, and must be disposed of after use as soon as is possible without posing risk of contamination or exposure to the body crafter, the client or the environment. The Director shall determine and publish a list of instruments and articles that are considered single-use. 
    Standard precautions means guidelines and controls, published by CDC which include specific recommendations for gloves, masks, protective eye wear and/or other protective equipment when contact with blood or bodily fluids containing blood is anticipated. Standard precautions apply to blood, all body fluids, secretions, and excretions, excluding sweat, regardless of whether they contain visible blood, non-intact skin, and mucous membranes. (Guidelines for Isolation Precautions in Hospitals. Infect Control Hosp Epidemiol (1996); 17:53-80. Additional references include Guidelines for Prevention of Transmission of Human Immunodeficiency Virus and Hepatitis B Virus to Health-Care and Public-Safety Workers. Morbidity and Mortality Weekly Report (MMWR), June 23, 1989; 38: No. S-6. Recommendation for Preventing Transmission of Human Immunodeficiency Virus and Hepatitis B Virus to Patients During Exposure-Prone Invasive Procedures. MMWR, July 12, 1991; 40: No. RR-8. Recommendations for Prevention and Control of HCV Infection and HCV Related Chronic Disease. MMWR, October 16, 1998; 47: No. RR-19. Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) Blood-borne Pathogens Precautions Standard. 29 CFR 1910, 1030.) If CDC, OSHA, or other primary reference or regulatory authority publish materials or amend regulations applicable to this definition, this definition shall be deemed amended to include the latest versions. 
    Sterilization means reduction of microbial life at an order of 10 LOG 6 using equipment capable of delivering full efficacy to all surfaces in the unit chamber, including tubes, lumens, cracks, or other obscured surfaces, including those in packaging. 
    Sterilizer means a piece of equipment that performs sterilization as defined herein. 
    Sterilizer indicator means a device designed to give visual verification that sterilization temperature and/or pressure has been achieved during the sterilization procedure. 
    Studio means a body craft studio. 
    Suspension means piercing of human tissue or skin with hooks or other piercing apparatuses for supporting or bearing weight, either human or object. 
    Tattoo means to mark or color the skin by pricking in or piercing indelible pigments or dyes under the skin or mucosa and includes the definition of tattoo as defined in O.C.G.A. § 31-40-1(1) and as may hereafter be amended; also includes all forms of cosmetic tattooing. 
(Former § 6-008(3.)) 
Sec. 6-79. - Exemptions. 
    These rules shall not apply to a physician or osteopath licensed under O.C.G.A. tit. 43, ch. 34, or a technician acting under the direct on-site supervision of licensed physician or osteopath. 
(Former § 6-008(4.)) 
Sec. 6-80. - Body crafting not allowed in mobile, transitory facilities. 
    Body crafting is not allowed in autos, tents, RV's, trailers, mobile, transitory, or other non-fixed facilities. 
(Former § 6-008(5.)) 
Sec. 6-81. - Responsibilities of body craft studio owner. 
    The owner shall comply with all requirements of this section, all requirements in O.C.G.A. §§ 31-40-1 et seq. and all applicable administrative rules and regulations of the department, including all applicable statutes, rules and regulations regarding disclosure of ownership. The owner shall comply with all city and Walton County Ordinances, including the zoning ordinance of Social Circle. 
(Former § 6-008(6.)) 
Sec. 6-82. - Body craft studio minimum floor plan requirements. 
(a)  All body craft studios shall be constructed, arranged, and maintained to protect the health and safety of its customers and staff. 
(b)  All body craft studios shall be constructed to allow the customer receiving the procedure privacy from observers. 
(c)  Insects, vermin, and rodents shall not be present at the body craft studio, building, or premises. Effective pest control measures shall be taken to prevent such. 
(d)  The body craft studio shall have adequate mechanical ventilation that complies with all applicable provisions of this Code and any other building codes. 
(e)  Walls and ceilings of the procedure room shall be painted or covered to allow effective cleaning. All paint and coverings shall be light color. Walls, floors, and ceilings shall be painted or covered to allow to be easily cleanable. 
(f)  Floors shall be approved, nonabsorbent material, which will allow effective cleaning and disinfection. Floors in the procedure room areas shall not be covered by carpet or wood. 
(g)  A clean and sanitary toilet and hand washing facility with a self-closing door and exhaust fan shall be accessible to customers. Such facilities shall be separate from the procedure room. 
(h)  The procedure room shall be equipped with facilities to enable effective hand hygiene using methods currently approved and recommended by the CDC, such as a brushless alcohol-based scrub system or a sink providing hot and cold water under pressure through a mixing valve with no aerator, and with foot or wrist actuated controls. These facilities shall be for the body crafter for sanitizing his or her hands and preparing customers for body crafting. This area shall he supplied with supplies necessary for body crafting. 
(i)  An equipment-washing sink shall be in the studio, distinct from the hand sinks, and shall be in the equipment handling and assembly area. It shall meet National Safety Foundation standards. 
(j)  The procedure room shall have an artificial light source of at least 20 lumens, three feet off the floor. Body craft procedure areas, and equipment handling and assembly areas shall have an artificial light source at least 100 lumens at the level where the procedure is performed. 
(k)  The body craft studio shall utilize a hot water heater, capable of continuously heating water to 100°F and maintaining such temperature, to provide hot water to the studio. 
(Former § 6-008(7.)) 
Sec. 6-83. - Furnishings and fixtures. 
(a)  Furnishings of the body craft studio shall be maintained sanitary, intact, and functional. The studio shall be kept clean, neat, and free of litter and rubbish. 
(b)  Cabinets for storage of instruments, single-use articles, stencils, jewelry, studs and supplies shall be provided for each procedure room and designed, manufactured, and maintained to protect the contents from blood and body fluid contamination. 
(c)  Appropriate furnishings shall be provided in procedure rooms. Surfaces of all furnishings shall be smooth, nonporous, nonabsorbent, corrosion-resistant and easily cleaned and disinfected. 
(d)  Furnishings shall be disinfected with an EPA-approved disinfectant after each body crafting. 
(e)  Smoking, eating, or drinking is prohibited in the procedure room, except water as required to ensure the health and safety of the body crafter and/or the client. 
(Former § 6-008(8.)) 
Sec. 6-84. - Body craft studio supplies. 
(a)  Single-use sterile articles shall be in uncompromised, sterilized condition at the time of use, either by processing in a unit that meets the requirements for a sterilizer as defined herein, or packaged and sterilized by the manufacturer in an FDA approved facility. These shall be handled to prevent contamination including all requirements hereof and shall be stored separate from chemical supplies and facilities utilizing open supplies of running water. 
(b)  Any jewelry used in any procedure shall consist of a material rated by the American Society for Testing Materials or the International Standards Organization as suitable for permanent surgical implant, such as stainless steel, titanium, niobium, solid platinum or a dense low porosity plastic such as Tygon or PTFE. Copies of the jewelry manufacturer's documentation, which verify compliance with standards, must be available for inspection on request of the director. Solid 14 karat, or higher, white or yellow nickel-free gold may also be used. Purity verification must be available for inspection on request of the director. 
(c)  Only single-use sterile gauze shall be used. 
(d)  Single-use articles shall not be used on more than one customer, and must be disposed of after use as soon as possible without posing risk of contamination or exposure to the body crafter, the client, or the environment. 
(e)  Dyes and pigments shall be dispensed into single-use containers. 
(f)  After tattooing each individual, the remaining unused dye or pigment in the single-use container shall be discarded, along with the container, into a biohazard container. 
(Former § 6-008(9.)) 
Sec. 6-85. - Body craft studio permit requirement and application process. 
(a)  No body craft shall be performed outside the confines of a current and validly permitted body craft studio. The owner must apply to the director for a permit to operate in Social Circle at least 30 days prior to the anticipated date of operation of the body craft studio. 
(b)  The permit application shall be on forms promulgated by the director and shall not be accepted until complete in all respects, including payment of application fee set by the board of health. 
(c)  The application for a permit shall list the full legal names, home addresses, and telephone numbers of the owner(s) of the body craft studio. 
(d)  Any individual or entity with any interest in the body craft studio shall be fully disclosed, and the extent or amount of such ownership shall be provided to the director in the application. 
(e)  The application shall contain written proof that the studio complies herewith, plus with the building, gas, electrical, and plumbing codes and zoning ordinances. 
(f)  The application shall include owner's written statement of policies & procedures that ensures: 
(1)  No person under 18 shall perform body crafting upon any person; 
(2)  Body crafters shall not be under the influence of alcohol and/or drugs; 
(3)  No body crafting shall be performed on a person who appears to be under the influence; 
(4)  No person under 18 shall be permitted to access any body craft studio; 
(5)  No animals shall be allowed in a body craft studio, except service animals for disability; 
(6)  Each body crafter shall have a valid body crafter permit. 
(g)  The application for a permit shall be on forms provided by the board of health environmental health section. Such application shall be signed and verified by the owner. 
(h)  New studios. 
(1)  At least 30 days before date of opening, the owner of a new body craft studio shall submit an application to the board of health for a permit. 
(2)  The application for a new body craft studio shall include: 
a.  A quarter-inch per foot scale drawing of the body craft studio, signed by a registered engineer or architect. Such shall accurately show Hand sinks, bathroom(s), first-aid kits, waiting area(s), windows, doors, tables, chairs, room measurements, equipment. 
b.  A zoning certification from the city. The applicant shall comply with all applicable zoning, building, safety, fire, and other local codes and requirements; 
c.  A copy of the certificate of occupancy for the studio; 
d.  A complete description of all body craft services to be provided; 
e.  The full or legal name under which the body craft studio is conducted; 
f.  Address of the body craft studio; if owner leases, name and address of landlord; 
g.  Name and home address of the owner; if the owner of the studio is an entity, the formation date and names and addresses of all partners/ shareholders/members and the name and address of registered agent. 
h.  List of names and home addresses of all staff who will be working in the studio; 
i.  Written policies and procedures of the body craft studio; and 
j.  Signed acknowledgement that owner has read, understands and will comply with this section. 
(3)  The applicant shall submit a non-refundable plan review fee set by the board of health. 
(i)  Existing studios. 
(1)  At least 30 days prior to the expiration of a body craft studio permit, the owner shall submit an application to the board of health for a new studio permit. No body craft studio shall be operated without a permit that is current. 
(2)  The application for a body craft studio permit for an existing studio shall include: 
a.  A complete description of all body craft services at the studio; 
b.  The full or legal name under which the body craft studio is operated; 
c.  The address; if leased, the landlord and the landlord's address; 
d.  The name and home address of the owner; if the owner of the studio is an entity, the formation date and names and addresses of all partners/ shareholders/members and the name and address of registered agent. 
e.  A list of names and home addresses of all of staff of the body craft studio; 
f.  A copy of the written policies and procedures of the body craft studio; and 
g.  Signed acknowledgement that owner has read, understands and will comply with this section. 
(Former § 6-008(10.)) 
Sec. 6-86. - Denial, suspension or revocation of body craft studio permit. 
(a)  Upon recommendation of the director or official action of the board of health, a permit may be denied, suspended or revoked by the board of health, and considered null and void, if: 
(1)  The application contains false or misleading information or omitted material facts; 
(2)  The premises are in violation of any provision hereof, or other state or federal law; 
(3)  The studio is determined to be a threat or nuisance to public health, safety or welfare; 
(4)  The owner or body crafter violated the provisions of this section; or 
(5)  Violations of the conditions of the permit are committed. 
(b)  If a body craft studio permit has been revoked, a permit shall not be issued until all violations have been cured and all changes comport herewith as determined by the director. 
(c)  No body craft studio permit shall be issued to any applicant, business, or related entity who, within 12 months preceding the filing of an application, has been denied a permit or has had a permit revoked for any location due to fraudulent or untruthful information in any application or having omitted any material fact in any application. 
(d)  Any person substantially affected by any final order of the board of health denying, suspending, revoking or refusing to grant or renew any permit provided under this section may secure review by appeal to the department of human resources per O.C.G.A. § 31-5-1 et seq. 
(Former § 6-008(11.)) 
Sec. 6-87. - Body craft studio permit. 
(a)  No permit shall be issued to any owner not in full compliance with this Code or state law. 
(b)  The body craft studio permit must be obtained annually and expires 365 days from date of its issuance. The original permit shall be conspicuously displayed in public view on the premises. 
(c)  Permits are not transferable from owner to owner, or from location to business location, or from person to person. 
(d)  The holder of a body craft studio permit shall only hire, employ, or use individuals to perform body crafting who have complied with this section. 
(e)  Body craft studio permits are the exclusive property of the board of health. Permits may be confiscated by the board of health, or its designee, per this Code or state law. 
(Former § 6-008(12.)) 
Sec. 6-88. - Inspections. 
(a)  The director shall make inspections and issue written reports of such. The premises of any body craft studio and all records required to be maintained shall be available for examination by the director and properly identified representatives of the city during normal business hours to determine compliance. The owner shall have an employee knowledgeable as to the whereabouts of these records on duty during all hours of operation. 
(b)  Work necessary to receive a permit shall at all times be subject to inspection by the director. The owner shall ensure all work shall remain accessible for inspection until approved. Approval shall not be construed to be an approval of any violation or nullify any provisions of the Code or other law. Neither the director nor the city or county shall be liable for any expense in the removal of any material required to be moved for inspection. 
(c)  The director can examine structures, sites, and records associated with an application. 
(d)  Studio inspection shall be performed at least twice annually. Each inspection will carry an inspection fee set by the board of health and approved by the city. 
(e)  The director can enter the structure or premises at reasonable times per this section. If such structure or premises is occupied, credentials shall be presented to the occupant and entry requested. If such structure or premises is unoccupied, the director shall first make a reasonable effort to locate the person having ownership or control and request entry. If entry is refused, the director shall have recourse to any remedy provided by law to secure entry. 
(f)  A copy of the most current inspection report shall be posted in an un-obscured manner in public view. The report shall be posted at five feet six inches, within 15 feet of the main door of the studio, and shall be approachable to within one foot. 
(g)  If an individual becomes aware of a body craft studio in violation of this Code, or other law, they may contact the director. The name, address, number, and other identifying information of the reporting individual will remain confidential, unless required to be disclosed by law. 
(h)  If an individual becomes aware of unlicensed performance of body crafting, they may contact the director. The name, address, number, and all other identifying information of the reporting individual will remain confidential, unless otherwise required to be disclosed by law. 
(Former § 6-008(13.)) 
Sec. 6-89. - Body crafting procedure. 
(a)  Body crafters shall comply with all standard precautions, as that term is defined in this section. 
(b)  Body crafters shall remove all jewelry prior to beginning any body craft procedure and secure their hair using a hat, cap, net, or holder prior to beginning a procedure. 
(c)  Prior to body crafting on each client, the body crafter shall ensure that his/her fingernails are closely trimmed and perform hand hygiene. This includes use of a CDC-approved method of hand decontamination (such as an alcohol brushless based system), washing the hands, or other means of hand hygiene through use of provided procedure room facilities per this section. 
(d)  Prior to the start of any craft procedure, the body crafter shall inspect his/her hands for hangnails, small cuts, sores, lesions, scabs and abrasions. If a cut, sore, lesion, or an abrasion is detected a bandage shall be applied for added protection before gloving. 
(e)  Single-use medical gloves shall be worn during the body crafting. They shall be donned so their integrity is not compromised. They shall be changed and properly disposed of each time there is an interruption in the procedure, the gloves become torn or punctured, or their integrity has been compromised so they pose a contamination risk. The body crafter shall perform hand hygiene before donning and after removing gloves. 
(f)  The body crafter shall adhere to standard precautions: eye protection, masks, disposable lap towels, smocks, aprons, and sleeve protectors shall be available and utilized as required by standard precautions as defined herein. 
(g)  Body crafters experiencing symptoms of illness, including diarrhea, vomiting, fever, rash, jaundice, or skin infections shall not perform any body crafting. 
(h)  To minimize exposure to infectious body fluids, solution used during procedures shall be sprayed onto a clean towel and applied to client or applied using a squeeze bottle. 
(i)  Only single-use razors shall be used to shave where the body crafting will be performed. 
(j)  All sharps shall be sterile at time of procedure and shall be visually inspected for integrity before and after use. If a sharp is not intact prior to use it shall be discarded. If a sharp is not intact or is not accounted for after use, the client shall be immediately notified and instructed to seek medical attention. This shall be noted in the client record. 
(k)  All fixed surfaces contaminated with blood shall be cleaned per OSHA blood-borne pathogens requirements, and then disinfected using an EPA-approved tuberculoidicidal disinfectant. 
(Former § 6-008(14.)) 
Sec. 6-90. - Tattoo preparation and care. 
(a)  Before placing the tattoo design, the body crafter shall treat the area with an antiseptic. 
(b)  If a paper stencil is used for transferring the design, the stencil shall be single-use disposable. 
(c)  If the design is drawn directly on the skin, it shall be applied with a single-use sterile instrument only. 
(d)  The completed tattoo shall be washed with a single-use towel saturated with antiseptic solution. 
(e)  After the area has dried, ensure that a layer of antiseptic is applied. 
(f)  After antiseptic, a bandage shall be applied using sealed, non-sticking absorbent pads. 
(g)  The client shall get written and oral instructions on how to care for the tattoo during healing. 
(Former § 6-008(15.)) 
Sec. 6-91. - Body piercing care procedures. 
(a)  Before piercing the skin, the body crafter shall apply an antiseptic solution to the skin. 
(b)  The client shall get written and oral instructions on how to care for the piercing during healing. 
(c)  A facility that limits its piercing to the lobe of the ear with pre-sterilized, single-use stud and clasp ear piercing systems shall be exempt from this section. Compliance with this exemption may be verified by inspection at the option of the director. 
(Former § 6-008(16.)) 
Sec. 6-92. - Sterilization. 
(a)  Instrument cleaning. 
(1)  All non-single-use instruments shall be sterilized after each use per manufacturer's recommendations. 
(2)  Employees shall wear heavy-duty, waterproof gloves while cleaning instruments. 
(3)  Used instruments shall be soaked in an enzymatic solution or cool water until cleaning can be performed. 
(4)  Instruments shall be disassembled for cleaning. 
(5)  All instrument components shall be cleaned, manually or in an ultrasonic cleaner, using the appropriate cleaning agent specific to the type of cleaning performed. 
(b)  Instrument packaging. 
(1)  Employees shall wear clean gloves while packaging or wrapping instruments. 
(2)  Instruments shall be wrapped or packaged with a sterilizer indicator on each package. 
(3)  All packages shall be labeled with time and date of sterilization. Packages shall no longer be considered sterile if the integrity of the package is damaged. 
(c)  Instrument sterilization. 
(1)  Except as provided in this subsection, all body craft studios shall utilize a sterilizer that shall be designed and labeled as a medical instrument sterilizer to achieve the sterilization definition. 
(2)  The operator's manual for the sterilizer shall be available on the premises at all times and the sterilizer shall be operated according to the manufacturer's recommendations. 
(3)  The sterilizer shall be cleaned and maintained per manufacturer's recommendations. 
(4)  A sterilizer load log shall be maintained per manufacturer's recommendations for the life of the facility and available for inspection by the director and clients. The log shall contain the following documentation for each load: 
a.  A description of instruments in the load; 
b.  Date of sterilization, and time if more than one load is processed in a day; 
c.  Manufacturer's recommended cycle data; 
d.  An indication of the proper sterilization of instruments, as indicated by the appropriate color change of the sterilizer indicator on each package. The indicator used shall be compatible with the sterilization process being used; 
e.  Any action taken when appropriate color indicator change did not occur; 
f.  Maintenance log, including: 
1.  Date of service; 
2.  Sterilizer model and serial number; 
3.  Sterilizer location; 
4.  Name of person requesting service; 
5.  Description of malfunctions; 
6.  Name of person performing maintenance; 
7.  Description of services and parts replaced; 
8.  Results of biologic validation and testing; 
9.  Signature and title of person acknowledging completed work. 
(d)  Sterilization monitoring. 
(1)  Sterilizer monitoring shall be at least monthly, unless the manufacturer specifies more frequent monitoring, or after 40 hours of use, whichever comes first, using a commercial biological monitoring (spore) system. 
(2)  All biological indicators shall be analyzed by a laboratory that operates under FDA guidelines and is independent of the body craft studio, with reports sent to the studio. 
(3)  Biological indicator test results shall be maintained on the premises for the life of the studio and must be available for inspection by the director at all times. 
(4)  Upon a positive microbiological monitoring report, the sterilizer shall be immediately checked for proper use and function and the studio shall cease use of the sterilizer immediately. Three consecutive passed biological tests must be achieved before the studio is reopened. The studio can obtain a properly functioning sterilizer to re-open. 
(e)  Instrument storage. 
(1)  Hands shall be washed and gloved prior to handling sterilized instruments. 
(2)  After sterilization, instruments shall be stored in a dry, clean area reserved for sterilized instruments. 
(Former § 6-008(17.)) 
Sec. 6-93. - Disinfection of the body craft studio. 
(a)  Each body craft studio shall be kept clean and sanitary. 
(b)  The owner shall develop and implement a written cleaning protocol that includes appropriate facility decontamination plus any daily tasks or procedures. This protocol shall be based on types of surfaces to be cleaned, the types of possible contamination, the tasks or procedures to be performed, and location within the studio. Adherence to the protocol must be documented weekly, to be appended to the maintenance log. All workers shall adhere to the protocol. This protocol shall he available for review by county or city employees or inspectors during normal operation hours and to the general public upon request. 
(c)  All work surfaces shall be disinfected with an EPA-approved disinfectant at the start of each work day, after completion of body crafting on each individual, and the end of each work day. 
(d)  All coverings, such as bather films, plastic wrap, and aluminum foil shall be single-use only. 
(e)  Reusable receptacles such as bins, pails, and cans that have the likelihood of becoming contaminated shall be decontaminated weekly with a current, EPA-approved disinfectant. When contamination is visible, receptacles shall be cleaned and decontaminated immediately. 
(Former § 6-008(18.)) 
Sec. 6-94. - Disposal of waste. 
(a)  Contaminated needles shall not be bent, broken or their structure otherwise compromised. 
(b)  Sharps waste shall be safely discarded in a rigid and puncture resistant waste container that is leak proof on the sides and bottom with a self-closing lid, labeled with the international biohazard symbol and the word "BIOHAZARD" prominently displayed. Sharps waste shall be handled per all applicable laws, rules and regulations regarding biohazardous waste. 
(c)  Biohazardous non-sharps waste shall be discarded in a biohazard bag. Waste shall be removed and disposed of in per all applicable laws, rules and regulations regarding biohazardous waste. 
(d)  Non-biohazardous disposable waste shall be placed in lined, easily cleanable containers with tight fitting lids to prevent leakage or spillage. 
(e)  Non-biohazardous disposable waste shall be handled, stored, and disposed of to minimize direct exposure of personnel to waste materials. 
(f)  Self-closing waste containers lined with plastic bags manufactured specifically for each waste container shall be in each procedure room and restroom and be emptied at least once a day into a commercial dumpster. This dumpster must be emptied by a commercial contractor at least once per week. 
(g)  All sewage, including liquid waste, shall be disposed of by a public sewage system or a sewage system constructed and operated per applicable provisions of this Code or state law. 
(Former § 6-008(19.)) 
Sec. 6-95. - Client records. 
(a)  The owner shall maintain a written detailed client record that describes the body crafting procedures administered to each client for a minimum of five years after the procedure. Client records shall be made available for inspection by the director within five days of request. 
(b)  The client record shall be created prior to any body craft procedure being performed and shall have the client's name and signature, address, proof of age, body craft procedure performed, date, design, its precise location on the body, and name of the body crafter(s) and other persons performing and assisting in the procedure. It shall also describe whether any complications or incidents arose and detail what action was taken to resolve the incident. A copy of the client's valid state issued driver's license or photo identification must be maintained in the record. 
(c)  Each client shall be provided and sign an informed consent statement that fully explains the procedure prior to any body crafting. This shall be maintained by the owner in the client record, with a copy given to the client. 
(d)  A "disclaimer of liability" form promulgated by the director shall be signed by the client prior to any body crafting procedure. The owner shall keep a copy in the client's record, with a copy to the client. 
(e)  The client record shall also contain a signed and dated statement by the client attesting that he or she is not under the influence of alcohol and/or drugs at the time of the body crafting. 
(f)  The client record shall contain a signed and dated statement by the client attesting that he or she has received, read, and understood a copy of an after-care procedures form. 
(g)  The client has the right to request and receive their entire client record. If the record is available on the premises of the body crafting facility the record shall be made available immediately upon request. If the record is not available on the premises, then the client's request for the client record must be fulfilled within five business days. 
(Former § 6-008(20.)) 
Sec. 6-96. - Body crafter requirements and permit. 
(a)  All persons performing body crafting shall only perform such in a validly permitted studio. 
(b)  All persons performing body crafting must first satisfy all of the following requirements: 
(1)  Current certification in emergency first aid, CPR, and blood-borne pathogen or infection control training, from agencies licensed by the state or federal authority. This is not required for body crafters who are licensed health care professionals; 
(2)  Reserved. 
(c)  All persons performing body crafting shall first apply for and obtain a permit from the director. 
(1)  The application shall be on forms provided by the director and shall not be considered accepted unless complete in all respects, including payment of any fees. Application fees shall be set by the board of health and approved by the city. 
(2)  The application shall include full legal name of the applicant, any aliases ever used, current home address and phone numbers and a copy of a valid driver's license or valid state-issued photo identification. 
(d)  Every owner must maintain on the premises an employee application for each body crafter, which shall immediately be available for inspection by the director, and shall include all of the following information pertaining to the body crafter: 
(1)  Copies of emergency first-aid, CPR, blood-borne pathogen or infection control certifications. 
(2)  Reserved. 
(e)  The studio permit must be obtained annually and expires 365 days from date of issuance. The permit shall at all times be conspicuously displayed in public view on the premises. 
(Former § 6-008(21.)) 
Sec. 6-97. - Violations. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person or entity to violate any this section or this Code. 
(b)  No one can perform body crafting unless employed by a body crafting studio, with a current body crafter permit. No one can perform body craft outside of a permitted body craft studio. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful to be under the influence of any alcohol and/or drugs while body crafting. 
(d)  The owner of a body craft studio is responsible for any act, omission or violation by any body crafter working on his premises, or performing body crafting as an independent contractor. 
(Former § 6-008(22.)) 
Sec. 6-98. - Body crafting and tattooing of certain persons prohibited. 
(a)  No person shall perform body crafting on anyone under 18, except piercing of the ear lobe in the presence of a documented parent or legal guardian with government issued identification. 
(b)  No person shall perform body crafting on an individual who is, or reasonably appears to be, under the influence of alcohol or drugs or is of unsound mind or body. 
(Former § 6-008(23.)) 
Sec. 6-99. - Enforcement and penalties. 
(a)  This section shall apply to all matters related to body crafting and body craft studios in Social Circle. Where different sections specify different materials, methods of construction, or other requirements, the most restrictive requirement shall govern. Where there is a conflict between a general and a specific requirement, the specific requirement shall govern. 
(b)  The board of health, its officers, agents, and employees are responsible for the administration and enforcement of this section. 
(c)  Any person who violates this section shall upon conviction be subject to a fine and/or imprisonment per this Code. Where any offense continues from day to day, each day's continuance thereof shall be deemed a separate offense. 
(Former § 6-008(24.)) 
Secs. 6-100-6-125. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - FIRE STANDARDS[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) ---

Sec. 6-126. - State minimum fire standards; adoption of model codes.

(b)  The city has also adopted by separate ordinance the international codes including the International Building Code, International Fuel Gas Code, the International Mechanical Code, the International Fire Code, International Existing Building Code, International Property Maintenance Code and Life Safety Code (herein "model codes"). Complete copies of the model codes set forth in subsections (a) and (b) of this section are on file at the Social Circle Fire Department Office, 165 East Hightower Trail Social Circle, Georgia 30025. [2] 
(c)  Notwithstanding any other provisions of law or any local ordinance to the contrary, in the event of a conflict between the state rule and regulations and any other adopted by reference herein, the provisions of the state rules and regulations shall prevail. Subject to the forgoing, in the event of any conflict between any specific code or standard, the following shall act as the guide:
