The animal control unit shall enforce this article and the operation of the county shelter, which also house animals from the city. 
(Former § 9-002-2) 
Sec. 9-53. - Duty of owner to keep animals under control. 
    It shall be unlawful for the owner of any domesticated animal, or anyone having a domesticated animal in his possession or control, to permit such domesticated animal to be at large. If the owner or keeper of any animal is a minor, the parent or guardian of such minor shall be responsible to ensure that all provisions of this article are complied with. 
(Former § 9-002-3) 
Sec. 9-54. - Duty to keep animals under restraint while on owner's property. 
    It shall be the duty of every animal owner or custodian to ensure such animals are kept under proper restraint and reasonable care and precautions are taken to prevent the animal from leaving, while unattended, the property of its owner. 
(Former § 9-002-4) 
Sec. 9-55. - Duty to keep animals under restraint while off owner's property. 
(a)  It shall be the duty of the animal owner or anyone having an animal in their possession to keep the animal under restraint and control at all times while the animal is off the real property limits of the owner, possessor or custodian. For the purpose of this section, an animal shall be deemed under control when off the owner's property when: 
(1)  The animal is in a vehicle, parked or in motion; 
(2)  The animal is properly confined within a secured enclosure with the property owner's permission; 
(3)  The animal is securely restrained by a leash or other method held by a competent person; or 
(4)  The animal is under immediate voice command of a competent person at all times. 
(b)  Hunting dogs shall be deemed under control for the purpose of this section when they are in a hunting role per state game and fish department laws, rules, and regulations. 
(Former § 9-002-5) 
Sec. 9-56. - Enforcement. 
(a)  Primary enforcement responsibility. The primary responsibility for enforcement of this article shall be vested in the animal control unit. 
(1)  The animal control unit shall consist of animal control officers, the number and identity of which shall be designated by the board of commissioners and deemed approved by the city mayor and council. 
(2)  These officers shall be vested with the authority to issue citations for violation of this article. 
(3)  The officers comprising the animal control unit may also call upon any law enforcement officer as may be necessary for the enforcement of this article. 
(b)  Issuance of citations. Upon information known to any officer or member of the animal control unit, or the county sheriff's department or city police department, that anyone is in violation of this article, a citation may be issued requiring the owner or possessor of such domesticated animal to appear before the judge of the municipal court on a day and time certain to stand trial for the violation of this article. 
(c)  Right of officer to defend himself in performance of duty. In the performance of his duties per this article, any animal control officer or any law enforcement officer assisting in enforcing this article may use such force as is necessary to defend themselves from attack by an animal; provided, however, that reasonable efforts shall be made to impound an attacking animal without undue harm, injury or danger to the animal, the officer, or to any other persons and property. 
(d)  Right of entry. Any animal control officer or other authorized officer is authorized to enter any property for investigating alleged violations of this article, or to seize and impound any animal found in violation of this article. The animal control unit may use any appropriate means necessary to remove an animal in distress locked in a closed vehicle. 
(e)  Testimony of witnesses. If a violation of this article has not been witnessed by an officer of the animal control unit, the sheriff's department or city police or other employee of the city or county, a subpoena shall issue to the person possessing evidence of a violation requiring such person to appear on the day and time set to testify. 
(f)  Impoundment of animals. Animals in any of the following classes may be impounded by the animal control unit: 
(1)  Animals at large in violation of this article; 
(2)  Animals that have been abandoned; 
(3)  Animals subjected to inhumane treatment in violation of section 9-69; 
(4)  Animals which have bitten a person or animal or which have been bitten by an animal suspected of having rabies; 
(5)  Animals not wearing current vaccination tags; 
(6)  Animals suspected of having rabies; and 
(7)  Unconfined dogs in quarantine areas. 
(Former § 9-002-6) 
Sec. 9-57. - Disposition of impounded animals. 
(a)  Notice of impoundment. The animal control unit shall immediately notify the owner of each domesticated animal impounded if the owner of the domesticated animal is known or can be reasonably ascertained. 
(b)  Mandatory minimum holding period. The animal control unit shall house and care for any impounded domestic animals for 72 hours if the owner is unknown and the animal is untagged; or ten days if the animal is properly tagged or chipped with the current owner's information and the owner can be properly notified. 
(c)  Reclaiming animal; fees. The owner of any impounded domesticated animal may, within the holding period, reclaim such animal by payment of the impoundment fee and daily board rate established from time to time by the board of commissioners (which is deemed approved by the mayor and council). It shall be in the discretion of the animal control unit whether to allow an owner to claim an animal or make application for adoption if the mandatory minimum holding period has expired. If no proof of current rabies inoculation can be shown at the time of the animal's release, the owner shall pay the necessary fees to have the animal properly inoculated and tagged, in addition to any other fees due. 
(d)  Animal adoption. The animal control unit may release for adoption any animal unredeemed or unclaimed after the mandatory minimum holding period, following the adoption procedure outlined in section 9-68. Any person adopting an animal shall pay the required adoption fees and any other such fees deemed necessary. 
(e)  Treatment or euthanization of diseased or injured animal not bearing proper identification. If an animal not properly tagged or chipped is impounded by the animal control unit and shows evidence of contagious, infectious or fatal diseases, is seriously ill or severely injured, the animal control officer shall confer with the animal control director or his designee to determine a just reason for euthanasia or may have the animal evaluated by a licensed veterinarian. 
(f)  Treatment or euthanization of diseased or injured animals bearing proper identification. If any properly tagged or chipped animal is impounded by the animal control unit and shows evidence of contagious, infectious or fatal diseases, is seriously ill or severely injured, such animal will be evaluated and the advice of a licensed veterinarian sought to determine whether to treat the animal or euthanize. In the absence of available veterinarian the animal control officer will confer with supervisor on duty to determine a just reason for euthanasia. 
(g)  Veterinary expenses. All veterinary expenses incurred shall be charged to the owner of such animal. 
(h)  Destroying animals. Any animal which is suffering excessively or which exhibits feral or wild tendencies or may present a perceived danger to persons, animal control personnel, or other animals may be, without regard to the mandatory minimum holding period, destroyed by the most humane method available. 
(Former § 9-002-7) 
Sec. 9-58. - Public nuisance animal. 
    It shall be unlawful for an owner to allow an animal to be a public nuisance. An animal will be deemed a public nuisance if: 
(1)  It is repeatedly found at large. 
(2)  It damages the property of someone other than the owner. 
(3)  It aggressively chases, attacks or bites a person while off the property of the owner. 
(4)  It produces, because of quantity, manner or method in which animals are kept, unsanitary conditions. 
(5)  The owner of a dog or cat fails to remove feces deposited upon public property or the property of another. This shall not apply to hoofed animals or livestock. 
(6)  A dog continuously makes excessive noises: continuous howling, barking or crying or causing unreasonable annoyance continuously for one-half hour or more. For the purposes of this section, the dog must be within 200 feet of the property line of the complaining party. 
(7)  An in-heat female dog or cat is tethered outdoors or allowed to be at large thereby attracting males of the same species. 
(Former § 9-002-8) 
Sec. 9-59. - Abandoned animals. 
    It shall be unlawful to abandon or permit such abandonment of or aid in abandonment of any domesticated animal. 
(Former § 9-002-9) 
Sec. 9-60. - Biting dogs, cats, and exotic animals, wildlife, rehabilitated wildlife kept as pets. 
(a)  Confinement. All domesticated animals, vaccinated or not, known to have bitten a person causing an injury that bleeds, shall be confined for ten days for observation for rabies. 
(b)  Destruction and analysis of animals suspected of rabies. For all such animals, or by consent of owner of a dog or cat, the animal shall be destroyed immediately, decapitated and its brain tissue analyzed for indications of rabies, if it has bitten a human or another animal. 
(c)  Destruction of unvaccinated dogs or animals. A dog or other animal which has not been vaccinated or which has been vaccinated less than one month prior to being bitten by a known rabid animal, shall be immediately destroyed. 
(d)  Confinement of animal in isolation. If the owner is unwilling to destroy such animal, it shall be confined in strict isolation in a location approved by the animal control officer for six months. 
(e)  Vaccination of confined animal. The confined animal must be vaccinated five months after the bite. 
(f)  Revaccination and confinement. Any dog or other animal for which rabies vaccination effectiveness has been established and having current vaccination at least one month prior to being bitten by a known rabid animal may be revaccinated and then confined in a manner approved by the animal control officer for 30 days; thereafter, it shall be released to the owner if the animal exhibits no signs (clinical) of rabies as adjudged by a veterinarian. 
(Former § 9-002-10) 
Sec. 9-61. - Establishment of infected area quarantine. 
    Whenever the department of human resources may declare the county or city or any area therein an "infected area" per O.C.G.A. § 31-19-2, then every dog in such infected area shall be quarantined and confined to the owner's or custodian's premises during the entire period of time for which such declaration to the department of human resources is in effect. 
(Former § 9-002-11) 
Sec. 9-62. - Confinement area of facility. 
(a)  Place of confinement. Confinement area or facility to which an animal is confined in compliance with this section shall be an animal shelter, kennel, animal hospital or such other place designated by the animal control officer. 
(b)  Requirements for confinement facility. Unless otherwise authorized by the animal control officer, unvaccinated biting animals and animals to be confined per section 9-60 shall be confined in an animal shelter, kennel or animal hospital at the owner's expense. Such facility shall provide for the following: 
(1)  Construction and management which will keep the animal dry and clean, prevent its escape and prevent its contact with people and other animals. 
(2)  A method and procedure for identification of the animal and recording of date of its admission to the area or facility. 
(3)  Assurance the animal will have adequate water and food. 
(4)  Adequate space for the animal's exercise. 
(5)  Protection against excessive heat and cold. 
(6)  Space, cages, pens and other necessary equipment to isolate the animal for its protection against injury and infectious diseases. 
(Former § 9-002-12) 
Sec. 9-63. - Vaccination of dogs and cats. 
(a)  Vaccination required. The owner of a dog or cat four months of age or older shall cause such dog or cat to be vaccinated against rabies as defined by this section. 
(b)  Revaccination. If such dog or cat is less than one year of age upon vaccination it shall be revaccinated within one year of the original vaccination. 
(c)  Vaccination periods. When dogs or cats one year of age or older are vaccinated with a vaccine approved by the department of human resources as providing three-year protection, such animals shall be revaccinated within three years. When other approved vaccines are used, yearly inoculations shall be required. 
(d)  Vaccination by owner. Vaccination by an owner, unless such owner is a licensed veterinarian, shall not be recognized. 
(e)  Revaccination of dogs or cats brought into county. The owner of a dog or cat brought into the county for a permanent stay from outside the county shall cause such dog or cat to be revaccinated in accordance with this section. 
(f)  Certificate of vaccination for evidence of comparable procedures. When the owner of such dog or cat produces evidence satisfactory to the animal control officer that such dog or cat has been vaccinated compliant with this section, then a county certificate of vaccination may be issued in lieu of revaccination. 
(g)  Vaccination by licensed veterinarian. No person shall vaccinate dogs and cats against rabies who is not licensed to practice veterinary medicine in the state. 
(h)  Temporary stay requirements for dogs. Any dog brought into the county for a temporary stay not exceeding 14 days shall be confined or on a leash at all times unless it has a current vaccination for rabies in its home jurisdiction. 
(Former § 9-002-13) 
Sec. 9-64. - Certificate of vaccination. 
(a)  Issuance of certificates of vaccination and vaccination tags. Any veterinarian is authorized and required in connection with his practice to issue certificates of vaccination and vaccination tags. 
(b)  Evidence of vaccination. Evidence of vaccination shall consist of a certification of vaccination and vaccination tag. 
(c)  Preparation of certificate. The certificate, with each item answered, shall be prepared in triplicate and signed by the veterinarian administering the vaccine. 
(d)  Disposition of copies. The veterinarian shall furnish one copy to the owner, one to the rabies control officer and retain one. 
(e)  Maintenance of records. The certificates of vaccination furnished to the rabies control officer by the veterinarian shall be maintained by the rabies control officer in an orderly, indexed file until expired. 
(Former § 9-002-14) 
Sec. 9-65. - Vaccination tags and collars. 
(a)  Issuance. Coincident with the issuance of the certificates of vaccination, the veterinarian shall furnish the owner of the dog or cat a serially numbered tag bearing the same number and year as the certificate. 
(b)  Vaccination tag to be worn. Every dog and cat at all times shall wear on its collar/harness a current vaccination tag. 
(c)  Unlawful removal. It shall be unlawful for any person to attach a vaccination tag to the collar of any animal for which it was not issued, or to remove such tag from any animal. 
(Former § 9-002-15) 
Sec. 9-66. - Adoption. 
(a)  When animals to be offered for adoption. The animal control unit or its agent may offer for adoption any animal unredeemed or un-reclaimed after the mandatory minimum holding period defined in section 9-57. 
(b)  Immediate availability. If the animal is surrendered to animal control unit by its owner, it may be offered immediately. 
(c)  Age requirement. All persons adopting animals must be over 18 and shall provide proper and humane care, feeding, sheltering, and protection from weather, and veterinary treatment as required. 
(d)  Spay and neutering. All persons adopting a fertile dog or cat shall cause it to be spayed/neutered within 30 days of adoption in the case of an adult, or within 30 days of sexual maturity in the case of an immature animal. 
(e)  Use of adopted animal for research prohibited. A person adopting an animal shall not permit it to be used for research. 
(f)  Restrictions on frequency of adoption. The frequency with which a person may adopt animals may be restricted. 
(g)  Refusal of adoption. The animal control unit or its designee may refuse adoption to a person that does not meet specified requirements. 
(h)  Adoption fees. Adoption fees are set by the board of commissioners (deemed approved by the mayor and council) and may include all or part of the costs of examination and rabies inoculation and spaying or neutering. 
(Former § 9-002-16) 
Sec. 9-67. - Discretion. 
    Any animal control officer may at his or her discretion not impound a dog or other animal found in violation of this section but may instead return the animal to its rightful owner. 
(Former § 9-002-17) 
Sec. 9-68. - Interference with an animal control officer. 
    It shall be unlawful to interfere with the investigation or duties of any animal control officer or officer empowered to act by law, or to take or attempt to take an animal from a vehicle used to transport such animal or from the animal control shelter or impounding area, or to otherwise seek to release any animal from the custody of the animal control unit. 
(Former § 9-002-18) 
Sec. 9-69. - Humane treatment of animals. 
(a)  Provision of food, water and shelter. No one shall fail to provide an animal adequate food, water, shelter, and adequate protection from the elements. Adequate veterinary care shall also be provided to prevent suffering. Animals shall be treated with humane care at all times. 
(b)  Inhumane treatment prohibited. No one shall beat, ill-treat, torment, overload, overwork, or abuse an animal, or cause, instigate, or permit combat between animals. 
(c)  Exposure to poisonous substances. No person shall expose any poisonous substance, mixed with food or not, so that the poisonous substance shall be likely to be eaten by any domesticated animal. 
(d)  Exposure to unsanitary conditions. No person shall expose an animal to unsanitary conditions by depositing or failing to remove feces, waste or trash from the animal's immediate living area or area of confinement. 
(e)  Improper tethering. Any owner who shall cause an animal to be tethered shall do so by the use of a proper collar, harness or other acceptable restraint; by a chain or cable of adequate strength, weight and length consistent with the size and strength of the tethered animal and free from obstructions allowing the animal to access adequate food, water, and shelter. It shall be unlawful to tether an animal under the following circumstances: 
(1)  On vacant or uninhabited property without daily adequate food, water, shelter and veterinary care; 
(2)  During any declared weather advisories, warnings, or emergencies; 
(3)  In a manner that prevents the animal from lying, sitting, or standing comfortably, without the restraint becoming taut; 
(4)  In a manner that allows the animal to become entangled on the restraint or another object; 
(5)  In a manner that restricts the animal's access to adequate food, water, or shelter; or 
(6)  In a manner that causes injury to the animal. 
(Former § 9-002-19) 
Sec. 9-70. - Liability of county, officers and employees. 
    The county, the city, the animal control unit and its officers shall not be responsible or liable for any accidents, diseases, injuries or deaths to any animal while impounded or boarded at the animal shelter. Furthermore, the county, the city, the animal control unit and its officers shall not be responsible or liable for the health, welfare or actions of an animal after its adoption. 
(Former § 9-002-20) 
Sec. 9-71. - Violations. 
    Any person who shall violate any provision of this article, as this article exists or as it may hereafter be amended, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and subject to the jurisdiction of the municipal court and, upon conviction, shall be punished as provided in section 1-5. 
(Former § 9-002-21) 
Sec. 9-72. - Chickens as domesticated animals. 
(a)  Definition. 
    Chickens are included within the definition of "domesticated animals" within section 9-51. "Chickens" are also included within the definition of "household pets" in the zoning code of the city. The keeping of chickens, as a part of the category of household pets, is allowed within the following zoning districts: AG, AG-2, R-25, R-15, and RMD in accordance with the following provisions: 
(1)  Chickens are only permitted as pets or for egg-laying production; chickens cannot be kept for slaughter. 
(2)  Chickens, chicken products, and/or by-products shall not be sold on the property. 
(3)  No person shall fail to prevent his or her animals from straying from the property of the owner, or going upon the property of any other person, or upon any public rights-of-way. 
(4)  Roosters, any male chickens, and any other crowing chickens are prohibited. 
(5)  Guinea hens, peacocks, and geese are prohibited. 
(6)  No chickens shall be kept on a lot of less than 8,700 square feet. 
(7)  Three pet chickens are allowed on a lot sized 8,700 square feet or more. 
(8)  Six pet chickens are allowed on a lot sized 15,000 square feet or more. 
(9)  Nine pet chickens are allowed on a lot sized 25,000 square feet or more. 
(10)  Twelve pet chickens are allowed on a lot sized one acre or more. 
(b)  Housing requirements. 
(1)  Chickens must be kept securely in an enclosed yard or pen at all times. 
(2)  Any structure housing chickens must be located in the rear yard. 
(3)  All such houses, pens, or enclosures, shall have a minimum floor space of four square feet per bird over four months old. 
(c)  Sanitary requirements. 
(1)  Chickens must be kept under sanitary conditions and the enclosure they are kept in must not be allowed to become filthy or unsanitary. 
(2)  All places where chickens are kept shall have adequate drainage sufficient to prevent standing water in yards or pens. 
(3)  All places where chickens are kept shall remove all manure from such containers before the same shall become malodorous or unsanitary. 
(4)  All places where chickens are kept shall be kept free from vermin. 
(5)  Feed must be stores in a fully, enclosed, vermin-proof container. 
(Ord. No. 2017-9, § 4, 5-16-2017) 
Secs. 9-73-9-100. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - DANGEROUS DOGS[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Responsible Dog Ownership Law, O.C.G.A. §§ 4-8-20 et seq. 

Sec. 9-101. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Animal shelter shall have the same meaning as in O.C.G.A. § 4-14-2. 
    Classified dog means any dog that has been classified as a dangerous dog or a vicious dog per this article. 
    Dangerous dog means any dog that: 
(1)  Causes a substantial puncture of a person's skin by teeth without causing serious injury; provided, however, that a nip, scratch, or abrasion shall not be sufficient to classify a dog as dangerous under this subparagraph; 
(2)  Aggressively attacks in a manner that causes a person to reasonably believe the dog posed an imminent threat of serious injury to such person or another person although no injury occurs; provided, however, that barking, growling, or showing of teeth by a dog shall not be sufficient to classify a dog as dangerous under this subparagraph; or 
(3)  While off the owner's property, kills a pet; provided, however, that this subparagraph shall not apply where the death of such pet is caused by a dog that is working or training as a hunting dog, herding dog, or predator control dog. 
    Mail means to send by certified mail or statutory overnight delivery to the recipient's last known address. 
    Probate court means the Walton County Probate Court, with whom Social Circle has a contract. 
    Owner means any natural person or any legal entity owning, possessing, harboring, keeping, or having custody or control of a dog. If a dog owned by a minor, "owner" includes the parents or person in loco parentis with custody of the minor. 
    Serious injury means any physical injury that creates a substantial risk of death, or results in death, broken or dislocated bones, lacerations requiring multiple sutures, or disfiguring avulsions; requires plastic surgery or admission to a hospital; or results in protracted impairment of health, including transmission of an infection or contagious disease, or impairment of function of any organ. 
    Superior court means the Superior Court of Walton County, Georgia. 
    Vicious dog means a dog that inflicts serious injury on a person or causes serious injury to a person resulting from reasonable attempts to escape from the dog's attack. 
(Former § 9-002-51) 
Sec. 9-102. - Exceptions to definitions. 
    The terms "dangerous dog" and "vicious dog" as defined in this article, shall not include: 
(1)  A dog in the act of use by a law enforcement or military officer to carry out the officer's official duties. 
(2)  A dog that inflicts an injury on a person who, at the time, was committing a willful trespass or other tort, or was tormenting, abusing, or assaulting the dog or had in the past been observed or reported to have tormented, abused, or assaulted the dog or was committing or attempting to commit a crime, under O.C.G.A. tit. 16, § 5. 
(Former § 9-002-52) 
Sec. 9-103. - Applicability of provisions. 
    Any dog classified prior to July 1, 2012 as a potentially dangerous dog in this state is now classified as a dangerous dog under this article. Any dog classified prior to July 1, 2012 as a dangerous dog or vicious dog in this state is now classified as a vicious dog. The owner of any dog referred to in this section shall come into compliance with all current provisions of this article immediately. 
(Former § 9-002-53) 
Sec. 9-104. - Animal control officer. 
    The director and personnel of the animal control unit created by section 9-52 shall serve as animal control officers for the county and city and shall be charged with enforcing this article. An animal control officer is authorized to make whatever inquiry is deemed necessary to ensure compliance with the provisions of this article. 
(Former § 9-002-54) 
Sec. 9-105. - Liability of county and city. 
    Per state law, under no circumstances shall the county or city or any employee or official of either be liable for any damages to any person who suffers an injury inflicted by a dog as a result of a failure to enforce the provisions of this article. 
(Former § 9-002-55) 
Sec. 9-106. - Procedures for classifying vicious dogs and dangerous dogs; notice; hearing. 
(a)  Duty to investigate. Upon receiving a report of a dog believed to be subject to classification as a dangerous or vicious dog within the animal control officer's jurisdiction, the animal control officer shall make such investigations as necessary to determine whether such dog is subject to classification as a dangerous or vicious dog. 
(b)  Impoundment. If the animal control officer believes that a dog subject to classification as a dangerous or vicious dog poses a threat to public safety, the dog may be immediately impounded and the owner shall be responsible for all costs from such impoundment. At the discretion of the animal control officer, the dog may be held at an approved veterinary or boarding facility at the owner's expense. Any impounded dog may be held until the requirements for possessing a classified dog as contained in section 9-107 are met or until a hearing in probate court per subsection (d) of this section results in a decision that no classification is warranted. Notwithstanding the foregoing, if the animal control officer states his or her intention to pursue a civil action in superior court to request euthanasia of the dog per subsection (g) of this section within ten days of mailing the notice provided for in subsection (c) of this section, the dog may be held at the owner's expense through the final adjudication of said civil action. 
(c)  Notice. When the animal control officer determines a dog is subject to classification as a dangerous or vicious dog, the animal control officer shall mail a dated notice to the dog's owner within 72 hours. Such notice shall include a summary of the animal control officer's determination and state that the owner has a right to a hearing before the probate court on the animal control officer's determination within seven days after the date shown on the notice. The notice shall provide a form for requesting the hearing and state that if a hearing is not requested within the allotted time, the animal control officer's determination shall become effective for all purposes under this article. If an owner cannot be located within ten days of an animal control officer's determination that a dog is subject to classification as a dangerous or vicious dog, such dog may be released to an animal shelter or humanely euthanized, as determined by the animal control officer. 
(d)  Hearing. When a hearing is requested by an owner per subsection (c) of this section, such shall be scheduled within 30 days after the request is received; provided, however, such hearing may be continued by the probate court for good cause. At least ten days prior to the hearing, the probate court shall mail to the owner written notice of the date, time, and place of the hearing. At the hearing, the owner may testify and present evidence and the probate court shall receive other evidence and testimony as reasonably necessary to sustain, modify, or overrule the animal control officer's determination. 
(e)  Notice of determination by probate court. Within ten days after the hearing, the probate court shall mail written notice to the owner of its determination on the matter. If such determination is that the dog is a dangerous or vicious dog, the notice of classification shall specify the date that determination shall be effective. If the determination is that the dog is to be euthanized pursuant to subsection (h), the notice shall specify the date by which the euthanasia shall occur. 
(f)  Judicial review. Review of the probate court's final decision shall be per O.C.G.A. § 5-3-2 and costs shall be paid per O.C.G.A. § 5-3-22. 
(g)  The superior court may order the euthanasia of a dog upon finding, after notice and opportunity for a hearing as provided by this article, that 1) the dog has seriously injured a human, or 2) presents a danger to humans not suitable for control under this article and the owner or custodian of the dog has been convicted of a violation of any state criminal law and the crime was related to such dog or any local government authority has filed with the court a civil action requesting euthanasia of the dog. 
(h)  A dog that is found, after notice and opportunity for a hearing as provided by this article, to have caused a serious injury to a human on more than one occasion shall be euthanized; provided, however, that no injury occurring before July 1, 2012, shall count for purposes of this subsection. 
(Former § 9-002-56) 
Sec. 9-107. - Requirements for possessing a classified dog. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for an owner to have or possess in the city a classified dog without a certificate of registration issued in accordance with the provisions of this article. Certificates of registration shall be nontransferable and shall only be issued to a person 18 years of age or older. No more than one certificate of registration shall be issued per domicile. 
(b)  Except as otherwise provided in this article, a certificate of registration for a dangerous dog shall be issued only if the animal control officer determines the following requirements have been met: 
(1)  The owner has maintained an enclosure that securely confines the dog on the owner's property indoors, or in a securely locked and enclosed pen, fence, or structure that prevents the dog from leaving such property; 
(2)  Clearly visible warning signs have been posted at all entrances to the premises where the dog resides; 
(3)  A microchip containing an identification number and capable of being scanned has been injected under the skin between the shoulder blades of the dog; and 
(4)  The dog has been sterilized. 
(c)  Except as otherwise provided in this article, a certificate of registration for a vicious dog shall be issued only if the animal control officer determines the following requirements have been met: 
(1)  The owner has maintained an enclosure that securely confines the dog on the owner's property indoors, or in a securely locked and enclosed double-walled pen, fence, or structure that prevents the dog from leaving such property. 
(2)  Clearly visible warning signs have been posted at all entrances to the premises where the dog resides; 
(3)  A microchip containing an identification number and capable of being scanned has been injected under the skin between the shoulder blades of the dog; 
(4)  The dog has been sterilized; and 
(5)  The owner maintains and can provide proof of liability insurance of at least $50,000.00 issued by an insurer authorized to transact business in this state insuring the owner of the dog against liability for any bodily injury or property damage caused by the dog. 
(d)  No certificate of registration shall be issued to any person who has been convicted of two or more violations of this article. 
(e)  No person shall be the owner of more than one vicious dog. 
(f)  No certificate of registration for a vicious dog shall be issued to any person convicted of: 
(1)  A serious violent felony as defined in O.C.G.A. § 17-10-6.1; 
(2)  The felony of dog fighting as provided for in O.C.G.A. § 16-12-37 or the felony of aggravated cruelty to animals as provided for in O.C.G.A. § 16-12-4; or 
(3)  A felony involving trafficking in cocaine, illegal drugs, marijuana, methamphetamine, or ecstasy per O.C.G.A. §§ 16-13-31 and 16-13-31.1 from conviction until two years after completion of sentence, nor to any person residing with such person. 
(g)  An annual fee, which may be set from time to time in an amount deemed reasonable by the board of commissioners (deemed approved by the mayor and council), in addition to any regular dog licensing fees, shall be paid to register classified dogs as required by this article. Certificates of registration shall be renewed annually, and payment of the annual fee shall be paid at the time the certificate of registration is issued. At the time of renewal of registration for a classified dog, an animal control officer shall require proof from the owner or make such investigation as necessary to verify continued compliance with all provisions of this section. Failure to renew a certificate of registration within ten days of the renewal date shall constitute a violation. 
(h)  The owner of a classified dog shall notify the animal control officer within 24 hours if the dog is on the loose or has attacked a human and shall notify the animal control officer within 24 hours if the dog has died or been euthanized. 
(i)  A vicious dog shall not be transferred, sold, or donated to any other person except it may be relinquished for euthanasia to a government facility or veterinarian. 
(j)  The owner of a classified dog shall notify the animal control officer if the owner moves out of the city no later than ten days after such move. The owner of a classified dog who moves to the city from another jurisdiction in Georgia shall register the classified dog within ten days of becoming a resident and notify the animal control officer of the jurisdiction from which it moved. The owner of a similarly classified dog who moves into this state shall register the dog as required within 30 days of becoming a resident. 
(Former § 9-002-57) 
Sec. 9-108. - Unlawful acts by owner of a classified dog. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for an owner of a dangerous dog to permit the dog to be outside an enclosure that securely confines the dangerous dog while on the owner's property or outside a securely locked and enclosed pen, fence, or structure suitable to prevent the dangerous dog from leaving such property unless: 
(1)  The dog is restrained by a leash not to exceed six feet and is under the immediate physical control of a person capable of preventing the dog from engaging any other human or animal when necessary; 
(2)  The dog is contained in a closed and locked cage or crate; or 
(3)  The dog is working or training as a hunting dog, herding dog, or predator control dog. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for an owner of a vicious dog to permit the dog to be: 
(1)  Outside an enclosure designed to securely confine the vicious dog while on the owner's property or outside a securely locked and enclosed double-walled pen, fence, or structure suitable to prevent the vicious dog from leaving such property unless: 
a.  The dog is muzzled and restrained by a leash not to exceed six feet and is under the immediate physical control of a person capable of preventing the dog from engaging any other human or animal when necessary, or 
b.  The dog is contained in a closed and locked cage or crate. 
(2)  Unattended with minors. 
(Former § 9-002-58) 
Sec. 9-109. - Confiscation of classified dogs for noncompliance. 
(a)  A dangerous or vicious dog shall be immediately confiscated by any animal control officer or by a law enforcement officer in the case of any violation. A refusal to surrender a dog subject to confiscation shall be a violation of this article. 
(b)  The owner of any dog that has been confiscated per this article may recover such dog on payment of all reasonable confiscation and housing costs and proof of compliance with the provisions of this article, unless such confiscation is deemed in error by an animal control officer or the probate court. All fines and all charges for services performed by a law enforcement or animal control officer shall be paid prior to owner recovery of the dog. Criminal prosecution shall not be stayed due to owner recovery or euthanasia of the dog. 
(c)  If the owner has not complied with this article within 14 days of the date the dog was confiscated, such dog shall be released to an animal shelter, as defined in O.C.G.A. § 4-14-2, or euthanized in an expeditious and humane manner. The owner shall pay the costs of housing and euthanasia. 
(Former § 9-002-59) 
Sec. 9-110. - Violations; penalties. 
(a)  The owner of a classified dog who violates this article may be prosecuted under O.C.G.A. § 4-8-29(c) and, upon conviction, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor of high and aggravated nature. 
(b)  An owner with a previous conviction for violation of this article whose classified dog causes serious injury to a human under circumstances constituting another violation of this article may be prosecuted for a felony under O.C.G.A. § 4-8-29(d) and, upon conviction, shall be punished by imprisonment for one to ten years, a fine not less than $5,000.00 nor more than $10,000.00, or both. In addition, the classified dog shall be euthanized at the cost of the owner. 
(c)  Any irregularity in classification proceedings shall not be a defense to a prosecution under this article if the owner received actual notice of the classification and did not pursue a civil remedy for the correction of the irregularity. 
(Former § 9-002-60) 
Sec. 9-111. - Confinement. 
    Choke collar or pinch collars shall not be used. 
(1)  All owners shall confine dogs within an adequate fence or enclosure or in a house, garage or other building, or shall securely confine with a chain, cable or leash at least ten feet long, with a swivel at both ends to prevent entanglement, attached to a trolley system four feet to seven feet above ground level and no less than 30 feet long. 
(2)  It shall be unlawful for any owner of a dog to chain, tie, fasten or otherwise tether the dog to dog houses, trees, fences, vehicles or other stationary objects as a means of confinement, except while the dog is being temporarily confined in the immediate visual outdoor presence of its owner. 
(Former § 9-002-61) 
Secs. 9-112-9-125. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - NOISE REGULATIONS 

Sec. 9-126. - Purpose. 
    The purpose of this section is to prevent certain loud or excessive noises, which are plainly audible from a distance of 100 feet and detrimental or annoying to the public. This section shall not prohibit supervised shoots under the Georgia DNR supervision on DNR property. 
(Former § 9-007(1.)) 
Sec. 9-127. - Sound amplifying devices regulated. 
    Except as contemplated under chapter 12, article II, it shall be unlawful for any person within the city who has not first obtained a permit from the city manager to speak through any horn, megaphone, sound box or amplifier or play any phonograph, radio or other mechanical or electrical device where the sound is amplified, where the sound is plainly audible from a distance of 100 feet, between 10:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m., and is detrimental or annoying to the public. 
    Exceptions. The paragraph above shall not restrict the playing of radios or musical instruments for the amusement, instruction or education of himself, members of his family or guests, within the limitations set forth in section 9-130 below, and as long as the sound is not plainly audible from a distance of 100 feet and detrimental or annoying to the public. Nor shall said paragraph restrict noises made by participants in a parade for which a permit has been obtained pursuant to chapter 12, article II of this Code. 
(Former § 9-007(2.)) 
Sec. 9-128. - Motor vehicles. 
    No person shall slow a road tractor, dump truck, fuel truck, garbage truck, or other truck over 10,000 pounds gross vehicle weight rating by downshifting. The brakes shall be used. It shall be unlawful for any person to operate a motor vehicle within the limits of the city of without a proper muffler, in good working order and in constant operation, to prevent excessive or unusual noise. No person shall use a muffler cutout, bypass or similar device for noise making. This shall not, however, apply to farm tractors. 
(Former § 9-007(3.)) 
Sec. 9-129. - Noise from automotive shops regulated. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to perform or permit to be performed maintenance or repairs on automobiles, motorcycles or other motor vehicles or to operate or permit to be operated a machine shop of any kind within the city, if such activity results in excessive noises which are detrimental or annoying to the public and plainly audible from a distance of 100 feet, between 10:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m. 
(Former § 9-007(4.)) 
Sec. 9-130. - Nuisance may be abated. 
    In any case where the owner or tenant of land in the city limits, or both, fails to comply with this section, then such failure to comply is hereby deemed a nuisance and the city judge may issue an order directing the nuisance to be abated. 
(1)  Notice of violation. Whenever it comes to the attention of the city manager that any violation of this section exists, a notice in writing shall be served upon the occupant of the land where the violation exists, and, if different, upon the owner of the land, notifying them of the existence of the violation and requesting its abatement 14 days after receipt of the notice. 
(2)  Time for abatement by owner or occupant. The owner or occupant as aforesaid shall have 14 days after receipt of the notice in subsection (1) above to come into compliance with this section. If compliance has not been completed within said 14 days, the city manager shall initiate an action for abatement in the city court and shall also seek the fines provided for below. 
(Former § 9-007(5.)) 
Sec. 9-131. - Covered area and establishments. 
    This section shall only apply within residential areas. 
(Former § 9-007(6.)) 
Sec. 9-132. - Violations and fines. 
    Any person violating this section shall be subject to a civil fine of not more than $200.00 per offense. Each time such violation is committed or permitted to continue shall be deemed a separate offense. 
(Former § 9-007(7.)) 
Chapter 10 - ALCOHOL AND ENTERTAINMENT REGULATIONS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Public alcohol consumption, § 9-6. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 10-1-10-25. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - REGULATIONS FOR THE SALE, TAX AND CONTROL OF MALT BEVERAGES AND WINE 

Sec. 10-26. - Purpose. 
    The purpose of this section is to establish and promulgate certain standards and regulations in regard to the sale, tax and control of malt beverages and wine in the city. 
(Former § 10-001(1.)) 
Sec. 10-27. - Definitions. 
    Alcohol means the product of distillation of any liquid, whether rectified or diluted, whatever may be the origin thereof, and shall include synthetic ethyl alcohol. 
    Church means a building used primarily for public religious worship on a regular basis. 
    License means the authorization by the council for a person to engage in retail sales of malt beverages and wine by the package, not for consumption on the premises of the licensee. 
    Licensee means any person, firm or corporation engaged in selling malt beverages and/or wine in unbroken packages at retail, not for consumption on the premises of the licensee. 
    Malt beverage means any beer, ale or like beverage. 
    Minor means the age established by O.C.G.A. § 3-3-23 or by other state laws regulating the sale of alcoholic beverages. 
    Permit means the authorization by the council for a wholesaler or wholesale distributor to engage in the wholesale sales of malt beverages and/or wine to retail licensees. 
    Person means any individual, partnership, corporation or association. 
    Retailer or retail distributor means any person or entity selling, at retail, malt beverages and/or wine. 
    School means a building, publicly or privately owned, used for teaching or giving instruction in any subject to pupils. 
    Wholesalers or wholesale distributor means any person, firm or corporation engaged in distribution or selling to retailers for the purpose of resale of malt beverages and/or wine. 
    Wine means the fermented juice of any fruit or plant having an alcoholic strength of no more than 21 percent alcohol by volume. 
(Former § 10-001(2.)) 
Sec. 10-28. - Eligibility requirements for malt beverage and wine license. 
(a)  Minimum age and residency of applicants. No malt beverage and wine license shall be granted to any person unless such person is at least 25 years of age and has been a resident of the State of Georgia, for a minimum of one year prior to filing an application for such license. In the event a corporation should be an applicant and said corporation has not been incorporated and/or allowed to do business by the secretary of state in Georgia for said one-year period, then the incorporator of said corporation and the owners of at least 80 percent of the stock of said corporation shall all have been residents of Georgia for at least one year prior to filing an application for such license. 
(b)  City employees not eligible for licenses; exception. No employee of the city, nor its mayor or members of its council, shall be eligible to receive a retail malt beverage and wine license; provided, however, that any non-profit corporation whose earnings are purely civic and for community purposes may be organized or owned by or operated by the mayor, members of council, and by employees of the city as the case may be. 
(c)  Required distances from schools, etc. No retail malt beverage and wine license shall be granted to any person unless the entire business premises of the proposed location is situated beyond 100 yards from the property line of any school grounds or college campus, the same to be measured by way of the nearest traveled road, street or highway, as provided by law. The council may require each application for a retail malt beverage and wine license to include a scale drawing of the location of the proposed premises showing the distance to the nearest school, and a certificate of a registered surveyor that such location complies with this section. 
(d)  Licenses required for each location. A separate retail malt beverage and wine license is required for each place of business. 
(e)  Building to be completed prior to issuance of license. No retail malt beverage and wine license shall be issued to any person unless the building in which the business will located is completed and detailed plans of said building and outside premises are attached to the application, or unless proposed plans and specifications and a building permit of a proposed building to be built are attached to the application. The completed building or the proposed building shall comply with all requirements of this Code governing building construction, permitting and code enforcement, and the regulations of the state revenue commissioner and the laws of the state. The proposed building shall also be subject to final inspection and approval, when completed, by the building inspector, in accordance with this Code. Each applicant for a retail malt beverage and wine license shall attach to his application evidence of ownership of the building or proposed building or a copy of the lease, if the applicant is leasing the building. 
(f)  Licenses not to be issued to felons; others. No applicant for a license who has a conviction or has pled nolo contendere to a felony or a misdemeanor involving moral turpitude shall be granted a license. 
(g)  Minimum percentage of non-beer and non-wine product sales required. No license shall be issued under this section to any public or private business or person unless such business or person derives at least 75 percent of its total annual gross sales income from the sale of products other than beer or wine. 
(h)  Minimum amount of non-beer and non-wine product sales required. No license shall be issued under this section to any public or private business or person unless such business or person has total annual gross sales income from the sale of products other than beer or wine in an amount exceeding $100,000.00 per calendar year. 
(i)  Council to consider other factors if necessary. The council, in its discretion, may consider any and all relevant circumstances which may reflect favorably or unfavorably on the applicant, application or proposed location of the business. If in its sole judgment, circumstances are such that the granting, suspension or revocation of the license would or would not be in the best interest of the general public, such circumstances may be grounds for the decision of the council. 
(Former § 10-001(3.)) 
Sec. 10-29. - License application and submission requirements. 
(a)  Expiration of licenses; re-application. A retail malt beverage and wine license shall be valid only for the calendar year indicated thereon and no such license may be renewed. A licensee who desires to continue in business during the next or subsequent calendar year must make a new application for such year on or before December 15 of the preceding year. 
(b)  State requirements to be met. In addition to the completion and submission of the application form as required by council, each applicant shall attach thereto a completed form with all attachments and requirements for a state license. 
(c)  Performance bond to be posted. Before any malt beverage and wine license is granted, the applicant must post with the council, along with his application, a performance bond with an insurance company as surety. Said bond is to be conditioned requiring the faithful observance and performance by the licensee of the rules and regulations contained in this section. Upon violation of any section herein, the amount of the bond to be forfeited will be determined by the seriousness of the violations as determined by the council. Said bond is to be approved by the council and shall be properly executed. Said bond shall be in the amount of $2,500.00 for a wholesale license and $500.00 for a retail license. 
(d)  Applications for licenses to be presented in person. All applications for a retail malt beverage and wine license shall be presented in person. 
(Former § 10-001(4.)) 
Sec. 10-30. - License fees and taxes on sales of malt beverage and wine. 
(a)  License fees to be paid before processing application. The annual fee for a retail malt beverage and wine license shall be $500.00 and shall be paid prior to the issuance of any license, said fee to accompany the application and be either in the form of cash or a bank certified check. All licenses shall expire on December 31 of the year granted. No license fee shall be prorated. 
(b)  Excise taxes on malt beverage and wine sales levied. In addition to the annual malt beverage and wine liquor license fee required, there is hereby levied an excise tax computed as follows: 
(1)  Wine sales. Wine shall be taxed at $0.22 a liter and a proportionate tax at like rates on all fractional parts of a liter. 
(2)  Beer sales. 
a.  Malt beverages, commonly known as tap or draft beer, sold in or from a barrel or bulk container, shall be at a rate of $6.00 on each container sold, containing not more than 15.5 gallons, and 
b.  Where malt beverages are sold in bottles, cans or other containers, except barrel or bulk containers, a tax of $0.05 per 12 ounces and a proportionate tax at the same rate on all fractional parts of 12 ounces. 
    Each wholesale distributor shall furnish to the council a summary of all purchase invoices for malt beverages and wine sold to each retailer in the city on or before the tenth day of each month following such purchase. Said invoices shall show the amount of excise tax paid. 
(Former § 10-001(5.)) 
Sec. 10-31. - Distribution permits for wholesalers. 
(a)  Permit requirements. Any wholesale distributor in malt beverages and wine licensed by the state or the agent of such licensed wholesale distributor, may be granted a permit to distribute such malt beverages and wine in the city, upon application of such permit to the clerk, and upon presentation of evidence satisfactory to the council that the applicant understands and will fully comply with all terms and conditions of this section governing the sale of malt beverages and wine, including but not limited to those under which retail licenses are issued. 
(b)  Permit fees and performance bonds required. Any wholesale distributor as described in subsection (a) above shall pay an annual fee of $500.00 prior to receiving a permit to distribute malt beverages and wine in the city. All wholesale distributors doing business in the city shall also be required to provide with the aforesaid application, a performance bond in the amount of $2,500.00 in cash or with security satisfactory and payable to the city. 
(Former § 10-001(6.)) 
Sec. 10-32. - Operating requirements of retail licensees. 
(a)  Telephone. A retail licensee shall maintain on the licensed premises at all times a telephone in good working order. 
(b)  Beverages to be covered or locked away on Sundays. On all Sundays, except 12:30 p.m. to 11:00 p.m., all licensees shall fully cover with opaque material or put under lock and key all malt beverages and/or wine on the premises of the licensee. 
(c)  Malt beverages to be transported to licensee in certain packages. All malt beverages transported or delivered to a retail licensee in the city shall be packaged in the following manner, to-wit: seven-, eight- or 12-ounce sealed containers packaged four, six or 12 per package; 16-ounce sealed containers packaged six per package; 24-ounce sealed containers packaged only by the full case; 32-ounce sealed containers packaged only by the case; and draft beer in sealed containers which contain one-half barrel, one-fourth barrel or any other size as draft beer is normally sold, transported and delivered in sealed containers within the state. 
(d)  Wine to be transported to licensee in certain packages. All wine transported or delivered to a retail licensee in the city shall be packaged in containers specified in the Standards of Fill for Wine prescribed by the Department of the Treasury of the United States for wines shipped in interstate commerce. The federal regulations relating to Standards of Fill for Wine adopted and incorporated by reference in this subsection. Wine manufactured and produced in Georgia shall be exempt from the provisions of this subsection to the extent that they are exempted from the provisions of O.C.G.A. § 3-6-28. 
(Former § 10-001(7.)) 
Sec. 10-33. - Sales and delivery of malt beverages and wine. 
(a)  General. No retailer shall sell or deliver malt beverages and/or wine except in said retailer's place of business. 
(b)  Times allowed for malt beverage and wine sales. No retailer shall furnish, sell or offer for sale malt beverages or wine: 
(1)  At any times except between 12:01 a.m. Mondays through and including 11:59 p.m. on Saturdays and on Sundays, from 12:30 p.m. to 11:00 p.m.; and 
(2)  At any time in violation of state law, state rules or regulations, local ordinances or regulations of the council, or on Christmas or Thanksgiving. 
(c)  Sales to certain persons prohibited. No person shall knowingly, directly or through another person offer for sale, sell, barter, exchange, give, provide or furnish malt beverages or wine to any person confined in any jail, penal institution, correctional facility, prison camp, penitentiary or other lawful place of confinement, or to any person who is a patient or inmate of the Central State Hospital, or to any person who is under the age of 21, or is noticeably intoxicated, or who is of unsound mind, or is a habitual drunkard whose intemperate habits are known to said license holder or employee. In addition, no person shall knowingly, directly or through another person offer for sale, sell, barter, exchange, give, provide or furnish malt beverages or wine to any individual unless said individual produces one or more pieces of picture identification which reasonably shows the individual customer to be the same person as in the subject picture and that the prospective buyer does not suffer from any of the aforesaid disqualifying conditions and/or statuses listed hereinbefore including, but not limited to, being under the age of 21. 
(d)  Licensee required to post sign. The holder of a license to sell malt beverages and wine shall post in a conspicuous place in his establishment a sign in letters at least four inches high reading as follows: SALE OF MALT BEVERAGES AND WINE TO PERSONS UNDER 21 YEARS STRICTLY PROHIBITED. 
(e)  Licensed retailers cannot operate as wholesalers. No licensed retailer shall keep any malt beverages or wine stored in any bonded or other type warehouse in the city, nor shall he enter into any type of arrangement whereby malt beverages or wine ordered by him by any licensed wholesaler. A retailer shall keep no inventory or stock of malt beverages and wine at any place except his licensed place of business, and within his licensed place of business. 
(f)  Licensee to retain regulations on premises; instruct employees about regulations. All holders of a license for the sale of malt beverages and wine shall keep a copy of this section pertaining to malt beverage and wine regulations, in his premises and shall instruct any person working there with respect to terms hereof and each licensee or his agents selling malt beverages and wine shall at all times be familiar with the terms hereof. The licensee shall be held responsible for any acts of his employees in any violations of this section or the laws of the state or the rules and regulations of the Georgia Revenue Commissioner. 
(g)  Licensee to keep premises open to inspection. The business premises of the holder of a retail malt beverages and wine license shall be open to inspection at any times by officials authorized to conduct such inspections. 
(h)  License shall be revoked for false information. The making of any statement on an application for license to sell malt beverages and wine later found to be false shall constitute grounds for revocation of said license. 
(i)  Age requirements of licensee's employees. No person under 18 years of age shall be employed in any capacity in any place of business licensed under this section. However, nothing contained herein shall prohibit persons under 18 years of age who are employed in supermarkets, convenience stores, breweries and drug stores from selling or handling malt beverages and wine which are sold for consumption off the premises. 
(j)  Games of chance prohibited on premises of licensee. 
(1)  Except for officially licensed sales and redemptions of Georgia Lottery tickets as contemplated in O.C.G.A. tit. 50, ch. 27; and except for coin operated slot machines, pin-ball machines, video games, arcade games and similar devices defined in O.C.G.A. § 50-27-70(b)(2)(A) which (i) depend on the skill of the player, (ii) do not pay out cash, (iii) which are expressly defined as bona fide coin operated amusement machines by state law (Collectively "COAM's") and (iv) which are expressly regulated as COAM's by O.C.G.A. § 50-27-70 through 50-27-104 and (v) for which each COAM a current Georgia "location" license and permit has been (a) procured and paid for, and (b) is in good standing, there shall be no gambling, betting, games of chance, punch boards, vending machines, slot machines, pinball machines, lotteries or tickets of chances therein or the operation of any schemes for hazarding money or any other thing of value in any licensed retailer's place of business or any room adjoining the same, owned, leased, or controlled by licensee. 
(2)  The General Assembly has found that the ability to operate a COAM business in this state constitutes a privilege and not a right. Nothing in this section shall be construed or have the effect to license, permit, authorize, or legalize any machine, device, table, or amusement machine the keeping, exhibition, operation, display, or maintenance of which is in violation of the laws or Constitution of this state. If a term is not defined below, the state law definition shall apply. 
    The city manager or designee ("city manager") shall provide for the proper administration of this section and act on behalf of the city for such purpose. The city manager may initiate investigations, hearings, and take other necessary measures to ensure compliance herewith or to determine whether violations exist. If the city manager finds evidence of any criminal violations, he/she shall notify the appropriate prosecuting attorney in the county in which such violation occurred. The city manager is authorized to provide for enforcement of this section and may delegate to an authorized representative any authority given to the city manager, including conduct of investigations, imposing of fees and fines, and holding of hearings. 
    As expressly authorized by state law, O.C.G.A. § 50-27-86, additional Requirements for COAM's, whether located on the premises of an Alcohol Licensee or not, follow: 
(1)  No more than six Class B machines that reward the player exclusively with noncash merchandise, prizes, toys, gift certificates, or novelties may be at the same business location. The city may, after no less than 60 days' notice to all master licensees and location owners and location operators, and consistent with O.C.G.A. § 50-27-103, vote to remove Class B machines from the city. 
Class B machine means a COAM that allows a successful player to accrue points on the machine and carry over points won on one play to a subsequent play or plays per O.C.G.A. § 16-12-35(d)(2) and: (a) Rewards a successful player in compliance with O.C.G.A. § 16-12-35(d)(1,2); and (b) Does not reward a successful player with any item prohibited as a reward in O.C.G.A. § 16-12-35(i) or any reward redeemable as an item prohibited as a reward in O.C.G.A. § 16-12-35(i). Further class B requirements follow: 
No COAM, its parts, or software or hardware shall be placed or leased in any location owner's/operator's establishment except by a master licensee and only if the owner or agent of the location owner/operator has entered into a written agreement with a master licensee for placement of the COAM. No person with or applying for a location owner's/operator's license shall have an interest in any person or immediate family member of a person with a master license, or doing business as a distributor, or manufacturer in this state. A location owner/operator may sell a COAM to anyone except another location owner or location operator. Violation may result in a state fine up to $50,000.00 and loss of license for one to five years per incident and subject the location owner/operator to loss of any other licenses held. 
Any written agreement entered after April 10, 2013, shall be exclusively between one COAM master licensee and one location owner/operator per location. No person shall receive any proceeds or revenue from operation of a COAM except the location owner/operator. No commission or fee shall be awarded for facilitation of a contract/agreement between a master licensee and a location owner/operator; provided, however, an employee of a master licensee may receive compensation, including a commission, for such agreements/contracts. A master licensee shall not pay commission or provide anything of value to an employee, independent contractor, or immediate family member of a location owner/operator; 
(2)  The owner/operator of a business location which offers to the public any COAM that rewards the player exclusively as described in O.C.G.A. § 16-12-35(d) must inform all employees of the prohibitions and penalties in O.C.G.A. § 16-12-35(e)-(g); 
(3)  The owner/possessor of any COAM that rewards the player exclusively as described in O.C.G.A. § 16-12-35(d) shall inform each location owner/operator where such COAM is located of the prohibitions and penalties in O.C.G.A. § 16-12-35(e)-(g); 
(4)  A license to manufacture, distribute, or sell alcoholic beverages or any other license granted by the city shall be suspended or revoked as a penalty for conviction of the location owner/operator of a violation of O.C.G.A. § 16-12-35(e)-(g). Due process shall be provided for refusal, suspension, or revocation of a license for manufacture, distribution, or sale of alcoholic beverages set out in O.C.G.A. § 3-3-2(b), including 30 days' written notice of the date and location of hearing and names of witnesses, notice of right to legal counsel, right to call and cross examine witnesses, and right to a public evidentiary hearing. The written notice may be served personally or by U.S. certified mail or statutory overnight delivery addressed to licensee at last known address. If notice cannot be effected by these methods after due diligence, the city may use any reasonable method of notice calculated to inform a person of average intelligence and prudence of the action, including publishing in a newspaper of general circulation in the area in which licensee conducts its business activities. The notice shall state with particularity the basis upon which the city is taking proposed actions; 
(5)  Penalties for violation include fines up to $1,000.00 per violation and/or suspension or revocation of a license as provided in paragraph (4) of this subsection, or both. Written notice shall be as follows: Delivery may be by: 
a.  Personal service on an individual licensee; 
b.  Personal service on any officer, director, partner, trustee, or receiver, as the case may be; 
c.  Personal service on the person in charge of the business premises, temporarily or otherwise, of licensee; 
d.  U.S. certified mail or statutory overnight delivery addressed to the business premises of licensee; or 
e.  Posting notice on the outside door of the business premises of licensee. 
Appeal by an affected person shall be to the superior court by petition for certiorari. The review shall be confined to the record. The court shall not substitute its judgment for that of the city as to the weight of the evidence on questions of fact committed to the discretion of the city. The court may affirm the decision in whole or in part; or reverse or remand the case for further proceedings if substantial rights of the appellant have been prejudiced because the city's findings, inferences, conclusions, or decisions are: (a) in violation of constitutional or statutory provisions; (b) in excess of the statutory authority of the city; (c) made upon unlawful procedures; (d) affected by other error of law; (e) not reasonably supported by substantial evidence in view of the reliable and probative evidence in the record as a whole; or (f) arbitrary or capricious or characterized by abuse of discretion or clearly unwarranted exercise of discretion. Appeal from any final judgment of the superior court may be taken in the manner provided for in civil actions generally; 
(6)  No location owner/operator shall derive more than 50 percent of monthly gross retail receipts for the business location in which Class B machine(s) is/are situated from Class B machines; however, revenues due to a master licensee or the corporation or noncash redemption earned by the player shall not be deemed revenue from Class B machines. Any location owner/operator subject to O.C.G.A. § 50-27-84(b)(1) must provide to the city a copy of each verified monthly report prepared per such Code. 
Said monthly verified report shall set out separately by each location in Georgia: gross receipts from Class B machines; gross retail receipts for the business location; and net receipts of Class B machines. No location owner/operator shall offer more than nine Class B machines to the public for play in the same business location; provided, however, this limitation shall not apply to an amusement or recreational establishment. The city may in its discretion perform an annual audit of reports from the location owner/operator. Any penalties authorized by O.C.G.A. § 50-27-84(d) may be imposed for any violation hereof. 
(7)  The location owner/operator which offers COAM's shall post prominently the following: 
GEORGIA LAW PROHIBITS PAYMENT OR RECEIPT OF MONEY FOR WINNING A GAME OR GAMES ON THIS AMUSEMENT MACHINE; PAYMENT OR RECEIPT OF MONEY FOR FREE REPLAYS WON ON THIS AMUSEMENT MACHINE; PAYMENT OR RECEIPT OF MONEY FOR ANY MERCHANDISE, PRIZE, TOY, GIFT CERTIFICATE, OR NOVELTY WON ON THIS AMUSEMENT MACHINE; OR AWARDING ANY MERCHANDISE, PRIZE, TOY, GIFT CERTIFICATE, OR NOVELTY OF A VALUE EXCEEDING $5.00 FOR A SINGLE PLAY OF THIS MACHINE. 
(8)  As a condition for doing business in the city, the location owner/operator must disclose in writing the name and address of the owner of the COAM's; 
(9)  All COAM's shall be placed and kept in plain view and accessible to any person at the business; 
(10)  Any business that offers COAM's must post its business license or occupation tax certificate. A copy of an owner's master license and the location owner's/operator's location license shall be prominently displayed at all locations where the owner and location owner/operator have COAM's available to evidence the payment of the fees levied under state law; 
(11)  It is a state law violation for a location owner/operator asking, demanding, or accepting anything of value, including but not limited to a loan or financing arrangement, gift, procurement fee, lease payments, revenue sharing, or payment of license fees or permit fees from a manufacturer, distributor, or master licensee, as an incentive, inducement, or any other consideration to locate a COAM in that establishment. A location owner/operator that violates this subsection may have all of the location owner/operator 's state business licenses revoked for one to five years per incident and be fined up to $50,000.00 per incident and required to repay any incentive fees or other payments received. 
(k)  Licenses to be kept on premises at all times. Licenses under this section of shall be displayed prominently at all times on the premises for which same was issued. 
(l)  Local, state and federal regulations all apply to licensee. No person shall engage in the sale of malt beverages and wine in the city, without first complying with all the rules and regulations set out in this section. Any person violating the rules and regulations set out in this section shall be subject to revocation of his license and punishment as prescribed by the mayor and council. Each licensee doing business in the city under this section shall comply with all state laws, federal laws, and rules and regulations of the state revenue commissioner relating to the sale or distribution of malt beverages and wine in Georgia, and any violation of same shall subject the licensee to immediate suspension or revocation of his retail malt beverage and wine license and also shall subject said licensee to criminal prosecution as provided by law. 
(m)  Process for making decisions on permits. The granting or refusal and the suspension or revocation of retail and wholesale and pouring permits and licenses under this section shall be in accordance with the following guidelines of due process: 
(1)  The provisions of this section as same may be amended shall constitute ascertainable standards upon which all decisions pertaining to these permits or licenses shall be based; 
(2)  All decisions approving, denying, suspending or revoking such permits or licenses shall be in writing with the reasons therefor stated, and mailed or delivered to the applicant; and 
(3)  Upon timely application, any applicant aggrieved by the decision of the mayor and council regarding a permit or license shall be afforded a hearing with an opportunity to present evidence and cross-examine opposing witnesses. 
(n)  Licenses not transferable. No retail malt beverage and wine license shall be transferable or assignable to any person or other location. In the event that a licensed business is sold or closed, it shall be the duty of the new owner or occupant to apply for a license which may or may not be granted. 
(o)  Exceptions on prohibition of sales. The prohibition in this section to individuals under the age of 21 shall not apply with respect to malt beverages, wine and/or any other alcoholic beverage for consumption in the following instances: 
(1)  For medical purposes per a prescription of a physician duly authorized to practice medicine in Georgia; 
(2)  At a religious ceremony; or 
(3)  In the individual's home with parental consent. 
(Former § 10-001(8.)) 
Sec. 10-34. - Violations and penalties. 
    Any violation of this section shall subject the offender to a fine of not more than $1,000.00 for each violation in addition to such violation being a cause for revocation or suspension of the license of the offending licensee by the mayor and council and criminal prosecution as well as forfeiture of all stock of malt beverages and wine. A license holder who sells or does not prevent the sale at his establishment of beer or wine to an ineligible individual under this section (including but not limited to a person under the age of 21 and/or sells during hours and/or days on which sales of beer or wine are prohibited under this section who is found guilty after the aforesaid hearing under this section hereof shall generally receive a minimum of a 30-day suspension of his license and a fine of $500.00. A second offense of a similar nature which results in a finding of a guilty within five years of the first offense conviction shall generally result in a minimum of the revocation of the license for the balance of the year and a fine of $1,000.00. All of the punishments listed herein are those an individual who is found guilty of said offenses can expect to receive as a minimum although the mayor and council will make the final decision in each case and has the right to impose sentences and fines different from those previously specified. In addition to and without limiting the foregoing, the city shall be authorized to make appropriate application to subject the offender to criminal penalties provided for under any law of Georgia which may have been violated by the offender's conduct in violation of this section. 
(Former § 10-001(9.)) 
Secs. 10-35-10-50. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - BEER AND WINE POURING LICENSES 

Sec. 10-51. - Purpose; definitions. 
(a)  Purpose. In accordance with the laws of the state, it is necessary and expedient for the city to establish and promulgate certain standards and regulations in regard to the sale for consumption on the premises of malt beverages and wine. This section does not permit the sale of distilled spirits by the drink or otherwise for consumption on the premises. Such sale of distilled spirits by the drink or otherwise for consumption on the premises is expressly prohibited under this section. 
(b)  Definitions. As used in this article, defined words shall have the meanings specified unless the context in which the word or term is used clearly requires that a different meaning be used. 
    Alcoholic beverage(s) means all alcohol, distilled spirits, beer, malt beverages, wine, or fortified wine. 
    Church means building primarily used for public religious worship on a regular basis. 
    City clerk means the clerk of the City of Social Circle, Georgia; 
    City manager means the manager of the City of Social Circle, Georgia; 
    Distilled spirits means alcoholic beverage with more than 21 percent alcohol by volume including, but not limited to, all fortified wines. 
    License ("pouring license") means the authorization by the mayor and council to engage in the retail sale of malt beverages and wine to be consumed only on the licensed premises. 
    Licensee means any person who has been issued a retail consumption dealer license by the mayor and council to engage in the sale of malt beverages and wine for consumption only on the licensed premises and not for resale. 
    Lounge means a separate room where malt beverages and wine are served by the drink which is either connected with or part of a restaurant and operated in conjunction with and under the same management as the restaurant operations. 
    Malt beverage(s) means any beer, ale or like beverage made from malt by fermentation. 
    Person means any individual, firm, partnership, cooperative, non-profit membership corporation, joint venture, association, company, corporation, agency, syndicate, estate, trust, business trust, receiver, fiduciary, or other entity, group or combination acting as a unit, body politic, or political subdivision, whether public, private, or quasi-public. 
    Place of business means the premises described in the licenses issued pursuant to this section. 
    Premises means the location where licensee is authorized to sell malt beverages and wine. 
    Restaurant means any public or private place kept, used, maintained, advertised and held out to the general public as a place where meals are served and where meals are actually and regularly served, without sleeping accommodations.
